I'd rather call this RimMod than RimWorld.

I played vanilla for the first 20 hours. And it was an o-kay game. However, I felt that there were many features lacking that I could not do with the game that is supposed to be IN THE GAME. So I was ready to uninstall it when I saw the reviews that this game is much better with mods.

So here I was dived deep into the workshop and found a lot of interesting ones. I sorted the mods according to the number of subscriptions and decided to install everything that looked good... which I ended up installing 233 mods in total. I even said to myself that if these hundreds of mods didn't work and gave me a crash error, I would immediately uninstall it. So when I restarted the game to boot up all the mods, it hung up and crashed because it took longer than normal, and I clicked on it accidentally. I gave it one last chance and decided to uninstall some mods, making it around 100-200 mods, realizing there were duplicate same-feature mods. And then wait patiently to load the game for a while, not even using my second monitor to browse.

The game and mod integrated successfully after a few minutes and was playable. It gave me more quality of gaming experience than the vanilla. This game is one of those game that I find starting a new game is alright.

I would rate vanilla 7/10, and modded 9/10. I haven't bought DLCs yet, maybe after I had more time to play the game.

The only thing I hate is the A.I Narrator and events, nothing much to expect like what is advertised.
I feel like this game  has the  personality that many strategy games lack

RimWorld, the acclaimed colony simulation game developed by Ludeon Studios, is an immersive journey into the depths of outer space where survival is not just a goal but a constant struggle against the odds. With its blend of complex systems, emergent storytelling, and strategic depth, RimWorld offers an experience that is as challenging as it is rewarding.

At its core, RimWorld tasks players with managing a group of colonists stranded on a remote planet, each with their own unique skills, traits, and quirks. From constructing shelters and gathering resources to fending off hostile creatures and rival factions, every decision carries weight and consequences that ripple throughout the game world.

What truly sets RimWorld apart is its dynamic AI storyteller, which constantly throws curveballs at players in the form of random events, ranging from pirate raids and toxic fallout to sudden outbreaks of disease and power outages. This unpredictability keeps players on their toes, fostering a sense of tension and urgency that drives the gameplay forward.

The depth of RimWorld's simulation is staggering, with players tasked with managing everything from food and shelter to social relationships and mental health. The game's intricate systems interconnect in meaningful ways, creating a web of dependencies and interactions that require careful planning and foresight to navigate successfully.

Visually, RimWorld may not boast the most cutting-edge graphics, but its charming pixel art style is brimming with personality and charm. From the diverse biomes and landscapes to the quirky colonists and bizarre creatures that inhabit them, RimWorld's world feels alive and vibrant, drawing players in and immersing them in its richly detailed universe.

While RimWorld is not without its challenges, including a steep learning curve and occasional bouts of frustration due to its unforgiving nature, the sense of satisfaction that comes from overcoming obstacles and building a thriving colony is unparalleled. With its endless replayability and modding support, RimWorld offers countless hours of entertainment for players willing to brave its harsh and unforgiving world.

In conclusion, RimWorld is a masterpiece of simulation gaming, offering a rich and immersive experience that will keep players coming back for more time and time again. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of the genre or a newcomer looking for a fresh challenge, RimWorld is an essential addition to any gamer's library, delivering endless hours of strategic depth, emergent storytelling, and nail-biting excitement. (yeah I went too far with that storyteller)

Rimworld: Where Survival Meets Quirky Storytelling in the Galaxy's Weirdest Sandbox

If life on the rim of the galaxy has taught me anything, it's that cannibalism is a viable career path, and that's just the tip of the iceberg in the enchanting chaos that is Rimworld.

Picture this: crash-landed on a distant planet with a handful of colonists, each with their own unique set of issues. Rimworld is the ultimate exercise in playing celestial landlord to a bunch of hapless spacefarers. But beware, this game is not for the faint of heart or those with a soft spot for emotional stability. It's a rollercoaster of joy, despair, and an odd fondness for manhunting squirrels.

First things first, the learning curve is steeper than a mountain range on an alien world. You'll find yourself wondering if your colonists have a secret pact with Murphy's Law, as disasters seem to strike just when you've finally managed to erect a moderately decent shelter. But hey, that's what makes Rimworld strangely addictive.

The beauty of Rimworld lies in its unpredictability. One moment you're celebrating a successful harvest, and the next, a psychic ship crashes, unleashing a wave of mechanoid invaders. It's like the universe has a cruel sense of humor, and your colonists are the punchline. Yet, there's a strange joy in watching your survivors conquer adversity, be it a sudden raid or a particularly harsh winter.

The game's storyteller AI is the puppet master pulling the strings of your digital puppets, and it's got a penchant for drama. Cassandra Classic will keep you on your toes, mercilessly throwing curveballs at your fragile colony, while Randy Random is the true chaos agent, capable of delivering blissful prosperity or cataclysmic ruin at a moment's notice. Choose your storyteller wisely; your sanity may depend on it.

The depth of Rimworld extends beyond survival and resource management. The game's penchant for emergent storytelling is where it truly shines. Your colonists develop relationships, quirky traits, and tragic backstories that unfold as you play. From the alcoholic doctor who's also an excellent marksman to the nudist botanist who excels at social interactions, each character is a narrative waiting to unfold.

However, Rimworld isn't just about the serious business of surviving against the odds; it's about having fun with the absurdity of it all. Who knew that a colony's success could hinge on the culinary arts of your resident chef, who has a penchant for creating lavish meals out of simple ingredients and a dash of creativity? Rimworld does.

In conclusion, Rimworld is a masterpiece of chaos, an uncharted galaxy of storytelling, and a testament to the resilience of colonists who can bounce back from anything‚Äîbe it a toxic fallout, a volcanic winter, or the untimely demise of their favorite pet warg. So, if you're up for a challenge and a healthy dose of dark humor, dive into Rimworld; just remember to bring some spare socks for your colonists‚Äîthey'll need them.

Long time ago when I was still a young kid, in the middle of RTS boom, I had a hope that one day I'll see a video game that isn't focused so much on battle/war aspect, but rather take base building to the extreme where we'll build our own castles, fortresses, defenses and our only goal will be to survive ever-increasing waves of enemies.

Years later, long after RTS boom has ended, I've never found my dream game from early childhood. Sure, there were games which were more-or-less about the same concept, like Settlers or Civilization, but it wasn't what I dreamed of, just something that can be considered close enough. There was a Dwarf Fortress as well, but it seemed too awkward even for me. My dream was still unfulfilled.

...until two games came out in 2017 and 2018 - They are Billions and Rimworld, respectively. This review is about the second one, Rimworld.

Rimworld is survival-oriented base building management game. While They are Billions matched my initial dream expectations more, I consider Rimworld one of the best games I've ever played, due to the complexity of the simulation, polished and enjoyable gameplay and the fact that there is no run that looks the same, there is always something to improve or to do, and the game doesn't stop to amaze me.

I'm deeply shocked how much work and thought was put into Rimworld as a whole, it's clear as day that the devs put a lot of effort and love into this game. Personally I'd love to see only one single thing added - the actual campaign/scenarios that would put us into predefined positions and expect from us to meet certain goal, whether it'd be survival, establishing peaceful relations with some faction or anything else. However, everything in the base game is polished to perfection, and I'm very happy that I've found RimWorld, a game which fulfilled my children dreams of a complex base-building game.

I can wholeheartedly recommend this masterpiece to every person that is interested in checking out how a perfect definition of base-building management looks like. I've barely finished a single playthrough during my 80 hours with this game, and I know that it isn't even everything that the game has to offer, let alone consider it finished. This is my current definition of how a good base-bulding game should look like, and I had a lot of fun from every single hour spent with this title, and a lot more to come.

July was all alone, but she was strong in every way. Of course she was going to survive!
But, one day she got food poisoning, threw up everywhere. And while this happened, a wild mare became mad. It was a tough battle, the mare went down. July then felt bad, so she was on her way picking up medicine to rescue her, but then she collapsed, right in front of all the high quality medicine. She thought "Well, if I just lay still, maybe I will heal and at least get rid of the poisoning so I can tend to myself." But oh so wrong she was, because then MALARIA hit her like a STONE. And she thought that this will be her death. Little did she know, a raider came and set fire to her base.
She turned to ashes in the hot flames, never to be reborn.

That's when I wanted to throw the screen out of the window, but I didn't. I took a deep breath, and made a new game... BEHOLD JULY 2.0! She's going to survive... right?

Title: A Masterpiece of Storytelling and Survival

RimWorld is more than just a game; it's an experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. Set in a distant and unforgiving frontier, RimWorld challenges players to survive, thrive, and ultimately, create their own epic tales.

At its core, RimWorld is a colony simulation game where players manage a group of survivors stranded on a harsh, procedurally generated planet. From managing resources to defending against hostile forces, every decision shapes the destiny of your colony.

What sets RimWorld apart is its unparalleled storytelling capabilities. Each colonist comes with a unique set of traits, skills, and personal histories, leading to dynamic interactions and unexpected events. From tragic love affairs to heroic last stands, RimWorld weaves captivating narratives that keep players invested for hours on end.

The depth of RimWorld's gameplay is staggering. Whether it's researching advanced technologies, trading with passing caravans, or taming wild animals, there's always something new to discover. The game's modding community further extends its longevity, offering limitless possibilities for customization and creativity.

Visually, RimWorld adopts a simple yet charming art style that complements its complex gameplay mechanics. While the graphics may not rival blockbuster titles, RimWorld's focus on gameplay depth and narrative richness more than compensates for any visual shortcomings.

In summary, RimWorld is a triumph of game design‚Äîan immersive and endlessly replayable experience that invites players to write their own stories of triumph and tragedy on the outer rim of the galaxy. Whether you're a veteran strategist or a newcomer to the genre, RimWorld offers something truly special that shouldn't be missed.

Clearly, there's something I like about this game, since steam says I've played it for a total of 85 hours. And I'd say it's primarily the base building and micro-managing, but I think a small part of it would be what happens when things go wrong. Sure it's fun to have a thriving colony, but I'll never forget the time when one of my colonists had a mental break, dug up a corpse, paraded it around the barracks and plopped it down on the table for everyone to see. I've seen other reviews compare it to dwarf fortress, but I'd say it's equally like cult of the lamb. Because all 3 games are like micro-managing a kindergarten classroom, except you can kill the ones you don't like. And maybe feed them to the others, but that's up to the player.

very atmospheric, and manages to keep a personal relationship with each pawn even though you are managing a colony. this personal nature makes the game feel very special, in addition to the polished gameplay. the modding community is extraordinary and I believe the best of any game I'v interacted with including skyrim, and there is so much content for whataver you want to do, I have added so much to my game that all feels very balanced and in the style and spirit of the game. the art style itself is also very timeless and works very well to make the game replayable. saying "replayable" is odd in this context however, as I think rimworld is an independent experience in each playthrough that feels like its own genuine story especially if you put time into lore and whatnot in character creation and faction etc which goes far to make a colony feel special, but this is not whatsoever to say that the game does not do well to develop its own story.

Rimworld is a lovable mess of a game that has only gotten better with age. I started playing a few years ago when the game went on sale and I've been a massive fan ever since. 

The studio behind Rimworld, Ludeon Studios, is a indie dev team that (imo) has pumped out consistent and well made updates since at least I've started playing. As far as I can tell, they have a good reputation and treat their team well. 

Another great aspect of the game is its active modding community. Rivaled only by games like Minecraft, Terraria, and PD2, there is hundreds and thousands of mods to enhance the base game, with many of the mods being what most would consider DLC worthy -- all for free.

If you ever are in need of a new game to sink a thousand plus hours into, this very well might be your match!

An extremely versatile game with endless hours of actually good content.  A vibrant modding community allowing for truly endless customization.  The stories you create can be as silly or dramatic or horrifying as you want them to be-- and it's truly gratifying to overcome the hardest challenges and survive for another day.

While the game can have an initial learning curve (that never ends, to be honest), both it and its expansions are some of the select few titles that actually are worth the cost when not on sale.

Highly recommend for anyone who enjoys colony sims and going tunnel vision on a game you can return to year after year and still find high levels of enjoyment-- even if you've been over a decade on from alpha.

Game is good, but I think its abandoned now. There are a lot of bugs in the core system, faults with logic subroutines for pawns, pets, animals which haven't been fixed, and I suspect wont be. I took to redit in search of support, to find that the community is so used to dealing with the faults, that they have specific workarounds for the issues with the game. Workarounds which cause their own problems, and workarounds for those too. Not to mention a culture of down voting any form of complaint or issue raising. I've found that the closed minded, sometimes cult-like community, along with the issues and faults in the core game, to be completely off putting. I think the game has the potential to be great, but with a community like this, and that it looks like no other updates are coming through, I cannot suggest buying this game. You need to be prepared to mod the game to bits, or have a complex weave of workarounds in order to get by.

This is one of my favorite games, but I do not recommend it. This is because to make the game great, *mods* are required. That means, the vanilla game lacks (in my opinion) some *fundamental details*.

If you are okay with modding, THIS GAME IS AMAZING. But the price of the base game with such glaring oversights is not worth it.

- There is almost a solid base game here. However, there are WAY too many things that require mods.

Why can the colonists only carry one weapon? [sidearm mod]
Why do they haul things away that aren't needed? [haul? mod]
Why do most visitors just walk around despite the weather? [Hospitality mod - to a degree (it only applies to *some* types of visitors)]

And the one that prompted this negative review (the straw on the camel):

Why is Neutroamine *NOT CRAFTABLE*?!?! This one just doesn't make sense. Medicine is a near crucial part of the game. Medicine manufacturing is unlocked later in the research tree. However, neutroamine is necessary to make medicine. Yet *it is only available through trade*. WHY!?!? If traders have it *SOMEONE* has the skill to collect or create it! My colonists can do nearly everything else - but they can't create a key chemical for medicine.

Nothing should be locked behind trade except for logistical necessity (e.g, my base is in an area that simply does not have limestone - so I must trade for it...)

If the devs *were* still working on such basic QoL things, I could recommend this game knowing that these would be addressed - unfortunately, it seems like they are following the cash cow and focusing on DLCs (which are GREAT, but the silly simple issues still stay.).

For a better optimised vanilla experience on the same wavelength as RimWorld - I *highly* recommend checking out Oxygen Not Included.

When I first watched a streamer play this, I was very unsure if this game was for me. I mean the way their colony died was pretty funny not gonna lie. But I'm so terrible at strategy games, which is why I rarely play this genre. But Rimworld made me give it a chance.
As you can see I have spent little over 2k hours on this game. Somehow I can't get enough Randy's bs x.x

Alright to the serious topic. Yes this game do not look very pretty, which is one of the reasons some people avoid the game.
Others avoid cause it is too hard of a game, and losing over and over again is not fun for everybody, which is totally fair.
Some people avoid it, cause it is too pricey. Sure you don't save alot on discounts, but there is a reason why this game has this pricetag. It is such an amazing game, and it has alot of replayability. This game has brought me a rollercoaster of emotions, and I have not regretted paying full price for it. I got my money's worth.

I have no clue where to start to be honest. So let me ask you: What do you want to do with your colony?
Raid every factions and wipe them all out before leaving the planet?
Or try and make friends with almost everybody before you head out to space?
Maybe you wanna settle down and make dinner and clothing out of these silly raiders that tries to wipe you out.
Parhaps you want to train every single deadly animal and create an army of wildlives. 
Oh maybe you wanna try to be the richest colony in the world. WARNING you may get alot of raiders, who is trying to kill and steal your goods. Wealth makes raids more tough.
No hmm how about being the local druglord, who sells alot of drugs to other factions.
Mayhaps you wanna do alot of serious warcrimes cough havesting cough.
Or maybe you always wanted to create an army of cyborgs, and destroy everything and everyone who dare to challenge you.
It could also be you wanna try and see how long you can survive in one run.
If you are looking for some sort of a challenge. You could try and do every single quest that pops up. I mean what could go wrong?
Another idea a cult that will sacrifice prisoners and animals to the greater will or god. Cough Cult of N'zoth cough.
I mean you can pretty much make a RP run if you like.
But yeah there is endless ideas what you could do with your colony so go crazy.

Now I do praise this game alot but it also has it flaws.
You can have a colonist waking into the fire, cause why take the time to walk around the fire am I right. Their pathing is not the smartest. You have to be on the lookout so they don't do dumb things.
Raiders can have some odd goals for themself. Like destroying animal sleeping spots. For some reason they really like destroying my pen, and let out all the animals. Sometimes they also want to kill the animals. I can't say for sure if this still happends since I more and less now avoid having animals.
Caravan system is not the greatest. I hate it from time to time. It's hard to explain what I hate about it, but all I can say it feels wonky.
The reputation system is also wonky. If a random predetor kills a faction's chicken or any other animal. They will blame you for it's death, and you get -rep for it. Kinda dumb if I have to be honest. I have been blamed alot.
Raiders, mechs and ant one shot is pretty annoying. You can have the best armor in the game. Yet you can still be one shotted by an arrow to the face. Like huh how is that even possible with the best gear in the game?
This is more and less my issues with the game. Dispire all that, I can still have the time of my life with this game.

Now to the storytellers.
Storytellers are those you creates the events, that is happing withing the game. It can be raids, mad animals, traders, pod crash and so on.
Cassandra is not a very nice storyteller. She is ruthless and merciless. She will strike when your colony do pretty good most of the time. In my experince, she has a happit of sending too many mechs. It can be rough so be well prepared.
Penelope was suppost to be the chill storyteller. She is not chill if your wealth is too high. She kinda goes like cassandra, and go all in to destory your colony. So remember to check you colony wealth, so you can prepare for her attacks.
Now to our favorite storyteller Randy Random. I have a feeling Randy is peoples go to story teller, because he do not care about the rules. He can make the game very interesting, since you never know when Randy demands BLOOD. Many colonies has fallen to O'mighty Randy and some colonies has escaped him.
At first I took Cassandra, but I got tired of the endless swarm of mechs, so I went with Randy Random. Randy can be unfair from time to time, but he brings the most crazy storytelling. It's a rollercoaster of fun and pain. As they say Randy gives and Randy takes.
But if you fear Randy's random demands of blood, you can give Penelope a try, since she should be the beginner friendly storyteller.

Now this game has a high learning curve. You will lose alot, but every story is not the same. Losing is part of the game. So don't be upset, but try to learn from your mistakes. Once you get the hang of it, I'm sure you can beat Randy and his rat army.
There is many things you have to look out for. Your colonies health, mental health, mood and their limbs. Yes your pawns might lose a limb or two.
Base layout is also pretty important. You don't want raiders to go inside from you front door, unless you have a plan. But yeah make sure you have some sort of a good defense, so you can gain the upper hand.
And for pete's sake DON'T attack the peaceful thrumbos, if you are not prepared. You will regret it, I'm telling you right now!

Getting bored of the vanilla game? Fear not Rimworld has a very awesome modding community. You wanna spice things up? I'm sure you can find just the right mods for that.
Wanna make the game little easier? There is some nice qol mods and some good turret mods, that will make sure the raiders pays with their blood for trying to invade you.
Or maybe you want more vanilla kind of things? Vanilla extended has you covered.
I'm sure you can find whatever mod that suits your fancy.
So a huge thank you to the modders in the rimworld community for you hard work to keep the mods up and running. Also thank you for creating these mods aswell.

Now to my little short story.
I had a raid coming and I managed to defeat them. Unfortunate I had a very heavy wounded guy, who was taken to the hospital as fast as possible. My doctor was supposed to tend to the wounded but.. Yeah my doctor was busy sleeping, so the guy bled out.
Few days later we held a funeral for the fallen. The moral guy spoke two words. Went on a mental break down ''Corpse obsseion'' Dug up the fallen pawn and slammed him on the table and left to her room. The rest of the colony found the funeral heartwarming.
So it was heartwarming to dig up a dead pawn and slam them on the table for the world to see? I'm not sure, how heartwarming that was but okay. #onlyinrimworld

I think I have covered more and less everything. I will let you explore the rest, if you decide to pick up the game.

realistic, challenging, immersive, engaging.

RimWorld is nothing short of a masterpiece, seamlessly blending intricate storytelling with the challenges of survival in a vast and unpredictable world. From crash-landing on an unknown planet to managing a diverse group of colonists, every moment in RimWorld is a gripping tale waiting to unfold.

The level of detail and depth in RimWorld is astounding. The AI storyteller weaves a complex narrative, throwing unexpected events and challenges at you, keeping you engaged and on your toes. Whether it's fending off raids, dealing with natural disasters, or managing the quirks and relationships of your colonists, every decision feels consequential and adds layers to the evolving story of your colony.

The open-ended nature of RimWorld allows for unparalleled creativity. Base-building is a rewarding puzzle, and the ability to shape your colony according to your vision is both satisfying and challenging. The modding community further enhances the game, offering a vast array of options to tailor the experience to your preferences.

The characters in RimWorld are more than just pawns; they're individuals with unique personalities, skills, and quirks. The emotional attachment that develops as you guide them through triumphs and tragedies is a testament to the game's immersive storytelling.

RimWorld is a game that keeps drawing you back in, thanks to its depth, replayability, and the sheer joy of watching your colony thrive against all odds. It's a journey of survival, resilience, and unexpected twists that cements its place as one of the finest games in the colony simulation genre.

[h3]=+ 20 March, 2023. - 2nd review +=[/h3]
Rimworld should be everyone's go-to game to relax in any life situation.
Normally I play on my custom built gaming PC which can run big games,
but since start of march 2023, I am unable to have my gaming PC with me
and in an attempt to get to enjoy playing some games (maybe, wasn't sure I'd be able)
I got myself a mini computer, quite small, runs windows 10, but not lots of games plays on it.
fortunately enough, i got a spacious external SSD.
I tried a few games. Project zomboid, doesn't work (sad) thought it would.
tried Zero Sievert. no luck.
Then I tried Rimworld. to my surprise, Rimworld plays very well on such a small low end PC.
I even got a few mods installed and it still plays well. ok, not the full set of mods i used to play with, but it plays well.
I cant be less grateful for the creator/devs who made this game play so well. 10/10
Now if you are a lover a colony building, survival game like me.
Rimworld is my #1 recommendation for you.
plays basically on anything you can call a computer ;D

What can I say about this game. Is it the prettiest game? No. Does it have the most in your face action packed shoot em up game play ever to grace the PC gaming world? Nope. But you know what it does have? Endless replayability and story opportunity. The game itself without any mods could have you telling the tale of a naked dude, crash landed on an alien planet fighting for their lives and just trying to scrape by in one game, then as a group of tribal people fleeing from an apocalyptic event, looking for a new home. Add mods in and... well shit... I created a custom race of Amazon Mer-Women that believed femininity was the apex of civilization and would capture any male raiders, implanting them with their offspring, and keeping them prisoner until the child was born, sending them away after as penance for their transgressions against their little village on the waters edge. The game gets wild and it's more fun when you just let it play out. Losing a colony starts off frustrating and then becomes this kind of goofy "Awww shit, that was one hell of end to the people of Derpy Derpy... time to make a new colony."
"Do you think if we take the prisoner's lungs out and swap them with our asthmatic colonist's lungs we could give the prisoner asthma and cure our colonist?"

RimWorld is one of my 'if you could only take one game with you to a deserted island' games. I always get back to it eventually, even if I take a break to play other things for a few months.

There's a complex web of ways to play it, whether vanilla or increasingly with all the amazing mods in the workshop, so different playthroughs can truly have different vibes, and you can make it almost as easy as you'd like for one play, or extremely hard to suit one's mood.

Want a farming simulator? You can do that. Hardcore colony survival? That's the 'usual' game. Want lots of fighting or want to turn off violent events? Be altruistic good guys or commit fictional war crimes? There's not one 'right' way to play and I greatly appreciate its scope.
I may declare that the game illuminated in this review is exceptional. Buy it. If you are not invited by my humble invitation, thou must be mildly mistaken and bewildered. Do not wait, purchase now!
There is so much you can do in the game, it really never gets boring. The workshop also allows for so much more to do as well and I love it.

RimWorld isn't just a game; it's an experience. From the moment you crash-land onto your chosen RimWorld, you're sucked into a whirlwind of storytelling, survival, and unexpected twists. It's no exaggeration to say that I've lost entire days to this game, and I regret none of it.

What sets RimWorld apart is its unparalleled depth and replayability. Even without the DLCs, which I highly recommend as they add even more layers of complexity and enjoyment, the base game stands strong on its own. The sheer variety of scenarios, from building a thriving colony to weathering the harshest of environments, ensures that no two playthroughs are ever the same.

But what truly elevates RimWorld to greatness is its vibrant modding community. Thanks to the dedication and creativity of mod authors, there's a seemingly endless supply of content to explore. Whether you're looking for quality of life improvements, new challenges, or entirely new gameplay mechanics, the mods for RimWorld have you covered. And the best part? Even after sinking countless hours into the game, there's always a new mod or combination of mods to breathe fresh life into your RimWorld experience.

If you haven't experienced the joy and frustration (in the best possible way) of RimWorld yet, I highly recommend diving in and discovering what makes it one of my all-time favorite games.

RimWorld is an absolute blast, offering an immersive survival experience where your decisions shape the outcome. With its captivating storytelling, strategic challenges, and endless opportunities for creativity through mods, it's a game that keeps you hooked. Despite its simple graphics, its charm and atmosphere make it incredibly fun to play. It's a must-try for anyone who loves gaming for the sheer enjoyment it brings.
oh my god make it stop please

RimWorld is one of the best strategy games ever made. It has an amazing amount of content and a level of difficulty that not many games can match. The Ludeon Studios-made game is a masterpiece of spontaneous stories and strategic gameplay. Players are in charge of a colony of survivors on a faraway planet.

Realistic simulations of people and their connections are what "RimWorld" is all about. Each colonist has a unique past and set of personality traits that affect how they act and talk to other people. The game's health system is just as realistic, simulating accidents and diseases in a way that affects people in a variety of, often shocking, ways.

The setting of the game is also always changing. There are many problems that players have to deal with, such as bad weather and pirate attacks, which makes each game play different and uncertain. An important part of the game is the AI storyteller, which changes the difficulty and events based on the player's situation to keep things fair and interesting.

The "RimWorld" extra material (DLC) makes the game even better to play. "Royalty," the first big DLC, adds a new group of royal titles, mental skills, and quests to the game, giving the story and tactics a new twist. The "Ideology" DLC gives players the tools to give their colony its own unique social and cultural identities. This gives the game a level of depth and flexibility that has never been seen before.

The active mod community in "RimWorld" is one of the things that makes it so interesting. The game has a lot of mod support, which lets players make the experience fit their needs. From making life better to completely changing the game, the changes in the workshop give the game new life and make sure it will be played again and again.

"RimWorld" is more than just a game; it's a place where stories can be told, a place where methods can be tested, and a place where modeling complexity can be shown off. Fans of simulation games can't miss this game because it has detailed city management, a deep story, and strong mod support. "RimWorld" has a world that is always interesting and makes you want to come back, whether you're a planner, a writer, or a maker.
If you like colony sim games, this one is great. Give it a go, you won't be disappointed.

Rimworld is my first real experience of a story telling game that actually allows me to tell stories, thanks to its highly flexible mechanics and extensive mod support.

Once the mechanics are understood and the game aspect no longer acts as a challenge on its own (which will take a bit as there Is a lot to learn) you can start making your own goals and scenarios using the building blocks given by the game, its excellent dlcs and the seemingly infinite supply of mods. 

If you're a dwarf fortress player, the first immediate "drawback" is the lack of Z depth, but after playing the game for a bit I stopped missing it, as the overworld aspect can act as a Z layer as well. For me rimworld offers a more polished, open ended feel than dwarf fortress ever did, so while I appreciate df trailblazing the genre, rimworld realized its promise better.

Fun!

Here we are, six years later. So much stuff has happened in the world. I've developed a general malaise, as has nearly everyone else of the human species on this planet, when something comes over my YT Music playlist.  A familar riff: Em, D, A, Em, C, A. A beautiful whistle accompanies the chords. And it drags you back, in one instant, not to the first time you hear this amazing track, but the first time you find out you've developed an emotional attachment to one of your pawns.  A tear starts to leak from your eye. Then another, as your other pawns, also crying, carry the fallen pawn to the graveyard, and hold a short service. Life had become so brutal since the crash onto this Rimworld. And your pawns which you've come to see as your children struggle every day to have a decent life. You see yourself in these pawns, how they are almost a reflection of you, and losing one feels like losing part of ones self.  And then Alastair Lindsey's Moving On plays.  I'm convinced there's a hidden "emotional level" variable in the game, because that song always cues not right as tragic or beautiful or emotional events happen, but about 30 seconds later when you're just starting to process just what has happened. 

This game means something different to everyone. But I highly encourage you to find out what that is, because on the Rimworlds.... you just.might find yourself.

I have put 860 hours into this game so far and I'm nowhere near sick of playing it. It's the ultimate dopamine tickler. I tend to go through stints of playing it. I'll play it for a month or so, put it down, then remember it's there after a while and start a fresh colony. The randomness, DLC and dedicated modding community allow so much variety of game play, it's just insane. 

Perpetually satisfying, reliably frustrating, infinitely rewarding. The game inspires creativity in base construction, people management, work scheduling, resource extraction & management, production automation, item fabrication, weapon/inventory loadout, raiding (offence and defence), travelling & exploration, tech research, trading, disaster prep, religious doctrine, the list goes on and on. Create a prosperous utopia of free love, a zealous high tech cult that worships hard drugs, or even a nightmare of sadistic torture, slavery and depravity... 

You can modify the gameplay to suit your desires. You can even cheat as much as you like to test out the mechanics. Just remember that the fun really starts when you're fighting to survive, winning some, losing almost everything, then rising from the ashes and doing it again! It's not called a Story Generator for nothing!

Oh, and the game music by Alistair Lindsay will become a permanent part of your inner monologue (I also recommend downloading the P-Music mod from the Workshop - not to mention the insane amount of extra content and quality of life mods!).

I cannot recommend this game highly enough. It's the luciferium of gaming! My thanks goes out to Tynan and Ludeon Studios for enriching my life when I've really needed a break from the true unfolding nightmare that is the real world. <3

This game is great... but... there is a problem..

Rimworld is an amazing colony simulator and story builder. There are a lot of solid mechanics, a ton of mods, and an overall satisfying gameplay loop. The glaring issue of this game is its Raiding system and its bad enough that I will often just not finish playthroughs simply because the raids come too often and become more of a nuisance than a fun mechanic, not to mention the main way to beat the game has 15 days of raiding from all factions including mechanoids before you win.

No matter what mods I bring, the raiding system remains to be a problem. Basically, you get raided based on the amount of wealth your colony has (wealth is determined by objects, buildings, number of colonists, and loot/items) and increased wealth can bring more raids and bigger raids over time. That mechanic is fine. What I don't like is that you can be raided by the same faction over and over and they never lose population or get weaker.. 

All colonies have the ability to send an infinite number of enemies as often as they feel like and it kind of ruins the game. It doesnt matter if you raid them and kill everybody, it doesnt matter if you wipe their colony off the map.. They will continue to come no matter what. It doesnt matter if you live on an island, in a sealed mountain, or miles away from any faction. They always come. And theres always more of them. And thats annoying to me. I don't want to have to play in "builder" difficulty and completely remove the challenges from the game just to enjoy it. Couple all this with the fact that none of these factions ever have anything worth taking from their own camps, they have no production or really any buildings.. and most times, they dont even have a large population.. yet they can send 40+ man raids to your faction weekly.. and its kind of bs.

Still, I'm not going to tell people not to buy this game, or that its bad in any way.. its just this one mechanic really gets under my skin and I just wish it wasn't like this just for the sake of difficulty.

I bought this game... maybe 4 days ago.

39 hours already.

This has never happened before.

Help.

EDIT: So, 918 hours later, some thoughts.

First, the memes are true. RimWorld really will just screw you over sometimes. There is no positive feedback loop, and there is no god to help you. This is part of the experience. Additionally, this game will make you a monster if you let it. Like, "running a colony of slavers that kidnap entire camps and harvest their organs before forcing the captives to either work or die" is a colony that you can make and it's not even in the top three least-ethical colonies I've made; my current colony is a group of matriarchal slavers that live on a massive battleship in orbit and occasionally descend to kidnap entire colonies, forcibly give them bionic implants (Advanced Components and Steel aren't difficult to find in orbit, because Save Our Ship 2 is a wonderful mod) and then sell them for a ludicrous profit, recruiting any skilled women captured along the way.

Second: This is an enduring stance of mine, but mods make every game better. I run close to ninety, from tiny QOL tweaks like zooming in further to colossal overhaul mods like Save Our Ship 2, Combat Evolved, RJW (IYKYK, keep your mouth *shut*. There are much better reasons to shame me than RJW) and about half the Vanilla Expanded catalog.

This game has foreclosed my house and taken my kids. It's launched a raid on my IRL computer. I love it so much. I can't avoid it. I can't prevent it from making me stay up entirely too late. I missed classes because of RimWorld and I. Regret. Nothing.

RimWorld is to Arts Majors what Factorio is to Engineering Majors: crack.

15/10.

Title: "RimWorld: A Hilarious Journey of Survival"

Review:
If you're looking for a game that seamlessly blends strategic thinking, resource management, and unexpected laughter, look no further than RimWorld. This gem of a game has truly redefined the survival genre, offering a unique mix of challenges and hilarity that keeps players hooked for hours on end.

One of the standout features of RimWorld is its dynamic storytelling. The game generates unpredictable scenarios and events, ranging from the absurd to the heartwarming. From colonists going on wild escapades to unexpected encounters with eccentric characters, every playthrough unfolds like a riveting novel. The sheer unpredictability ensures that no two experiences are ever the same, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting.

The game's quirky colonists add a whole new layer of enjoyment. Whether it's the eccentric scientist with a penchant for accidentally setting things on fire or the perpetually upbeat but slightly clueless farmer, each character comes with their own set of quirks and traits that contribute to the overall hilarity. It's like managing a group of unintentional comedians in a space survival setting.

The level of detail in RimWorld is truly commendable. The intricate base-building mechanics, coupled with the intricate needs and relationships of your colonists, create a complex web of interactions that is both challenging and immensely entertaining. The game doesn't shy away from presenting players with tough choices, but it does so with a humorous touch that keeps the experience light-hearted.

RimWorld's modding community also deserves a special mention. The wealth of user-created content adds even more layers of fun and creativity to the game. Whether you're adding new challenges, introducing bizarre events, or simply enhancing the visuals, the mods ensure that the game has endless replayability.

In summary, RimWorld is a masterclass in blending strategy and humor. It's a game that doesn't take itself too seriously, and that's precisely what makes it so enjoyable. So, buckle up for a rollercoaster ride of survival, laughter, and unexpected moments ‚Äì RimWorld has it all. LMAO, and happy colonizing, bozo!

Wow.. just, wow.. This is an amazing game.

With how addictive I'm finding RimWorld to be, I would be surprised if I ever rack up hours in another game as quickly as I have with this one. A clear indicator that I'm thoroughly interested and am enjoying a game is if it creeps its way into my head when I'm not actively playing it. Sitting at my office desk planning my next play session, or driving somewhere and planning my next character's build, things like that. With the variety of play style that RimWorld offers, I currently find myself in the middle of a two week old run with another planned for right after, and another after that, and another, and so on and so forth.. 

My first couple of runs were short and sweet. I would shoot my fist into the air in elation as my doctor performed a clutch life saving surgery, I'd snicker to myself as I tricked the enemy AI to walk right though my cleverly placed wooden traps, and I would also sit quietly, stunned, as my colony was absolutely obliterated by enemies I thought couldn't possibly be killed and must have been some sort of glitch. Once my runs were lasting longer than one play session, I purchased the Royalty DLC. This added magical powers, which are a delight, and another faction to the game. A faction who quickly humbled me one particular run that lasted a mere few hours. I purchased the Ideology DLC with roughly 200 hours of playtime. This DLC improved my ability to "theme" my runs drastically, greatly improving the game's replay value; I've played as a cannibalistic tribe, an underground mole people, a colony of melee-only brawlers who were unhappy unless their eyes were removed.. the possibilities feel endless.

I remember, before purchasing the game, reading reviews of people with 1000+ hours of play time saying things like "just finished the tutorial" and thinking it was just an ironic inside joke, but now I know the truth.. I've seen it with mine own (bionic) eyes. After 420 hours I still haven't built half of the available buildings, haven't used a majority of the ideologions, and have only completed two of the four possible endings. Meanwhile, I still haven't used the Biotech DLC, which is often praised for having added the most content of the three. Then, on top of all of this, there is the [i]insane[/i] modding community, which just adds an astronomical amount of content and replay value.

I find myself having the most fun by treating this game like a roguelike and playing on commitment mode. There was a run I did fairly early on where I did play on reload anytime, and while I do feel like the lessons I was able to learn by reloading encounters were invaluable, I found that save scumming takes away my enjoyment of the game in the long term; my enjoyment (addiction) stemming from the game's unpredictability and persistent demand of problem solving. 

All in all, I'm truly excited to keep playing this game and working my way through its tutorial, and I don't see that feeling fading any time soon.
simply the best game ever!

Don't be confused by the name, this game is not about rim-... Ahem, sorry, what I meant to say is that this game is a spiritual successor to Dwarf Fortress, a game where you watch little brain-dead dwarves build, mine, and craft an ever growing empire. You try your best to keep everyone alive, but sometimes things happen. Disasters; raids; forgetting to clean the floor, causing your cat to walk through spilled beer and dying of alcohol poisoning by licking its paws. (RIP Sniffles, you were my baby).

Rimworld is the same in spirit: you watch your brain-dead pawns build, mine, craft, hunt, research, and farm with the ultimate goal of leaving the rimworld (roll credits) you are on. You need to monitor them almost constantly in the beginning, watching out for things like their mood, their health, and their work schedule. Forget to build a table so your pawns can eat like civilized folk? Well, the next thing you know, one of your pawns goes into a blinding rage, while the other dies of hypothermia from being stuck in the freezer during a food binge.

Babysitting pawns is not the only challenge you will face. The game has several "story-tellers". Basically settings for how random events generate. In the vanilla game, there are only [strike]3[/strike] 1 to choose from, Randy Random. He is the perfect embodiment of an uncaring god, giving and taking from you as he pleases. Just barely survived a manhunter pack with 80 yorkshire terriers? I'm sure you can deal with a strike force of 30 bandits armed to the teeth that is about to construct a mortar to shell you into submission. But I see you are struggling to tend to your wounded, so I will airdrop some drop pods filled with medicine, that should sort you out, right? The random events combined with managing your colonists makes for great emergent storytelling.

Once you are bored with the base game, you can delve into mods. There are thousands of mods, adding things from extra hairstyles, to complete overhauls of the theme. Tired of sci-fi? Try the Medieval Overhaul. Tired of boring old humans? Try the myriad of mods that add alien races. Want to be able to [strike] get intimate [/strike] hold hands with your elven waifu? Try [strike]Lover's[/strike]... Never mind.

Anyway, enough rambling. This game is definitely worth checking out if you're into colony management, emergent storytelling, and pain and suffering. I rate it 10/10

Ok, so, I know rimworld is super popular and yes its fun and the mods are amazing. However, I have never actually managed to have a decent game. How is this, you might ask? Why can I not manage to actually play this game if it is so good?

The answer, dear gamers, is the steam workshop.

Normally, when I play a heavily modded game, I download the mods and install them with either a mod manager or manually. I get the files, then I use the files. However, steam workshop does not function like that. Steam workshop controls the horizontal. Steam workshop controls the vertical. Steam workshop can remove mods from my game whenever it wants. And it does, without my consent, constantly. Creative differences between modders? Congrats all your saved games are now bricked. Mod pushes a bad update? Hahahaha start a new game loser. I haven't had a game on rimworld go longer than a week before mysteriously it no longer functions and I have to try yet again.

Yet without mods this game is trash compared to competitors like dwarf fortress. Curious.

This game is the only Colony Sim you will ever need. Tynan and the team keep working on it and adding DLC that are always huge additions that allow you to do so much more with your colony. They also come out pretty slowly which is great because

1) It doesn't cost a ridiculous amount to keep up with the latest content
2) When DLC does come out it's always well polished and full of interesting features
3) If you take a long break from playing there isn't a lot you'll need to catch up on
4) The modding scene has plenty of time to build up a massive amount of mods (currently over 17,000 mods on version 1.4)

I personally have over 1,000 mods subscribed and always play with at least 500 of them in a single colony, yes it is that stable. I don't see myself ever getting into any other Colony Sim as much as RimWorld.

My first game was so much fun. Engaging, challenging, fun to discover all the mechanics, and it was so fun getting them off planet. But ever since then I have not found nearly the same enjoyment. The encounters mostly just become annoying, and I've never really enjoyed the challenge type runs like ice sheet or desert. It was fun while it lasted, and maybe one day i'll pay for the expansions and they'll renew my enjoyment of the game.

Edit: I have found myself returning to the game periodically and it still can be a lot of fun. Not a credit to the original devs but the modding community has added a ton of fun challenge and an enhanced combat system that really improves the game.

It's a space-opera set in against a far-future back-drop with genetically altered humanoids, robots and hostile insectoids coming up through the floors.

It's a cranky people simulator with exploding deer and insufficient tables.

It's a tactical top-down strategy game with sight lines and cover, and how much love a spouse receives from their partner impacting their mood and thus performance in battle (or anything else), as well as the quality of their food. 

With the modding community at your fingertips, it's any game you've ever wanted.

My first play thru of this game was using the Androids Mod. I had never played this game before then. I name all of my robots based on dieties in relation to thier generation number. Gen 1 was Norse Gods,  Gen 2 was Egyptian Gods, Gen 3 was Greek Gods, Gen 4 was Judeo-Christian deities. I made 2 Gen 4 robots.. One name Yaweh and another named Lucifer. I started allowing Gen 4 robots to build lesser generations to help with things. Lucifer creates his first Gen 3 Android. This new android he created has the "Homosexual" trait.. I think this is odd AF because how do make a robot have this trait? I shrug it off thinking it was a fluke of the game. Gay robots are fine. I have Lucifer create another android. He makes the very next one with the "Homosexual" trait. Lucifer was immediately taken off of creating new robots.  After being taken off of this duty , he opens an ancient threat on accident and the group inside wipes the entity of the base. Such a great and subtle display of evil from a robot not intended to be that way. I have been hooked on this game ever since.  10 out of 10 for the games storytelling.

At this current time I haven't spit 100+ hours in the game (probably because I am a casual player). However, I think 50 hours is enough time to give a review on this game. For some people, this game might be a hit or miss when it comes to style, game play, and difficulty (which could go under game play, but I will leave that up to you). The thing that got me into the game was Youtube and the amount of chaos that you could cause with just a group of three people, and when you get those great stories and laughs that you can tell your friends, that just makes it pure gold. The replay ability as well is a HUGE factor when it comes to this game especially with mods (which is what I want to get into later).

I think that most of the Rimworld fan base can agree on that replay ability is a big part of what makes Rimworld, well Rimworld. I'll give an example: my first game of rimworld went as most of are's did, build a small shack and get killed by something. I had landed in a Jungle with my 3 survivors and opened an ancient danger (Like a dumbass knowing full well what it was) and you guessed it died to a horde of mechanoids. Then in another on of my early games,  there was a raid that had happened while most of my colony was out and one of my colonists (who had a shooting skill of 10 mind you) was using a bow and got knocked to the raider who had a wooden club and got kidnapped. once my caravan had arrived back at base, it was a waste land, mostly everything was burned but nothing was stolen. Later down the line I ended up getting a chance to rescue that person. Overall replay ability is very strong in this game and works out in the games favor unlike Minecraft or Ark.

Next, modding is another part of Rimworld that makes it so great. There are mods that can add more factions, big cannons, more story tellers, ect. This can add onto that replay ability that I talked about earlier. The more you add to the game can make it fun and an enjoyable experience. Also collections are a good place to look if you are looking for something specific. 

Overall, this game is a great experience so far and deserves its player base and fans. If you are on the edge of the diving board to buying this game, then I think you should take the plunge and try it for yourself. I still have a long way to go to be an expert, but this game is more about the stories that you create and the laughs you have, instead of tryharding the game, completing it, and never touching it again.

My entire colony was saved by a tortoise.

This won't be a review like the ones I normally do, going over the pros and cons. Rimworld's a story generator, so I thought I'd share my story. I bought rimworld around two weeks prior to writing this, and set up a small colony. The first animal my colonists tamed was a 212 year old tortoise, who I named "Old Timer." We set up a small farm, and once we found a female tortoise (who I named "Henrietta Peach"), they had kids. And their kids had kids. Soon enough, I had too many tortoises than I knew what to do with, so i tried selling them, and the nearby colonists loved them. But things took a darker turn.

Around 5 days after buying rimworld, my IRL dog, of 15 years, passed. It was sad, but what hit extra hard was old timer's death only a few hours later. Both were blind, both had bad backs - it hurt, and I cried. I dug a big tomb in a mountain for old timer, and laid him to rest in it. But this is not where his story ends.

A few ingame hours later, I got a quest with a ressurection serum as a reward. In that moment, I knew what I had to do, as the end goal of my playthrough.

I couldn't save my dog from old age, but I sure as could save this turtle. Old timer was going to space.

After quickly gunning down some tribals and getting the serum, I needed a way to keep old timer from dying all over again while I aquired the supplies for the ship. Luckily, an ancient ruin was on my map, and after an intense fight with some killer robots, I safely placed him in a stasis chamber the robots were guarding.

Not much happened relating to him. Henrietta died of old age herself, and over the four or so years it took me to complete the ship, old timer's children numbered over 500. i made regular trips to the nearby towns to trade tortoises for the ship's supplies, like plasteel and uranium, and at long last, I placed old timer in the now-finished ship and turned the reactor on.

When you power on the escape reactor, rimworld basically becomes a sort of wave defense game, with a new posse of enemies coming every day for 15 days or so while the reactor charged. This wasn't a big deal - I had troops in power armor with miniguns, and we made it to the end of the 15 days without any deaths. Right as the reactor was at full power, and I told my colonists to enter the ship, things took a dramatic turn. A solar flare knocked out all my defences, leaving me without any kind of fire support. I hurredly got my colonists in the ship, but right as the last one was making his way across the fields to get to it...

Pirates airdropped into my base. I was screwed.

I was about to launch without him, when salvation came in a way I hadn't expected: A tortoise (number 493, to be precise) didn't take too kindly to someone coming out of the sky and attempting to shoot his keepers, and bit a pirate enforcer on the leg. This caused the pirate to hit him with his club, and after that the OTHER pirates started shooting the hundred or so turtles in the base, who promptly attacked back. And, in the ensuing chaos, my last colonist boarded the ship and we escaped.

Old timer, a blind, crippled, undead tortoise repaid me for saving his life - by birthing countless decendants to not only fund my escape, but who also protected me in my darkest hour of need. This game is a gift, and I cannot reccommend it enough. Even if you reload saves to keep the story going how you want, it's still a story worth telling.

RimWorld: Where Organ Trade Is Just Another Tuesday (And Tuesday Might Just Eat You)
5 out of 5 (stars, kidneys, and possibly your left arm...depends on the raid schedule)

RimWorld, folks, ain't your grandma's farm sim. Sure, you got your crops, your livestock (which may or may not be your former livestock), and your dreams of building a space utopia. But picture this utopia as a rickety shack constantly on fire, guarded by a pyromaniac squirrel with a shotgun and a crippling addiction to luciferium. That's RimWorld.

Think Castaway meets The Hunger Games, sprinkled with a dash of Mad Max and a whole lot of questionable decisions. You'll start with a ragtag bunch of crash survivors, each with their own baggage (literally, sometimes it's organs) and mental breakdowns waiting to happen. Your job? Keep them alive. This involves everything from fending off mechanoid centipedes with spoons to crafting hats from the skin of unfortunate raiders (hey, free tailoring practice!).

The learning curve is steeper than a mountain carved by angry space iguanas, but that's half the fun. Every mistake is a hilarious (or horrifying) story waiting to be told. My favorite colony went from peaceful rice farmers to cyborg ninja warriors after a particularly nasty raid left them with more bionics than limbs. We called them the "Bionic Butchers," and their motto was "Chop 'em up, sell 'em off, buy more luci for Sparky!" (Sparky, by the way, was the aforementioned pyromaniac squirrel. He had good taste.)

The AI storyteller is a sadistic genius. Just when you think things are going well, BAM! Solar flare knocks out your power, your best cook has a mental break and sets the kibble stockpile on fire, and a pack of manhunting boars decide your colonists are the perfect afternoon snack. But that's the beauty of it. Every disaster is a chance to rebuild, to adapt, to tell your friends about the time your one-armed farmer single-handedly beat a bear to death with throwing rocks.

If you're looking for a relaxing game where everything goes according to plan, steer clear of RimWorld. But if you want a wild ride full of laughter, tears, and questionable moral choices, this is your jam. Just remember, in RimWorld, the only constant is change. And maybe hats. Lots of hats.

P.S. Don't trust the ducks. They're up to something.

P.P.S. Seriously, buy this game. Just don't blame me when your real-life relationships suffer because you're too busy trying to save Biff from another squirrel rampage.

It's all about embracing the chaos and having fun with the story the game creates for you. And hey, if your colony falls apart...well, just start a new one! There's a whole galaxy of organ-harvesting, hat-crafting, squirrel-dodging adventures waiting for you.

(Disclaimer: I take no responsibility for any real-life squirrel attacks or luciferium addictions that may occur as a result of playing RimWorld.)

I have grown up with this game and it has grown up with me. I remember committing my first war crime all the way to finally beating the game on its hardest difficulty. I have watched the community grow where human hats and boars were all of the talk and watched the development team go through their own struggles as a virus and war hurt us all. Through my own personal life of highs and lows I remember being able to play the game and feel better enough to go back and finish my other problems. The countless hours of replayabilty and limitless stories told on the Rim has brought me back for more and more. I have even found that this was the perfect game to play while I do homework and studing too as sometimes it didn't require a lot of attention. So through the 5 years I have been playing this game I can say with my whole heart that it is a game I will never forget and one that I hope to play on and on.

There's plenty already written about the gameplay, so will just add two other points to the mix:

1)  The sound is kind of rhythmical and nice. Letting the game run in the background while you do some work feels sort of comfy- almost as if the survivors are working even as you are. 

2)  The visuals are unsightly and jarringly ugly though, and ultimately led me to stop playing. Did attempt scouring for visual overhaul mods again and again, but as of 20240125, there is still nothing to remedy the eyesore yet. 

Am writing this review for people like me who might want to enjoy the game but are just turned off by the look of it, so that regret doesn't eventually seep into what otherwise would be a pleasant experience.

TLDR: Recommended, if you look at it without part of you going ugh.

You really have to give the tribe start a try, with biotech DLC... The slow research speed means spending more time with your starting characters, and their child, and recruited characters. Though you may lose some characters, Sending your beloved characters that you raised from literally nothing to space, and ensuring their bright future is really touching. Much more than crashlanded start. 
 As for me.. I started a tribe start, spent 450 in-game days(didn't lose any colonist because I loaded my former save when someone died), and launched a total of 26 people to space...
Rimworld's  ending's not a blockbuster. I mean, it's quite simplified, like all the other UIs and graphics of this game. But what really touched me was the fact that, I wrote the ending credit myself. The 26 colonists that I stayed together for 453 in-game days, and roughly 100? Real-time hours(150?200...?? I don't remember). The ending credit had that. The name of 26 colonists.
 I'm really having much fun at rimworld. It's great 'story generator'. I'm sure I'm gonna play more of this game. And if further DLCs release, I'm Definitely interested. Also mods.

Fair warning. You NEED the DLC. A LOT of content is locked behind it, so don't see this as a $40 game. It's $100.

Good game, but frankly overpriced. The game is fairly limited without the DLC, or a LOT of modding (most of which requires you to own the DLC to begin with.)  Multiplayer is a mod, Many basic things needs mods to function well. It's sort of... the Skyrim of base management sims. A good game that gets "great" with enough mods added in.

For $100 though, you'd expect to not have to install mods for even basic things like Co-Op play to exist. (And that fact that modders could do it but not the devs only adds to my sense of a lack of value per dollar here.)

8.5/10 at a $40 - $50 price point. 6.5/10 at the $100 price point.

If money is no object, buy it, it's a pretty fun game. If you have an entertainment budget like a lot of folks, maybe look elsewhere. I got 200 hours out of it, but that was really only due to the modding community. Hell if we are now reviewing games based on mod content, then Skyrim would be the greatest game of all time... and it's not. 

2 hours to the dollar is pretty typical for most of the games I own, if not a bit on the low side, which frankly is why I couldn't rate this higher. For the money.. it's fairly average.

One last note here, is MUCH of the gameplay revolves around, sitting, waiting, and watching AI do things. This tends to artificially inflate game time even running it on x3 speed. A 6 hour session might only involve 1-2 hours of actual "gameplay." Which personally I don't mind, BUT if you have limited play time, it might feel a bit slow paced. Most of the gameplay revolves around assigning schedules, work zones, meal planning, trading, making blueprints, and occasionally some combat where you'll take "mostly" direct control.. through liberal usage of pausing.

RimWorld is an incredible game. It has a variety of game mechanics, expansions, and mods that allow for a different play through every time. You can make almost any situation in this game a favorable one with a bit of thought! There's even a mod for multiplayer if you're not a fan of single player games.

UI according to travelling and fighting outside your settlement isn't worth it and very tedious. Micromanagement overwhelms the game as AI is not very well programmed.

I don't recommend this game at all because it requires WAY to much micromanagement. 

Tattered clothing? Force your pawn to drop the item. Then you have to MANUALLY allow them to interact with it again and figure out how to dispose of said item.  (Or install a mod so they can repair it.)

Sent a pawn out hunting?  Well they regularly walk away before the animal is dead and it ends up bleeding out somewhere on the map.. and your pawns won't go get the corpse because it is NOT allowed since they didn't actively kill it.  So you either have to actively scan around the map for that dead animal and get it before the corpse rots and is useless  OR keep doing a Priority Hunt on the animal until the pawn fully kills and therefor will pick it up and haul it back to your base. .. and ONE "Prioritize Hunting" won't do it all the time either!  You'll have to sometimes do it THREE times until the animal is fully dead.

Which of course then annoys the pawn.

On top of that, expect to constantly be having to change the Work Priorities in the Work tab or nothing will get done. Or some injured pawn that had a 1 for something besides bedrest when wounded pawns end up becoming incapacitated and you have to rescue them.  (Manually of course!)  And there are other instances of this.   Like, ending up with rotting crops because the pawns decided cleaning was more important. 

There are mods that give you more priorities 1-10 instead of 1-3 but you shouldn't need this sort of mod to actually make the game functional.

It's like Dwarf Fortress but there is only one Z level and the game has a much better user interface and quality of life features. The basic premise is to crashland with three randos and try to survive until you can build yourself a ship to escape. You probably won't want to even beat the game because it's so interesting to build your settlement, collect and farm hundreds of animals, recruit people, fight battles and deal with the challenges that come your way.

I actually did not like it at first. I gave it another chance and ended up playing it for thousands of hours over the years. My wife also likes to play on the easiest setting and make a peaceful colony. There are so many mods you will basically be playing a completely different type of game with enough mods, like a medieval overhaul or a spaceship outerspace adventure or warhammer 40k. However, there are so many mods and they can interfere with each other so you might sometimes spend hours trying find good mods and trying to get a hundred mods to work together. My last settlement was made with mods and I had a bunch of space goblins living in a cave in a valley, growing more of themselves in vats until they spilled out and started raiding nearby settlements.

This game is good if you like building a sci fi settlement and trying to survive. Give it a try! The DLC is all excellent, too.

I was tempted to make this review negative, but doing so to a game as great as this would be a crime. Why negative tho? I can't stress this enough: this game will hijack your life. Play for an hour? Good luck, you'll realize you should've gone to bed once your alarm goes off in the morning. I imagine looking at this game if I were family guy; a chill solution to gaming cravings after tucking in the kids. If that is you, do not make that mistake. You'll get Jumanjied without countdown and your kids will grow up with one less parent. Since my warning will go unheeded, here's some things to pass your time in the game:
 
+ Live under a mountain, brew beer and fight anyone trying to stop you. Get stressed by the intruders' corpses, which further motivates the brewing process 'cos hey drinking helps. Experience the circle of life. Contemplate existence.
 
+ Lose an eye. Lose your jaw. Lose an arm and a leg. Still be the deadest shot on the planet five years later, your injuries only making you stronger. Experience pure happiness: the feeling that power is growing, that resistance is overcome. Contemplate existence.
 
+ Wake up on a hostile planet after narrowly escaping a burning spaceship. Get waylaid by man-hunting monkeys because malaria prevented you from preparing defenses. Launch yourself back to space. Contemplate existence.
 
All of this and more -- and this before I have even tried any of the DLC, which I definitely will. After playing for a while and reading through what the DLC add to the game the investment is a no-brainer. This game is a masterpiece. An oasis in the desert I did not even know I'm in. The pemmican savior of a long winter.
My life

This is one of the greatest games I have ever played, endless replayability, endless of fun, and if you get bored? A [i]toooon[/i] of workshop mods to add to or change the game.

When I played prison architect it created some sort of itch for me. I had no idea what it was but I wanted, [i]something[/i].
Well then I discovered Rimworld and it had that it factor, it scratched that itch, the way the game looks, feels, plays, how it immerses you.

It reminds one of the "one more turn" phenomenom when playing Sid Meier's Civilization.
"I will just do this thing, then I will save and quit", que 4 hours have passed and you've forgotten to do the laundry, start cooking. 

The game simply captures you in a way I can not describe with words.

Also the developer is dedicated and incorporates mods which the community has deemed as "essential" - aka, they are listening to the feedback which is given, a great thing to see!

I cannot recommend Rimworld enough!

[h2]A frame for shoving mods into, that may also be the greatest of games[/h2]
[b]It's absolutely amazing ant farm, deepest RPG out there, interctive story written by lunatics and you, some random bullshit full of furries and anime, or whatever else your imagination and modder's effort can bring to life.

That being said, for a new player it's advised to play the game unmodded until you explore the game and start getting picky about some specific elements; then go and get a mod that fixes your complain, yes there is such a mod, there always is.[/b]

Now how this works.
The game introduces you to it's world, implying depth; to your bunch of misfiits, nudging you to get familiar with them and care for them. Shows you a McGuffin or a few (with dlc's and mods) to chase. Grabs your interest. 
And from here just straight up attempts to murder you in most horrible of ways at all times. The rest is up to you, including whether to chase the McGuffin or go your own way. 
You've got tools, you do your best to keep your wonder team alive; then imagination kicks in, and that's what the "Story generator" from the title screen really is about. You make your own story, and Rimworld makes sure you always have something to work with.

 And it works wonderfully.

What, it doesn't for you? Well, there's a mod for that. And for this. Yes Timmy, for that too.

My hours say quite a bit already. Rimworld calls itself a story generator and a colony survival sim. Both of which are correct. This game has three base game narrators that dictate how the events are thrown at you and how hard. Want a classic ever increasing difficulty with time? Cassandra Classic is for you. Want to get hit hard, but plenty of breathing room for recovering and relaxing? Phoebe Chillax. Want a truly random experience where the first encounter you face could wipe you out? Good old Randy Random is your chaotic best bud.

There's various difficulties and starting scenarios to choose from, both can be customized to fit your ideal game. And if there's not enough scenarios or you don't want to make your own, you can find some on the Steam Workshop along with a sizable modding community that's even managed to give this game multiplayer. Though it's still a blast to play alone and vanilla if that's what you prefer. Especially with the DLCs that spice things up and give you alternative ways to "beat the game" so to speak.

If you like colony survival games and you like the idea of getting raided by a massive group only for a pack of manhunting chickens to save the day, then having a rat self-tame and join your colony, go ahead and buy the game. If that's not enough to convince you, find some players who've shared their unique experiences with this game and decide after that.
