The short version is that RimWorld is best described as "It's about the journey, not the destination" 

RimWorld is a "story generator" where you'll try and help direct the colonists to survival, events will more than likely disrupt your plans, and what you get from it is a very complex and deep set of systems that when events are strung together turn into an epic Sci-Fi story.

While I absolutely recommend the game, I admit that RimWorld is a strange game because RimWorld isn't a game you play to "win" instead it's a game that you play for the experience. 

The game may seem "hard" especially if you tend to be overly sensitive to loss, this is a game that has both tragedy and triumph in equal parts. 

The cool thing is RimWorld's systems will help prevent you from ever being completely wiped out and having no way to continue, but also won't give you such an easy time that there's no challenge anymore, by increasing or decreasing the difficulty and types of events you get, you'll always have something to do.

---- One RimWorld Story (Skip if not interested) ----

An example I had recently was I spent weeks planning and building, but there was turmoil in the camp. A couple of my colonists Jen and Quazar decided to get married, which upset one of the other colonists Helix as he had been perusing them. This made them very unhappy despite being in a fairly happy overall having a good quality of life. 

Winter struck and it became cold, a cold snap started killing off a lot of the outdoor crops, and food became limited, as the colonists rushed to take the remaining wheat and meat and creating pemmican to make sure none of it spoiled over the winter months. Pemmican is obviously not great to eat and such overall made everyone upset but none more so than Helix who at this point had been cooped up inside, freezing, hungry and still dealing with their feelings of being rebuffed by Jen.

Fed up Helix had a verbal disagreement with Quazar that led to a fist fight, and after beating up Quazar went to get medical attention for his bruises, from the doctor Nova. However as soon as they were patched up, Helix went had a mental break and began lighting EVERYTHING on fire. The whole base burned and the still injured Quazar, Jen and Nova weren't able to stop the spread fast enough to not have the fire destroy most of the supplies. Luckily after half the base burned down a morning spring shower rolled through and put out the rest saving at least some of the base. 

Both Helix and Quazar eventually died from their burns and other injuries getting infected and Jen and Nova had to slaughter all the animals for food. They shared a single bedroom for a few months, and struggled through spring to replant crops and traded all the weapons and materials they had left that survived to trade with wandering traders to help recover.

Eventually Jen and Nova were joined by a wanderer named Vega, they rebuilt the base, and Vega's higher intelligence let them quickly research tools for making greenhouses to help prevent a future cold-snap killing all the food. 

Jen eventually remarried, marrying Vega about a year later. Eventually they managed to build a ship and escape to build a better life, leaving Nova behind who's story continued.

--- End ---

The cause of the chaos and the later arrival of wandering traders and Vega in the story wasn't really random, it was RimWorld's safeties. With everything going smooth and a vast wealth of items and happy colonists, it started seeding some chaos in order to cause me to have to deal with some challenges, then after the chaos it saw a sudden drop in overall colony value and responding by giving some random events that helped like adding a new colonist that had valuable skills and sending wandering traders to be able to rebuild my base with essential supplies.

None of the above is explicitly told either, a lot of it was just me connecting the events into a coherent story. I noticed Helix was sad, checked the mood tab, saw he was sad because he had hit on Jen. Later Jen gets married, and then much later Helix throws a tantrum burning down the colony. I personally connected the dots but the tools were there for me to make that story on my own. 

The game also allows you to make starting scenarios that lets you change the supplies the characters start with, allowing you to roleplay a bunch of scenarios. Try making them stupid easy and have everyone start off rich and watch as their high standards of living cause drama as their wealth runs out, or make the game super hard and start off with no supplies at all and build up from there. The game is what you put into it. 

A comparison might be that the game is like Minecraft. Minecraft while the overall goal is to beat the Ender Dragon and "win" like you can win by creating a space ship and escaping in the crash-landed scenario, you can spend near infinite time building and upgrading and such before going and doing that. 

More than likely you won't "win" a scenario for a long time. In the 250+ hours I've played of this game I have created so many different colonies with different characters and scenarios, and I have only once actually eventually "won" the primary quest of building a space ship and leaving the planet. But winning isn't really the point as mentioned it's a "story generator" and if you can get past that, this game has a lot to offer. 

Overall, if you're interested in a sandbox survival game with deep mechanics, this is one of the best options out there.

Just as the founding fathers intended.

What I just described was but two highlights of one of my many play-throughs of this wonderful game with only the DLCs. I have had play-throughs where I sold enough drugs to make a cartel jealous, made hippie elf communes and even made peaceful frontier towns willing to help all those who needed shelter or aid. The ideology stuff is an enhancement of the story-generation, for the tale that the game tells. I am asking too much of the mods and of the ideology mechanics to get what I really want. I will surely continue to play this game, but I really must come back to it when I want a story of survival on a harsh planet, not when I want to RP a very specific societal structure on said harsh planet.

After playing Rimworld for ~180 hours, I've come to this conclusion; Rimworld is not a game, nor is it one for the feint of heart.

Sure, the game already bills itself as a 'storytelling simulator', but if you're looking at this like something like The Sims, it's INCREDIBLY different. Your colonists have free will, for better or for worse, and your first few colonies WILL fail. Rimworld pulls no punches, and will force you to learn the minutia, and if you're able to stick with it and learn what to do, you will be rewarded by harder and harder raids and events, forcing you to adapt to this unforgiving planet upon which you find yourself.

No two playthroughs are the same; Maybe the first one you have a colonist who's amazing at building but is also a psychopath who undergoes a mental break and kills the colony's pet, maybe hordes of bugs erupt from a nearby mountain face and you need to fight for your life, or maybe ~15 Llamas self-tame themselves and join your colony. These can and will happen, and it will be up to you to adapt and overcome when they do.

Once you've completed everything the base game offers, though, not only can you go through another playthrough that it in itself will be unique, but you have the choice of three DLCs that MASSIVELY change the gameplay; Royalty adds a social hierarchy, allowing you to create a kingdom of your own and promote your colonists through the ranks allowing you to call favors of other nearby neighboring colonies, Ideology institutes religion, allowing you to further edit how your colony interacts within it's own boundaries as well as with other people (You want a race of cannibalistic mole people who live in the mountains and worship a shotgun as their holy relic? Now you can do that!), and Biotech adds in new races with different resistances and buffs, gene splicing, and most interestingly, children who slowly grow and learn, eventually becoming full colonists themselves.

TL;DR, Rimworld isn't a game, it's a continued experience. If you're curious about the game, or just want to get started, I would advise just getting the base game and upgrading from there once you get the hang of it.

Rimworld is an interesting and exciting new journey that once unwrapped will have you hooked. You will find the world is brutally harsh in punishing mistakes, while continuously trying to beautify your region and develop your pawns' stories. So, the first half of whatever game you play will be a lot of fun. However, about halfway through your play, your success is immediately rewarded with raids upon raids of endless enemies whose only goal is to destroy everything you've created. No matter what difficulty you're on, you'll be forced to "game" the system by utilizing killboxes, choke points, and whatever other ways you can to minimize the fact you're pit against an unforgiving foe that has nearly unlimited resources. The DLC's make up some of this, by giving you some extra ways of gaining advantage, and they also provide with some new, interesting content. However, the clunky combat which is designed to become your main adversary (weird in a "story-based" game) combined with the single-thread computation (yeah, don't worry, you'll clock out that single. core after a couple of in-game seasons), makes the game's life somewhat short. I would recommend playing this game, but just know this is not a game of depth, but a shallow defensive resource survival game wrapped in a story-book shell.

Rimworld is a social experiment in which the player is given a choice between morally questionably decisions, and survival. Maybe you didn't have to cut off the limbs of those prisoners and send them out into the world with no chance of survival.

Really, that's for god to decide! Your only goal is to survive by any means- and in this game? The more reprehensible you are, the better your odds.

I've been diving headfirst into the wild world of "RimWorld" and, let me tell you, it's like falling into a strategy black hole - in the best way possible. I've spent more hours than I care to admit building, managing, and sometimes inadvertently setting fire to my little space colonies. 

Customization is King
First off, the customization in this game is insane. Want a colony of peace-loving artists? Go for it. Prefer a band of cannibalistic pirates? Weird, but also, go for it! The game's like, "You do you, chief." I've had playthroughs that felt like a serene space version of "The Sims," and others that were more "Mad Max" meets "Lost in Space." The AI storytellers keep things spicy - sometimes they're your best pal, other times, they're that friend who thinks it's funny to throw a bear into your birthday party.

But, About Those Stories...
Speaking of stories, they're a mixed bag. At first, it's all "wow, cool, a pirate raid during a solar eclipse!" But after a while, you might find yourself going, "Another toxic fallout, Randy? Really?" It's like the game sometimes tries too hard to impress you, and you just want to tell it to chill.

Cheese Factor
Now, let's talk cheese - and I'm not talking about the dairy product. There are ways to game the system here that can make things a bit too easy. Ever had a colonist survive solely on a diet of lavish meals and zero work? Yeah, it's possible and as hilarious as it sounds, it kinda breaks the vibe. It's like finding a cheat code that you can't unsee.

Final Verdict
All in all, "RimWorld" is a blast. It's a sandbox of epic proportions with more stories than my grandpa. Sure, it's got its quirks and can be cheesier than a pizza convention, but that's part of its charm. If you're into games that let you experiment and create your own wild tales of space survival (and don't mind occasionally yelling at your screen because of random events), then definitely give it a go.

I originally got into Rimworld during the pandemic from watching Francis John struggle his way through his first playthrough on YT. A week or two ago, at ~1800hrs in, I finally got the Royalty DLC. The base game alone is fantastic.

This game defines emergent gameplay and natural storytelling. It's demanding, harsh, and exciting. Plan for changing seasons. Plan for raiders. Plan for random events. Plan for your colonists to go nuts and destroy stuff or try to kill one another. Give it a proper go.

There is a great modding community. If you're getting into this I strongly advise looking at the various quality-of-life mods that are out there, so long as they don't interfere with difficulty.

Welcome to the Rim! Hail Randy, and don't ask what the hat's made of.

Top-down colony-building game with heavy focus on story generation and attachment to individual pawns rather than a faceless horde. Very customizable and adaptable to different skill levels. Just dive in - don't look up guides beyond the tutorial, because half the fun is trying designs out to see if they work. And remember that success isn't completing the end objective - it's experiencing a dramatic story. 

If it feels boring, turn the difficulty up to an uncomfortable level.

Okay, Its been a few years since my original review and a lot has changes, namely 3 DLCs have come out and the modding community has evolved even further to the point where one of the prominent groups are going off to make their own game.

To start with, Rimworld is a good game. Its main goal is to use its mechanics to create a memorable stories out of the colonies you spend hours playing on, and it does a very good job at that, I have countless stories of perseverance and heroism, as well as tragedy and despair. My personal favorite story is rather tragic, but extremely so to the point of being comedy:

I was doing a modded playthrough back before all the DLC when the only thing we had for adding more genetic variety in the colonists was Humanoid Alien Races, and I was doing a playthrough in the Jungle. I was still pretty new to the game so I didnt really know what I was doing or how to deal with certain things, such as a furred colonist named Sjord Bowman Lucas making her way to the colony. Bowman was not ready to deal with the heat of the jungle, and would rapidly develop heat stroke when outdoors, and I didnt know that I could make certain clothing items to increase heat tolerance, Bowman also had fantastic shooting stats, so they were our hunter and defender when food was low or we were raided, which was often cause I didnt know how to properly handle food. The result was that Bowman would pass out from heatstroke almost every other day, and because of how artwork goes, I kid you not, 3/4ths of all the artwork in the colony was about some time that Bowman collapsed from heatstroke. Everyone hated this woman, especially the medic who she tragically saw the most whenever they needed patching up after a raid or passed out from heatstroke. Bowman would eventually develop an infection in her leg that would need to be amputated to ensure her survival, the amputation was thankfully not botched by the medic, but what she did botch was the process for installing a prosthetic, where she fully destroyed the prosthetic. Making a new leg and successfully installing it with a different doctor this time I thought Bowman's suffering was over, but no, the Medic then got into a fight with Bowman where she destroyed the brand new prosthetic leg and Bowman's nose. The colony didnt last much longer because of a drop pod pirate raid that I was unprepared for, so I never got to continue Bowman's terrible, terrible life story. But that story is something I remember fondly for how utterly hopeless Bowman's situation was at all time, every time she got just a little bit of hope it was violently ripped away.

So yeah, I think it does a very good job at making memorable stories, I'm sure you've already seen that displayed though from the countless other reviews you must have read to get here.

RimWorld is one of the best colony sim games I have played. I wanted to write a review, but I dont have the patience to sit down and write that long. SO I did what any reasonable person would have done, I popped on over to ChatGPT and described what kind of game I was playing, and what kind of review I wanted.
  
RimWorld, propels players into the heart of a foreign planet teeming with challenges. Set against a backdrop of harsh conditions and untamed landscapes, RimWorld tasks you with the intricate responsibility of managing a diverse group of colonists as they strive for survival and prosperity. 

At its core, RimWorld excels in providing a deeply immersive and engaging, storytelling experience. Create your own story as you navigate the complexities of colony management. From the basic survival needs of your colonists to the intricate web of social interactions, RimWorld creates a dynamic and compelling simulation that keeps players on their toes

The harsh conditions of the foreign planet add an exhilarating layer of challenge. Whether you're combating alien wildlife, extreme weather,  or unexpected events, RimWorld ensures that every decision you make has profound consequences for the well-being of your colonists.

One of the game's standout features is its robust trade system with factions. Establishing relationships and engaging in trade brings a strategic depth to the gameplay, offering additional avenues for unique quests and resource acquisition that can tip the scales in your favor.

The $40 price tag for RimWorld is a worthy investment considering the depth and replayability it offers. The game's intricate mechanics and the ever-evolving narrative provide countless hours of entertainment. However, if you have the opportunity to snag it on sale, the added value makes RimWorld an even more enticing prospect.

In conclusion, RimWorld stands as a testament to the brilliance of colony simulation games. Its challenging scenarios, deep narrative, and strategic gameplay make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Whether you're navigating the trials of a new colony or establishing world dominion, RimWorld offers an immersive and rewarding experience well worth the investment.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Be warned... if you work from home and try to play this game at lunchtime, your day is over. You'll blink and 5 hours go by. Would not recommend if you have things to do in life... would recommend if you're looking for something to steal your youth.

Rimworld, in my opinion, is the best survival colony sim. The game has a vast amount of content, even in the base, and the DLC's only add to these intriguing worlds more. The game doesn't hold you by your hand, and it's definitely daunting to new players, but it is an addictive game I have fallen in love with. You don't play as one of the pawns that survive on the rim, you can't control every facet of what events can happen. You are almost like an onlooker, someone who experiences what happens in the story. The story generating aspect sets it apart, and puts it leagues ahead of other colony sims. From the ones that I've played, they almost seem to depend on the player to create the story, but in Rimworld, the game is the one making the story. You are just the one to see it, and interpret it. The game is magnificent, and is peak colony sim in my opinion, and is one of the most authentic and raw story generators that I've seen. The modding community is insane, adding so many things to the game if you have ever grown bored of the base or the three DLC's. This is a game you can sink hours, days, weeks, months, and even years into. Even if a colony of yours doesn't work out, you didn't lose the game. There is no 'losing Rimworld,' as one of the loading screen tips on console told me before I migrated to PC, that story just had a bad ending, and that's perfectly fine.
Absolute masterpiece.

This game drives me nuts. I *love* the idea of the game. But I spend more time managing mods, micromanaging and babysitting idiotic pawns, and looking things up online than enjoying it.

Case in point: I simply want visitors to stop wandering around inside my base. It should be a private, secure area. But they'll waltz into your dining room like they own the place. This should be part of the zones feature in the game, but that only applies to colonists and colony animals. You can try mods like Locks. But they can be buggy or have performance penalties or be fiddly.

This is one among MANY things that should be built into the base game, not left to the player to fumble with. This studio is too content to rely on unpaid, hobbyist modders to fix all the issues in the game.

Other issues include:

* Pawns dropping their weapons when they're downed, requiring a mod to fix the annoyance of having to find and equip their weapon again
* Pawns blocking doors with items leading to dangerous situations
* Pawns trapping themselves inside a building they've built
* No easy conduit deconstruction ("select similar" needs a mod)
* Pawns going on extended bad mood breaks with no recourse to the player (again, need mods like Snap Out of It, etc.)
* I could go on for a long time...

This should be the detailed simulation sandbox that it looks like from the outside. But once you start playing, you realize it's a janky mess, taped together with mod duct tape.

I have a strange addiction to landing at the poles of the planet. When things are going right, it's always barely. Even the slightest of upsets result in the entire colony dying. So inevitably, a short circuit starts a fire or one of my batteries explodes, completely destroying the crops I've been so tirelessly fighting to keep warm and give light to. Every playthrough, my colonists starve, freeze, lose sanity, and then proceed to wander aimlessly out into the fast fields of ice to finally be swept away by death.

You don't have to do the tutorial, but if you don't, good luck figuring it out yourself.

How the hell do I describe this thing?
It's The Sims mixed with the world from Firefly. It lets desperation and depravity have a seat at the table just as often as honor and success. A game I hated when I began playing it.  It felt absolutely cruel. I had no idea how much time and enjoyment I would get from it once it had a second chance to capture me. 

I really didn't understand this wasn't a classic game where you can win or lose. It's a neutral narrator guiding me through the story of my own successes and failures. Of how our own greed inevitably destroys all our favorite things. Maybe.

To keep things fresh, the mod community is on a whole other level.  This is likely my favorite game on steam this decade.

In a few ways I'm really thankful that the graphics for this are so low end. If even a small fraction of the shit that can happen in this game were rendered in any more detail than it is, it wouldn't be legal to buy practically anywhere on the planet.  Would probably also make folks a bit queasy.

Highly recommended.

I'm old now, got a few kids-- don't have as much time to game as I used to. I started a colony in Rimworld using the default settings and thought I was doing alright. I named everyone after myself, my wife, and my kids. We made it to winter with a hefty stockpile of food and wood to keep us warm. I hadn't figured out clothes production yet so we really needed the fire to keep going. I calculated that as long as we went and cut a few trees a day, we'd be just fine. 

Well, a ship full of radioactive Alphabeavers landed and they ate all of the trees and all of the wood in the storehouse. A blizzard started the next morning. We made it 2 days before we ran out of wood. I was the first to go trying to chop the few trees left on the edge of the map. My wife didn't know how to chop wood, a real homebody, so she froze to death in the house with the kids after a few nights when I didn't come home. Huh

10/10

pros:
amazing and actually funny ingame generated lore
its a management game so its my kind of game
the mod community keeps the game fresh and new

cons:
it gets stale
the game is single threaded and very unoptimized for mods 
the 2 dlc's "ideology and biotech" didn't add anything new "ill explain"
Massive time sink

explanation:
Don't get me wrong Rimworld is actually super fun but i wouldn't recommend it anymore, i did in the past. My issues with where the game is at, look at the ideology and biotech dlc's. ideology was amazing when it came out it was something new and not really on the workshop then came biotech which was essentially content already on the workshop. 

on top of it i realized that i can't enjoy the game without having more than 300 mobs changing the gameplay to be something that it wasn't like CE (Combat Extended). Even then when I have all those mods running it takes my computer a massive 5? 10? minutes to just boot the game up and the game is stored in an NVME ssd. I seriously built a separate computer just to run the game faster because its SINGLE threaded? like why? yeah there are mods that make the game multi-threaded but the compatibility is super limited

for those who are looking at my gameplay time and thinking "4k. that's nuts" you should also know that alot of this time in game was sorting mob load order back in 0.14 <1k hours; Before i used rimpy which made mod load order easier. 

over all if you do decide to get the game. sure. enjoy it have fun with it, but also remember that you're going to be spending ALOT of time with mods in the future and when you eventually do, going through compatibility and load order is gonna make you lose alot of time that shouldn't have been wasted.

Man... it's amazing what the base game offers, and the available mods just gives you an ALWAYS expanding library of content to customize your experience how you want it. Hell, I'd highly suggest grabbing the DLC, even at full price, just because the game's THAT GOOD. I'll never regret this purchase.

This game has a lot going for it.  Unfortunately, the AI is not one of them.  It has the dumbest AI of any game I've played in a long time.  It's like the entire AI is just a 2-page Case statement.  The game is designed to where you give your people more general of tasks, getting into specifics sometimes, but what ends up happening instead is you have to micromanage the hell out of them, even resorting to trickery, to get them to do what you want and to avoid them doing incredibly boneheaded stuff.  It's infuriating.  And, because the AI is supposed to handle most of what your people do, you end up fighting with the AI to get things done.  Sometimes it will go so far as to completely ignoring direct orders.  I just can't with this game.  I've installed many mods to correct this, but the AI fights with them, too, so mods only correct issues sometimes.

One thing this game really has going for it is its low overhead.  I can tab out of the game and leave it running in background on pause and not have to worry about my computer eating up all the electricity in the house.  In fact, I've accidentally left the game open for days, not realizing it was open.  It didn't crash even though I'd put my computer to sleep multiple times between play sessions.  The AI may be dumb as hell, but the core program is solid.

TL:DR Rimworld is a classic. Play it. Now. 

Rimworld is a survival builder, with a lot of options and a lot of RNG elements.  A typical start has 3 colonists, with options to pick up more as the game goes on.   Most colonist behavior is either automated or semi-automated, where the player gives them jobs and the colonists complete jobs at their own pace. The core loop would be gather resources, use resources to maintain or upgrade your base and colonists, and then defend from an attack or complication.  Colonists can be decked out in a variety of ways (from clothing to stimulants to bionic limbs), have attributes, and can have negative attributes that can screw you over (suffer not the pyromaniac).  Colonists have activities they like, and activities that they won't do.  There is ENORMOUS variety in the power and utility of the colonists. 

Rimworld is ultimately about:
A: Keeping your colonists alive. You must keep your colonists healthy and safe.
B: Keeping your colonists happy. Unhappy colonists will act up in all sorts of dangerous ways. 

If you can do A and B, Rimworld is pretty straightforward. Rimworld, however, has lots of ways of making A and B hard. There are other layers to playing Rimworld optimally (i.e. labor, time management) that the player can opt to avoid for more casual play. There is a broad variety of difficulty options, notably with three 'storytellers' that dictate the frequency and nature of RNG events. 

The caravan system is a bit weak, and diseases can be very punishing to inexperienced players, but overall Rimworld is a must-have for PC gaming. There are handful of weird game mechanicss that the player has to learn to account for or tolerate (pathing, etc.), and while these can be very frustrating from time to time, they don't wreck the core experience.  Killboxes can seem a bit cheap and unrealistic, but in general they work very well. 

The mod community is active, established, and top-notch. Prepare Carefully is an easy suggestion. The game (at the time of this writing) has 3 expansions, one of which (Royalty) is a bit so-so but the other two are very good. Still, I wouldn't say any of them are 'necessary' to enjoy the base game. The base game feels well made and fleshed out, and the expansions 'expand' the game rather than 'complete' the game. 

9.5/10, only held back IMO by the caravan system

RimWorld is all about resource management and time management, which I absolutely love. The parts of the game that I don't want to micromanage, my colonists do automatically, while there's just enough of the more interesting stuff to keep me engaged without feeling overwhelming.
The only real complaint I have is that sometimes the AI can be dumb, so you have to keep your eye on what they're doing, especially when threats appear. The colonists will do things like work while they have the plague, then die because they didn't get enough bed rest if you let them.
Overall, it's an amazing game that fills my management game need.

Introduction:
RimWorld has become a cornerstone in the world of colony management and survival games, offering an unparalleled experience that keeps me coming back for more. The blend of storytelling, resource management, and unexpected events creates a dynamic and immersive world.

Gameplay:
The depth of gameplay in RimWorld is astounding. From designing your base layout to managing diverse colonists with unique skills and personalities, every decision matters. The AI Storytellers add an extra layer of unpredictability, ensuring that no two playthroughs are ever the same. The challenge is real, but the satisfaction of overcoming obstacles is immensely rewarding.

Graphics and Atmosphere:
While RimWorld's graphics may not be cutting-edge, they contribute to its charm. The pixel art style is both nostalgic and effective, conveying the gritty atmosphere of survival on an alien world. The attention to detail, from the diverse environments to the weather effects, enhances the overall immersion.

Mods and Community Support:
One of RimWorld's greatest strengths is its modding community. The Steam Workshop is a treasure trove of additional content, ranging from quality-of-life improvements to total conversion mods. The active community and regular updates from the developers demonstrate a commitment to the game's longevity.

Warcrimes Element:
For those who enjoy pushing the boundaries, RimWorld even allows for the simulation of warcrimes in certain scenarios, adding a dark and morally challenging dimension to the gameplay. It's a testament to the game's flexibility and the freedom it provides to players to shape their own narratives.

Replayability:
RimWorld's replayability is practically limitless. The combination of procedural generation, random events, and modding support ensures that each playthrough offers a unique and engaging experience. Whether you're aiming for a peaceful colony or embracing chaos, RimWorld accommodates various playstyles.

Conclusion:
In summary, RimWorld is a masterclass in storytelling and colony management. Its depth, challenge, and modding community make it a must-play for fans of the genre. While it may not be for everyone, those who appreciate a rich and dynamic gaming experience will find RimWorld to be an absolute gem.

RimWorld stands as a perfect 10/10 in my gaming journey, securing its spot as my all-time favorite. Its unique charm prompts me to eagerly snatch up any DLC released, no questions asked. It's not just a game for me; it's an instant recommendation to all my friends, and witnessing them succumb to its addictive allure is a delight in itself.

This game is a strong contender for the best game on Steam.

If that endorsement wasn't enough, allow me to explain. This game is a colony sim that allows you to take your group in any direction you wish. If you want to be a clan of normal folk just trying to scrape by, that's both possible and engaging. Watching the little pawns struggle to get through the next year while dealing with their own emotional baggage is quite beautiful. You'll watch them struggle with depression, lust, sorrow, sickness, jealousy, addiction, the list goes on. 

You can also engage in morally reprehensible acts like slavery, organ harvesting, and more. You can set up automated murder machines that truly make you question your own humanity. With the DLC, child soldiers and slaves are added to the equation, which elevates the game into some truly messed up territory. 

You can choose to escape the planet your colonists crashed on, or you can stay and play the game for as long as you like. You can specialize in making high value goods and trading them, or you can raid surrounding colonies and steal from all around you. With the DLC, you could mold your group into trans-humanists, communists, supremacists, drug-chasers, the list goes on.

The title screen describes the game as a "Story Generator", and while it isn't exactly correct, I do feel like the game always provides an interesting story to reflect on no matter how long your colony lasts.

This game accomplished much of what made "Dwarf Fortress" so great, while also stripping away come of the unnecessarily complicated aspects and giving some much needed visual flair. While DF is great in its own right, there is no question that it wouldn't have made the jump to Steam without RimWorld. 

There are some unfortunate downsides, though, and they are important for anyone looking to get into this game. 

You'll notice that I've said "With the DLC" a few times in this review. I feel like the DLC is very crucial to having the best RimWorld experience possible. The unfortunate thing is that the DLC ALONE costs $65. This means that the ideal RimWorld experience will cost you around $100. That is simply too much. I would maybe undertsand if everything, DLC and base game included was $60, but no game should be that expensive. Royalty, in particular, is not worth $20. If you were to skip out on any DLC, skip out on Royalty, and buy Ideology and Biotech. I bought Royalty so that my character could wear a beret.

There are some very weird and specific issues with the game that are largely fixed by mods. For example, one of my characters had a baby that obviously needed food to eat, but the baby would only specifically eat baby food, and not nutrient paste, a cheap form of food with a paste texture. Babies should be able to eat this easily, yet there's no way to make that work beyond modding the game,

I still recommend this game to anyone interested in it, with the recommendation of slowly purchasing the DLC over time, as they exponentially increase the game's depth.

The crazy things that can happen to your colony and the relationships/interactivity between the pawns/animals/enemies will be hilarious, frustrating on higher difficulties and exhilarating once you get the hang of it. This is a colony/base building game with a skill system, relationship system, idea system, children system, and many other RPG/real-time elements that work really really well together. The DLCs add complexity, and I love complexity. My biggest complaint is that there are no achievements, but that is not a real complaint.

This is one of those games that you can't really review without talking about the modding community, since at this point I have so many great one that I don't even know what is part of the base game, DLC or mod.

The base game is great in itself but the mods just elevate the possibilities to a whole new level, allowing you to play games that are radically different but still as fun.

The DLCs add quite a bit of interesting things like psi powers (which you can make more engaging with mods) or ideologies/religions (that once again can be expanded to infinity with mods)

TLDR: If you like colony sims, building cute bases and stories with pain and hardship this is your game

The base game is just the template upon which the mod scene has turned this thing into something with thousands upon thousands of hours of potential.  It is ultimately what it says it is: A storytelling engine.  That's what it generally does best, although it can do a great, great many things.

Rimworld can be played like a pure game, but that's not really where it shines.  Rimworld is absolutely at its best when you've got a loose idea in mind and curate a modpack (or just find a premade pack that works) and run with it.  From there, who knows what might happen?   That's the beauty of it - being both unpredictable and just-predictable-enough.  It's really about finding that sweet spot of controlled chaos that you can have fun with.

So long as you never lose sight of what this game truly is, you'll realize it can be fun again and again.

Probably one of the greatest colony sims on steam to date.  I don't think anything can beat the depth of Rimworld. Brutal, cold, and joyless at time, but rewarding and fun when you succeed. Then through all that success the AI decides you'd like a pack of 40 wolves with scaria on your chunk and you helplessly watch as all your colonists and their children are torn limb from limb until there is only one left. You hide inside, low on food and with a drug dependency crossing your fingers he doesn't suffer a mental snap and walk out into the jaws of the wolves.  But a few days pass and he lives, left to pick up the corpses of the wolves and his fellow colonists, but while hauling that colonist he swooned over to her grave he skipped that one smoke leaf joint break and there it is the snap. In a fit of rage he takes out the power, destroys the stove, burns down the barracks. Then wanders aimlessly in his room before he dies an agonizing death of being broiled alive from the fire he started.  You lean back in your chair and stare as the fires burn themselves out. Click to the main menu and start it all over again.

If you love games that focus on developing something small into something big (base building) and managing lots of different aspects of the development then this is the game for you. 

In this case, you are managing a small "colony" or band of people with varying skills, level of technology, differing social relationships with each other, backstory and et cetera.  

Over the course of your game, depending on the difficulty the game has been set at, varying "threats" will emerge that challenge your developing colony/town/base, these can range from devastating to comedic.

You can "finish" the game, but in my many hundreds of hours playing this game, I have never really wanted to finish the game, just develop my base and watch the story of my colonists unfold.

This isn't a game for everyone, I'll definitely warn you of that! It doesn't promote graphics or ease of use, but if you're willing to see past these factors, or if you much prefer the sort of thing this game has to offer, then you still probably shouldn't play it, because it will become an addiction akin to that drug on the street your uncle always warns you about but secretly stashes under his mattress.
  This game is best described as a storytelling simulator, both because it runs as a simulation of a small colonial life on a lawless world, and because the stories that can occur, not as a result of your choices, but in direct spite against them, or in the ones you forgot to make at all, can end up becoming the most memorable part of our experiences in this game. From the first playthrough and subsequent loss of your colony, to the tenth playthrough and subsequent loss of your colony, each session is likely to contain drama, trauma, traders, raiders, and many other rhyming events that I'm honestly too tired to go on about. It's these sessions, the pawns' reactions to their environment, the player's attempt to hold their hands (and I mean that, don't turn your back for a second!), and much more that creates this addicting loop, a concoction of watching a live - action film that you direct, a one-more-turn feeling every time you're about to put it down, and graphic texty details of all the horrible war crimes you can sit back and think, "Wow, I really did that, didn't I?" right before doing something similarly horrible and unforgivable.

Rimworld is like crack cocaine, no matter what you will always relapse into it

Like how will I effectively progress my nice little society?

At one point I was sitting on the toilet thinking ‚Äúhmmm how do I minimize the risk of my colony founder who has the highest skills out of anyone from dying in a fight, since my other members were victims of an organ harvesting ring as children and refuse to commit any acts of violence due to their trauma?‚Äù

And then I was like hmmm

I have an idea!

Slavery!

Instead of killing, eating and making clothes out of the skin of the people who invade me,
I‚Äôll keep them alive and force them to fight for me!

What a great game

It's very addictive, which is why I almost feel free between plays, but I will inevitably go back to it because one day I will make it to the end game. It's hard.

Ultimately, good game, do recommend.

My first play through. Here's how it went.
Please note I did not play the tutorial and had no idea how to play this game.

We crash land, and build a small seaside settlement.
The first issue arises, food. 
Fuck, how do I get food. Hunt animals, but I have a pacifist and two individuals who have no idea how to use their weapons. Fine they'll do.
For the next month we survive of monkeys, guinea pigs and sometimes alpacas.
Throughout this month, "The Terrible Partners" would actively raid our unlucky trio, incapacitating at least one individual every attack.
They survived, and a caravan arrived who informed us of items nearby, so I sent my best to go collect. He was attacked by two man-hunter squirrels and perished.
Then a heat-wave happened, I had no power or cooling, everyone is collapsing constantly. Heatstroke sets into everyone, then as my cook is out of action, someone needs to take the reigns.
She gave everyone food poisoning and eventually died of Heat-death. 

This game is fantastic.

I want to recommend this game to people... but I can't and wont. Simply because some out of touch idiot(s) on their team thought it was a great idea to make the DLC that should have been native to the game cost more to purchase then the game it self.... didnt even make it 20% off for the winter sale so wish list users got pinged, gave a whopping 10% off ($2 btw) Just tired of seeing games that could be so freaking good, but default to "Consumers are stupid enough to buy it anyway, lets give them half of it...and make them pay more for the rest later" ... wouldn't it be great to be the first to do better? ... probably not when there is money to be reaped... just sad to see, but not surprising which is even more sad to see. Not that they will see or care lol. 

TL;DR Great game, potential wasted on money grabs like any other company with detached investors, and no one competent enough to tell them not to make stupid decisions. If you dont care about spending more on DLC then the original game, then go for it...it has the potential to be an amazing game- if you want to reinforce such a stupid practice.

I rarely write reviews but this game deserves it. 

This might be the best game I have ever played. I am experienced with all the top strategy games like Stellaris, Civ 6, Factorio, Starsector and X4 Foundations. However, all those games are missing something that Rimworld has and that is the human aspect. Your colonists have backstories, traits, addictions, bad backs, families, rivalries, etc. 

Your colonists will fight, they will get married and have kids, they will lose loved ones and then visit their graves. Their kids will grow and become adult colonists and fight mechs when they attack. 

I ignored this game for a long time due to its 2d graphics but that was a mistake. This game is epic.

This game is literally unplayable without 
a, extreme savescumming or
b, using only the "meta" builds from the wiki, all designed around exploting the AI and game mechanics the most efficient way possible.

But wait, it's my bad, I totally misunderstood, it's because this is not a game, it's a "story generator." (That means when it drops one of its many "and now you have to start over from 0 and there's not a damn thing you can do about it" events on your 50 hours savefile, you're supposed to answer with "thank you Daddy, may I have another?")
Spolier alert: it isn't a story generator. Crusader Kings is a story generator. This is a "******* off with a cheese grinder" simulator. Big difference. If you even try thinking about roleplaying in this, the game will make sure your colonists unlock the "murder victim #229" character background faster than you can click on that oh-so-useless power armor on the shelf. But don't worry, even if you get one of those rare raid types that [i]don't[/i] drop directly in your bedrooms in the middle of the night without any warning, your guys with the complete WH40K space marine equipment will still get easily one-shot by the cavemen with the poor quality shortbows.
.
.
.

Rimworld is probably one of the best games I have encountered in the past 30 odd years of being a gamer.

Whilst the classic Rimworld experience is one that definitely pays heed to Sci-Fi Shows along the lines of Firefly and it's sequel movie Serenity the game is extremely flexible with mods.

Whether playing vanilla or heavily modded I always have fun. This game follows the rule of Dwarf Fortress - a game clearly inspirational to the creator of this game. Losing, is fun. You don't need to win in Rimworld, sometimes going out in a blaze of glory (or a steaming spiral of mistakes) is just as fun if not more fun than successfully getting through an endgame.

I was reluctant to play this game as it didn‚Äôt really look like the type of game I‚Äôd enjoy. I really enjoy Stellaris, Kenshi, and recently bought Farthest Frontier and this game Rimworld continued to be recommended to me. I finally bought it and gave it a try.

My three colonists, Penguin (a 70 year old man with some medical experience), Chef (a 78 year old gunman who can cook), and Penguin‚Äôs 30 year old daughter Lulu (who was a janitor and an addict of some drug that she drank as a tea.)  Luckily we started the game with a good supply of the tea she was addicted to.

The three got to work on a shelter. We built it off from some temple ruins and added additions from there. Eventually Chef made a few passes at Lulu and eventually, despite their age difference, Lulu agreed to marry Chef. I suppose when there‚Äôs only two men and ones your dad your options are limited. 

We eventually captured our first prisoner Braga. A 22 year old savage lady who agreed to join us after a long negotiation with Chef. Braga‚Äôs father attempted to attack us to no doubt save his daughter, but he (Mark) was thrown in Jail for his attempt.

It was around this time we ran out of tea for Lulu. She spent her days wandering around in a daze for days and days. Finally she had a nervous breakdown and went around insulting people. This made Braga angry and she beat the ever loving shit out of Lulu and put her in a hospital bed. That wasn‚Äôt enough for Braga though. She was so pissed off she walked into the prison and beat the hell out of her dad. He ended up losing a finger. 

Braga‚Äôs lover Flandell crash landed outside our walls (how romantic) and he agreed to join us almost instantly. Braga and Flandell ended up sharing a room and made love nearly every night. Lulu and Chef  had been married for a long time and had never done that. I worry about their marriage.

Eventually a few more colonists joined us. Most came down with a muscular parasite which nearly killed the settlement, but somehow we overcame. Penguin tamed a pet monkey, but it was eaten by a cobra the first day. We can‚Äôt seem to make enough food for everyone and we‚Äôre running low on medicine. The raids are also becoming more difficult. 

I‚Äôm only 60 hours in and I‚Äôm addicted to this game.

One of my colonist's husband was kidnapped so she was constantly in a state of despair, having a mental break every couple of days. I force fed her psychite tea and smokeleaf, but once we ran out of smokeleaf, the breaks weren't able to be stopped. I made the decision to imprison her in the most secure prison cell my colony had until she stopped being sad about her husband. This was going well, until she developed an addiction to psychite tea (we were still force-feeding her the tea).
    I wasn't going to allow an addict into my colony, so I kept her in jail and deprived her of tea until she wasn't addicted anymore. Eventually, my colony was getting very low on food, so I decided to stop feeding the prisoners until we could get a reliable source of food. I ended up pushing her hunger too far and I realized she was going to die if I didn't feed her. As a colonist was delivering food to her, she died of malnutrition.

9 / 10: Rimworld is so much more enjoyable than I initially expected. I've played my heart out.

Rimworld has provided me with hundreds of hours of wild, wholesome fun (and panic, at times) with seemingly-endless customization, struggles, and success stories. The amount of mods available surely contributed; this game may have as much of an active modding community as Skyrim... And it's friggin' awesome! 
For a game with such simple graphics, I love it as much as any of my other favorites. Mods can introduce some... serious technical difficulties, especially in large quantities, but thankfully troubleshooting for this game is comparatively easy and modders make an effort to update or at least fork mods for every major new version of the game; all the while, it's easy to rollback and stick to a stable version if need be.

There are tons of ways to play: Just because I liked to play one save until I had built an indomitable city of thriving superfurries and superhumans and ethically perfected every aspect of their lives, doesn't mean you can't be the most evil or tyrannical overlord, or simply experiment with saves upon saves to get the most out of the glorious story generation that's available. 
The complexity and depth to each unique colonist made me forge quite a strong emotional connection to each and every one of them, almost like they became my children... Few games I've played foster such connections. My best way to describe my experience with this game is like watching a favorite long-running sitcom, but getting to choose the characters and themes.

I absolutely recommend this if you like building sims, strategic combat, modding, sitting back and watching interesting things happen, or just plain experimenting. In Rimworld, possibilities are basically endless.

Played the tutorial, and it let me continue after completing it. I picked randy and the hardest difficulty, but he sent dangers very slowly, I got sure of myself, starting making a colony with a family of three and a pirate captured from a space pod. I go through hardships, a batch of poisoned food, injured from raids and have to bunker down while a manhunter squirrel pack roams around, as the prisoner starves nearly to death. Eventually i recuperate, and start to make real technological progress, when a warg crits my entire colony and a man in black is sent to save them, but two of my three colonists die so it's up to him to stabilize things.

Eventually after having buried my dead colonists he goes cukoo and digs up the corpse of a raider, going on a mental break while my remaining colonist is in critical condition and my prisoner (who has no idea what happened) gets hungrier and sees the MIB roaming around holding a skeleton. Mib recovers, i try to salvage whatever funnies I can get from this situation, and eventually the prisoner decides he doesn't want to become the MiB's next art piece or starve, and he begins to break out, and he really shouldn't have done that. The prisoner Griffin (ironically a fat white man but not neccesary for this story) breaks down the heavy slate gate I have set as his cell door, only to be met with the business end of a now sane Man in Black's revolver. 


Something changes within him, and he takes pity on the remaining colonist, who has now gained an infection with little hope of recovery. MiB takes her out back and finishes her with his revolver, before eventually the melancholy gets to him and he tries to take his wrath out on a megasloth, and dies.

So yeah, I'm excited to play my second game of Rimworld now

This is analysis was result of almost 3 thousand hours of gameplay, both with and without mods. The game has a great idea as a story simulator of sorts, which also has interesting takes on social and behavior. This is the core of the game and the main proposal of it, and that is where the good things about Rimworld ends. The way which the game handles its core options could not be worst, specially if you take in consideration the mods, which could be a core aspect of this game. Kinda made me remember Skyrim without mods: a bland, tasteless experience. Most of mods adds functions, options and tweaks that should have been integral part of the game from the beginning. Also Rimworld has the worse mod management system I have ever seen in any game in my life, and boy, I have played a lot. I'm also a mod developer myself, have done great mods which are published here in the workshop, but I would never, absolute never do any mod for Rimworld. Managing mods in Rimworld is the worst experience I ever had in my life, and made not recommend. Mods are optional and not part of the game, but without them, I don't feel like the game is worth the cost, you should really invest in something else. You just have to choose: either play a bland, tasteless game with lots of flaws, or pay a horrible experience price in mod management that will only last until Ludeon decides to update the game, which will ruin all your mods in your modlist, your game save and keep you away from the game several weeks or months waiting at the mercy of modders that most of times don't even care to update their works. You have been warned.

We crash-landed.
We survived.
We fell in love.
We got married.
For a couple of seasons, everything was good.
Then we got raided.
They destroyed our home and took you away.
I thought you were gone.
I rebuilt.
I recruited more colonists.
I became our protector.
I stayed merciful. It‚Äôs what you would have wanted.
I recruited more prisoners, and pathed others up and sent them on their way after raids. Merciful. It‚Äôs what you would have wanted, my love.
I never gave up hope.
Several years after the raid that took you away, we received a garbled radio message asking for help. I knew it was you.
I told everyone that night that I was leaving in the morning. 
I had to rescue you.
I would go alone, I didn‚Äôt want to risk anyone else.
I awoke in the morning and put on my armor and grabbed my rifle.
I left my room and there was everyone else, ready to go rescue you.
We‚Äôre not letting you go alone, they said. Let‚Äôs go get your husband.
So we left.
We were prepared for the worst, and brought all our best weapons and plenty of food.
We arrived, and saw a small prisoner camp with three jailers.
They weren‚Äôt expecting us.
It was over quickly.
And then you were in my arms again.
We returned home.
Built a spaceship.
Defended it from raiders.
And returned to the stars.

[i]RimWorld[/i] is all about building up a nice little colony after crashing on a distant planet. The goal is to survive and advance far enough to be able to escape that strange planet you crash landed on. 

[b]RimWorld:[/b] The basic war crime simulator with a bit of colony sim attached to it.

[b]Royalty DLC:[/b] It's all about committing war crimes while you build up your royal lineage - sounds like the UK innit?

[b]Ideology DLC:[/b] Committing war crimes in a cult that thrives by brain washing people into your believes.

[b]Biotech DLC:[/b] Committing war crimes with the addition of children - you can also modify genetics and build mechanoids to commit war crimes more efficently!

In all seriousness, I put like 85 hours into [i]RimWorld[/i] so far and even the base game offers a lot of replayability. I haven't touched any mods yet but scrolling through the workshop page alone made me realize that there is a lot of stuff to mess around with. 

I would recommend trying out the base version of [i]RimWorld[/i] first before buying any DLCs or adding mods, since it's probably best to learn how the game works before adding a bunch of stuff that makes the game more complex or that makes changes to how the game works.

[i]And no, giving prisoners some weed and booze before releasing them is not a crime - but shooting them in the back afterwards might be.[/i]

RimWorld is a masterpiece that blends strategy, creativity, and storytelling. If you're a fan of immersive simulation games, play this!

The Game is incredibly fun, thats what you hear all the time but i can back this up ten fold. For one the game is designed so that it can be customized in any way, which you can do with any game with steam workshop but this one is different, it has 4 modes with 3 difficulties that can then be customized to how you prefer to play the game (Smooth Game play where action stays relatively the same, Exponential difficulty where the game gets harder and harder, and randomizer which as you can guess causes random events to happen). I can't explain all the positives of the game in one single comment, but this is one of the things i personally like about it.

This game will change your life. If your dog is revolted at the thought of playing with you. If your friends insist they don't know you. Even if your Mom tried to abort you in your teens. None of that will matter while playing this game. It will all seem superficial and tame by comparison. You will develop a different outlook on life after just a few games. Once you see the Messed up stuff that happens in here you will never feel sorry for yourself again. Consider this a cheap alternative to therapy. *This a game that will inspire other games for generation.

Quick and short positive review:

replayability? Guaranteed. Many times.

One of the very few games in the last ten years, that keeps me hooked and always gets me to come back.

An exceptional colony sim set in a sci-fi universe.  Play towards the end game, or go your own way.  Be primitive or be futuristic.  Be good, be evil.  Help people or use them. Build a community or build a fortress.  Fight The Man, or be The Man.  Be a vampire and go on to raise little, itty bitty vampires of your own.  Free people, or enslave them.  Be a shaman and help others find the true path.  Be a capitalist or be a socialist.  Finally build that ranch you've been dreaming about, or that farm.  The possibilities are endless.

Keep a sharp eye out though, because while you might feel isolated, there are a surprising number of groups fighting for survival as well, and they will eventually turn their eyes on you.  Human, alien and robotic will all eventually come looking for a piece of what you have.

In my opinion, all three dlc's are must-haves, and add a lot of depth and so many more options to explain choices you make in the game.  Ideology adds a belief and religion system, allowing you to provide shared motivation for you colony, as well as conflict from within and without.  Royalty adds a political system, allowing you to rail against it, or join it, and bringing a really nice system of "spell casting" through augmented mental powers.  The system is very nicely balanced and integrated into the game giving you lots of new options on how you want to play and approach solving problems.  Biotech brings yet another set of options that are seamlessly integrated, controllable robots, and gene manipulation.  Create an army of robotic helpers, or super soldiers, or both.  The game is quite good even without the dlc's, so if you've never played a game like this, try it without the dlc's and if you find you like it and want more, grab all three.

The game-play encourages the use of pausing and analyzing your colony and its situation.  There are multiple speeds of time flow, allowing you to sprint to an event then pause and figure it out, or play at a slower speed and deal with things as they happen, like an RTS game.  There are levels and levels of detail and information to gather in-game, as well as a nice public wiki that is a go-to for learning the nuances and the workings of objects and mechanics.

There are a number of ways of tailoring the game to your mood.  You can turn down or off most negative events, or turn them way up.  You can randomize them, or have the events get tougher as you get better.

Graphically, although being 2D, top-down, it is beautiful.  Structures and items are futuristic, without being way out there.  They mix really well with a more primitive play, or a futuristic one.  As your colony expands, everything just integrates really well and is quite nice to spend hours staring at it.

If you like this style of game, the asking price for this game is an absolute steal.  You won't regret buying it.

Do you like playing other games? Going out with friends? If so, then avoid this game at all costs. This game is legitimately crack in Video Game form.

The only bad parts about this game is the world itself doesn't feel like it's alive like your colony. Nothing really happens on the map unless you make it happen. Also, pawns can be frustratingly stupid sometimes and prioritize things very poorly. Some of that can be solved with mods, but for the most part you have to micro-manage some things WAY too much.

Other than those things, the game is an absolute 10/10. Mods boost it even higher than that honestly.

As for DLC, the only one I'd say is 100% worth it is Biotech. Biotech adds so much awesome content. The other two are REALLY dependent on how you want to play or how hard you want things to be.

Ideology is neat, and it adds some really good buildings like the Biosculpter Pod, but the ideology system just kinda makes the game more difficult without making it more fun. Unless you like managing 700 different religions in your colony, you're gonna have to imprison pawns and convert them and that can take a loooooong time. I alternate between having religons on or off on each playthrough because I don't really want to deal with it every time.

Royalty really doesn't add very much, the best thing about it is you get a new faction you can trade with that has a lot of great things to offer. Other than that, the royalty system doesn't really mean much and it doesn't add much else worthwhile imo.

RimWorld stands as a shining example of indie game innovation, blending colony simulation, storytelling, and survival elements into a captivating and unpredictable narrative. Developed by Ludeon Studios, this sci-fi colony management game immerses players in the challenges and triumphs of shaping a thriving community on an alien world.

One of RimWorld's strengths lies in its emergent storytelling. Every playthrough is a unique narrative woven by the interactions and decisions of colonists. The game's AI storyteller dynamically adapts events to keep players on their toes, presenting challenges that range from natural disasters to interpersonal conflicts, creating a dynamic and engaging experience.

The depth of RimWorld's mechanics is staggering. From crafting and resource management to base-building and diplomacy, the game offers a rich tapestry of interconnected systems that keep players engaged in the constant juggling act of survival. The diverse skill sets of individual colonists and the challenges they face contribute to the depth of gameplay, requiring thoughtful decision-making and strategic planning.

The modding community has played a significant role in RimWorld's longevity and versatility. The Steam Workshop is teeming with player-created content, offering everything from new factions and technologies to total conversion mods that transform the game into entirely new experiences. This commitment to modding has allowed RimWorld to evolve and expand far beyond its original scope.

RimWorld's aesthetic, while simplistic in its presentation, carries a charm that complements the game's depth. The top-down, 2D style allows players to focus on the intricacies of their colonies, and the soundtrack adds a subtle layer of atmosphere that enhances the overall experience.

The dedication of the development team to ongoing updates and improvements has solidified RimWorld's status as a modern classic in the simulation and management genre. The game's active community and the wealth of player-created content ensure that RimWorld remains a vibrant and dynamic experience for both new players and veterans alike.

In conclusion, RimWorld is a testament to the potential of indie game development, offering a compelling blend of simulation, storytelling, and strategy. Its depth, replayability, and the ever-expanding world of player-created content make it a must-play for anyone seeking a rich and immersive colony management experience.

It's like dwarf fortress but doesn't require a PhD. Like the sims with guns in space. I don't particularly care for the DLCs, they make the game more complicated than I want just to relax, but I'm sure someone will enjoy them.

Sometimes life happens. 

You have to share a bedroom with another person. Your friend with maxxed out Shooting Skill gets beaten to death by a bunny. A fence breaks and the donkey you spent multiple quadrums trying to tame wanders off the map. You mourn, you meditate on your mistakes, and you move on. Rimworld is a storytelling simulator, and what is a story without it's highs and lows. Eventually your colonists beat the blackouts, eventually they learn the magical mathematics of E G G, and eventually they find love and friendship in a hostile, unforgiving environment.

Then one day, during a very good patch of the emotional seesaw that is your life, you eat your Lavish Meal out on the job.

Without a table.

The madness sets in. Catatonia, rabid rages, depersonalizing right into a pack of manhunting poodles. All because you committed the ultimate sin of allowing your crumbs to return to the Earth instead of onto a slab of wood.

Humanity can find hope for the future in many places, but there are some moments where one stoops to a level so dark and dreary that there truly is no way to find your way out again. Damned be your friends, your thrumbo army, your 60x60 average-sized bedroom. 

Basic Needs forms the base of Maslow's Pyramid, and Rimworld displays that pyramid atop a wooden table (poor).

The game throws everything at you: diseases, faction raids, rabid animals, relationship failures, house cleaning, psychotic breaks, home renovations, injuries, etc. It's all designed to ruin your colony, and eventually it succeeds. And yet you still want to restart and try again, which is a tribute to how entertaining the experience is. Mods provide certain quality of life issues, but aren't critical to the experience.

My one nitpick, or maybe request, is that in high-stress situations the only possible results are bad. Every now and then, it would be nice to see the toons react to stress by banding together, displaying selflessness, and/or rallying to meet the challenge. Kind of like the stress system in Darkest Dungeon, where sometimes when all seems lost, the heroes rise to the challenge. I don't want RimWorld going soft on me, but sometimes it would be nice to think that humans don't just react to stress with tantrums, binges, and arson.

I'll be honest about this, I do not enjoy the vanilla game that much. Is it bad? No. It's actually designed *rather well,* but it has a plethora of shortcomings that none of the updates nor DLCs really address. Honestly, the artstyle, the toddler-piloting-an-adult AI of the raiders and how easy it is to exploit killboxes,  the utterly unimmersive combat system, the poorly optimized code and the characters feeling like pawns (literally, they're called that in-game and they feel exactly like non-living chess pieces, none of the traits do much to make them feel that alive) just takes away from the masterpiece this game could otherwise be.

However, this far into the review you may have guessed, ''but wait, this is a thumbs-up review... that means...''

Yes, Tynan Sylvester (bless his cranium) and his team figured out that making your game's code easily accessible to the modding community can do wonders. They learned from Todd, and did infinitely better with this piece of information than Howard ever has. All of the issues, flaws, shortcomings and gripes I mentioned... they're not only solved by the community's mods that you have EXTREMELY EASY ACCESS TO... but there's so many more mods out there that improve shit that I didn't even think could be improved, content that I didn't even imagine could be added to the game.

RimWorld is a good game as a base, but if not for the incredible community of modders (Jecrell, Fluffy, Rainbeau, and like thousands of others with sometimes dozens of mods each) it would remain as just that, a good game. However, with the modding community, RimWorld transcends the limitations of its initial flesh to become something much, much greater. It becomes one of the best games on steam in my opinion.

A couple of years ago I told myself that there is no way I could enjoy a game as much as I enjoyed Skyrim (I have +1000 hours in that game). Then I saw Rimworld in a YouTube channel I follow. I thought, "This game looks silly, why would it be recommended?" But it was on sale, so I decided to give it a chance... I have addicted to this game ever since.

Rimworld may be a little hard to understand as a new player, but once you get the hang of it, the game gives you the ability to run a colony ANYWAY you want. You want a colony of high-tech pirates that terrorizes a planet, sacking any and all settlements? Yes, you can. Want a colony of tribal people fighting the elements and the killer robots that come after you? Sure. Want a colony of tribal pirates that terrorizes the planet and fights against killer robots-- you get the idea.

If there is a word that describes Rimworld is FREEDOM. You can set a colony however you heart desires. The devs have given the player freedom to set the game however the player wants to. Also, the devs have given the community the tools to run rampant with mods, which adds even more things to the list of what one could do in this game.

I have had enormous fun playing this game.  It has endless replayability, especially with the mountain of excellent mods available.  There are so many ways to play it and I take a different approach each time I start a new colony.  Of the expansions, Ideology stands out as adding the most content, customization, and flexibility.  I highly recommend this one for anyone who likes sand-box type games.  It does require a fair amount of research to play well, but if this is your type of game then you are likely into that aspect as well. It's defiantly one to play on a powerful PC with large monitor, and keyboard.  The loss of modability on consoles removes 90% of the available content and it's a fairly demanding game.
Whether you want a moral base or a warcrime simulator, it's got a lot to offer.  It's a lot more under your control than many other randomized games.

Well, golly gee, space cowboys and cosmic calamities! I crash-landed like a candy-loving comet, thinking I'd be trading sweets and high-fives with the locals. Little did I know, these colonists are running a culinary circus, turning human feasts into the main attraction. Forget about cookies ‚Äì they're munching on more humans than a herd of muffalos at an all-you-can-eat buffet!

But hold on to your rocket boosters ‚Äì the craziness doesn't stop there. These colonists are playing doctor with raiders, swapping organs like they're trading cards in a galactic poker game. I mean, I signed up for colonizing, not a live demonstration of Operation: Space Edition!

As if that's not wild enough, every two days, it's like the Steam Workshop exploded in technicolor chaos. The player's adding more mods than I have Legos in my collection. I swear, they've got more mods than I have excuses for not doing my homework ‚Äì and that's saying something.

Just when I thought I'd seen it all, in walks this character with two wooden legs, talking about upgrading me like I'm the latest gadget. Wooden legs, for crying out loud! Rimworld's intricate balance of resource management, base construction, and colonist well-being captivates the perfectionist in me. Achieving a flawlessly functioning colony brings an unparalleled sense of accomplishment.

Its procedurally generated world immerses players in a unique and unpredictable narrative with each playthrough, ensuring exceptional replayability. Material grinding seamlessly integrates into the experience, offering a fresh and thrilling gameplay dynamic.

As a self-proclaimed perfectionist, I relished the multiple colony restarts, not out of frustration but to refine strategies and achieve optimal balance. Rimworld caters to meticulous players, encouraging experimentation and adaptation.

The modding community significantly enhances the experience, providing a variety of mods for tailored preferences. These additions extend the game's longevity, seamlessly integrating new challenges and features into the core experience.

Rimworld's depth extends beyond micromanagement, exploring colonist psychology and fostering a connection through emotional highs and lows. The emergent narratives, driven by player decisions and random events, create a living, breathing world with a masterfully executed blend of strategy and narrative.

Edit: The devs did address my comments. I disagree with them, but I appreciate that they at least care enough to respond to negative reviews.

RimWorld is the first game I've ever reviewed, because it's the only game I've played I thought worthy. 

RimWorld Novice: *Explains elaborate story about a colony, involving social drama between colonists, tons of little story details pulled from character info and random events, and catastrophic failure or tragedy resulting in the amazing loss of the colony, all with an attitude of shock, surprise, and amazement, with a huge dose of can't wait to to try again*
RimWorld Veteran: *In a nonchalant tone, with a hint of reminiscing* "Ah yes, I think that happened to me once. That's just life on the Rim. Wait till you ______"

RimWorld is a game of survival, mangement, and most of all, story. There are many different ways to challenge yourself, and many ways to just sit back and lead your colony to perfection. Don't let the graphics/visual style hold you back. You have nothing to fear, the amount of content for the price tag is staggering. Especially once you mention the very active and supportive, mod & reddit community.

The lives of the colonists you forge, the events you plan or let happen, and the random events that come up, will tell you a different story with every colony you start.

This has become my favorite game of all time. At 32 years old with 20+ years of PC gaming under the belt, I don't say this lightly, or often. It's been several years since the last, and I bet it will be several more before another takes the spot.

I will stick with  games like Necesse and Judgement which do not do that.
