[h1]DISCLAIMER : THIS REVIEW IS MY OPINION, IF YOU HAVE A DIFFERENT OPINION THAN THAT'S COMPETETLY FINE[/h1]
Im going to be completely honest with you, I felt like Rimworld could have had the potential to rival Dwarf Fortress. And after 300 hours I feel I certainly enjoyed myself. But after playing more time with Dwarf Fortress and other games in a similar genre. I can only think to myself how much of a waste this game really is of potential. I want to start by saying I don't consider the 300 hours to be thanks to the developers of this game, but too the massive modding community that circulates the game. Those people are talented and can actually make something with heart like Save our Ship 2 and Vanilla Expanded.  In fact, Im going to say that of the 300 hours of playtime on this game, about 3 to 4 of those hours were spent with vanilla. The vanilla is incredibly [b]boring[/b], events are incredibly limited and you will see all of them in your first few colonies or so. And the DLC are ripped straight from the workshop, especially Biotech which is just a collection of mods. That is just scummy. Especially since the developer charges the equivalent of Paradox with the full game. Also the developer likes to keep increasing the price every time there is a micro-change in the price of freddos in his country. In short, Rimworld is a sadder, shitter version of Dwarf Fortress which is actually a great game I will probably buy the steam port soon. The Graphics are better than Dwarf Fortress though, so it gets an 8/10 IGN.
it's clear the devs know what the players enjoy and are doing a lot to take the ideas of the fans then makeing use of them or createing a platform tomake storys intiry there own

Want to go from primitive rock throwing combat, to planetary annihilation? Rimworld.
Want to make a vast economical empire? Rimworld.
Want to survive an orbital evil robot bombardment, just to then die to a raid of poodles? Rimworld.
Want to watch a 9 year old child C O N S U M E an human as a happy meal? Rimworld.
Want to make a hotel service for weary travelers and caravans? Rimworld.
Want to harvest the organs of hotel guests as a source of income? Rimworld.
Want to breed 15,593 hamsters? Rimworld.
Want to form an army of 15,593 hamsters to eat people alive? Rimworld.
Want to raise a normal family that survives in an apocalyptic world? Rimworld.
Want to set fire to your entire settlement because the B U G S have claimed it as theirs? Rimworld.
Want to take over the world with an army of robots that you built yourself? Rimworld.

Do you like committing war crimes, but are afraid of social stigmas and possible consequences for disobeying the Geneva suggestion? Do you want to sell ethically dubiously sourced organs, drugs and Interns in shackles? Do you want to burn down a village of people that just discovered fire last week? 

Well, do I have the game for you! Rim world is a game where toxic warfare, gene editing, Involuntary internship, disfigurement, cannibalism and drug cooking are not only possible, but dare I say a requirement for the true Rim world experience.

And if that's not enough war crimes for you, there is always the War crimes 2 mod (apparently being a war criminal was so good that they had to make a sequel!)

This is probably one of, if not the best colony management simulators on the market. Its variety and depth are unmatched. Throw in mod support and it now has near unlimited replay-ability. 

My only warning is that, while both the Biotech and Ideology give enough content to warrant the price tag, the Royalty expansion is very lack luster in comparison and its hard to justify its price point.

Others really seem to like this game. To me it would have only a "positive" review if the mods had not saved the game.

Vanilla Rimworld is not that great. There are many things that are not enjoyable about it.
I am trying to think of some but I have so many mods (20+) at this point to fix things I have forgot the specifics.

One feature is in combat if you try to run away to the game seems to limit your speed and give an advantage to the pursuer. So as a gunman you pretty much get beat down unless kill them or human upgrade for speed.
If I was matching the speed of the enemy before I start to run, why would I go half as fast now. This is odd to me.

Anyway you may have a great time playing it, it's not a bad game and you will most likely get your monies worth. It just got more annoying than fun after a while. I guess I expect the mechanics to be somewhat logical.

11 / 10 would break the Geneva Convention again. Want to:

Butcher your enemies and turn their flesh into biofuel and skin into coats? Check
Make a colony of nudist, pacifist tribespeople and hide from every fight? Check
Enslave your enemies and make them follow your every demand? Check
Pretend to be nobility and climb the ranks of royalty through violence, quests and occasionally looking after the High Stellarch's bed ridden pet poodle? You bet.

Seriously though, this is about as close to perfection as any game has come in years. Endless fun, and even while the Ideology DLC pack is the weakest of the bunch, it still adds a huge amount of variety and interest. Pair with about 100 or so essential mods and you've got quite possibly the perfect colony simulator.

After coming back to this game years later, I realized that I never gave it a proper chance. This was one of the first true colony management games to hit the market, and I wasn't familiar enough with the genre to understand how good of a game this really is. I played other games similar to this (Judgment: Apocalypse Simulator, Against the Storm, All the Rebuild games, the Survival Series, Ixiom, etc) and when I came back to it I realized how polished the mechanics of this one are.

If you are a fan of colony management, please give this a chance. You'll thank yourself. Yes, it has a learning curve, but stick with it and it'll be one of the most rewarding games you'll ever play.

Sometimes, the stories you make are the best, and Rimworld truly gives you your own adventure, do whatever you want. Plethora of mods really make this shine. Be a space marine, be a US army grunt. Be an Enclave trooper.

If you like base building and making your own civilization then I highly recommend this game. It would probably be beneficial to at least install some Qol mods for yourself, but you can make tons of different scenarios which keeps the game play quite fresh. "Objectively, there is no reason to bury your colonist in a sarcophagus. It has no mechanical advantage over a grave for the rest of your colonists, and it's a precious waste of time and marble at a time when you are desperate to rebuild. But to you, he is more than just a scrap of code in a video game. He is the researcher who cracked the secret of the battery just in time to save your stale meat from rotting before the long winter. He's the medic who stayed up all night without food without so much as a complaint, saving half the hamlet from bleeding out. He's the miner who recovered precious components from the ancient rock when the old generator broke down. And he died a hero, protecting his fiance and his friends, holding the line against pirate scum storming the barricades. And you will honour him. Because that's what this amazing game does to you."

You can avoid these feelings by using debug and save scumming

 Misha's lover Nelson was heartbroken and beat. He was able to get up and make it to bed. This game should be called shelf manager, because that's going to be one of the biggest parts of your game. You'll be swearing when your people drag all of your hay all the way to the other side of your base away from your animals because you forgot to switch off hay in one shelf unit. Having said that, this is a really great game, just make sure you tailor people in the beginning or it can be really tough. For instance, having a noncombatant in the early game is really difficult. All of the skills are fairly important, but having people with high medical, construction, and intellectual is very important in the early game. You have to be able to effectively heal your people, build things, and do research. You have to upgrade and build because the various raids are tough. Also be careful who is checked for hunting because one of your best people could run out into the bush and get killed by a linx, or some stupid situation like that.

This one of the best games of my life

A lot of people will get intimidated by the mechanics or turned off by the graphics but you are doing your self a disservice

First of all, just like with Path of Exile, do not think you need to know EVERYTHING about the game before you start, there are people with 1k hours still learning, you will definitely fail your first colonies for stupid reason you can't possibly know and possibly experience frustration for not using "exploits" that most youtubers or guides use

My advice: If you enjoy watching people, watch Quil18, No Mods, No DLC playthrough for a while, its great

Use lower difficulties, adjust settings (especially research speed) Save and Load and use Dev mode to test stuff especially on colonies that have gone on a while

It's one thing to handle basic things on early game and another when you have 10+ colonists and crumble from the pressure

Focus on small projects and dont overplan and build

Use mods, quality of life or whatever, to enrich your experience, the game is 10 years old and very mod friendly

My personal suggestions? Everything "Vanilla Expanded" and everything QoL like Simple Utilities, and Allow Tool, Pick Up and Haul, Achtung and many others

But honestly, just play the game, experience the AI storytelling, add more storytellers, your experience will be very different everytime

Disable or reduce frequency of events that really frustrate you  (I feel like I get Solar Flares every week)

You dont have to do unethical things like organ farming or butchering humans, or exploits like killboxes especially on lower difficulties

in fact with great knowledge you dont even need those even on most difficult

Find your balance of using mods and exploits and building/making what you want

Enjoy

Never really played the game as designed and usually stuck to mods, however they pretty much become ingrained into your playthroughs.

The DLCs are pretty good with my preference going; Biotech > Royalty > Ideology. My reasoning mainly being ideology being really finicky to work around unless you have mods to compensate it, like my current colony having atleast 5 different ideologies going on due to most of them being non-prisoner colonists and not converting them through prisoner method.

The base game price for RimWorld is ¬£28.49, which rarely, if ever, gets a discounted price. The price of the games 3 DLCs (Biotech, Royalty and Ideology) collectively cost a whopping ¬£51.97. It gets worse. Another DLC, called Name in Game Access, which costs AGAIN ¬£12.79, gives you the right (subject to approval) to enter a name into the game so it shows up in all players' games. AND if you're not done tirelessly throwing your hard earned cash at Tynan Sylvester AND Ludeon Studios, you can also buy the RimWorld Soundtrack and the RimWorld Royalty Soundtrack together for ¬£10.08, bringing the total cost to ¬£103.51. Come on. This is absolutely ridiculous. This is becoming comparable with Train Simulator games/Sims games in terms of how much the consumer is actually spending.

What's worse is, the game is held up like a lifeless ventriloquist dummy by its modding community, the games "intelligent and in-depth" AI often perplex you with brainless decisions and the game also drowns you with its redundant system of micromanagement and endless menus/sub-menus. The game seems to taunt you by having its AI thoughtlessly dilly-dally into danger and failing to grasp the concept of survival. 

Instead of providing the player/consumer who has spent a trillion pounds on your game already with an enjoyable and balanced experience, the game instead tends to punish you by throwing relentless challenges at you that seem more like punishment than an in-game examination of skill. Oh, and if you criticise the game? the games "thousand(s) hourers" hound you like a pack of dogs, insisting that the game is perfect and that you're to blame, or you're too stupid to get it.

I do not recommend RimWorld at all.

A review cant even slightly contain enough information of what this game actually is. I'll just describe a little bit :) I like to use some mods (like the prepare carefully, where you can easily decide what kind of people and gear you want to start with) and just start playing whenever I feel like. I keep coming back to rimworld.

In the game you make your own story, everything is possible, there is a tech tree that you can use. The game gives a goal you can decide you want to achieve, the goal is to develop the tech tree, gather resources and eventually build the starship and go back to space. If you'd rather run around naked with just a hat of human flesh on your head you can just do that.  

Building and maintaining a strong and defensible tribe is hard to achieve. It really is an easy to play and hard to master game. You can see how many hours i played this game, I still die with new tribes in under an hour when the odds are against me. You can starve, get killed, lose a foot, get a random disease, be tramped by animals, burn to death and a bunch of other things. Have fun!

EDIT: I wrote this at about 500 hours in game. As you can see I now have some hours more.

[h1]üöÄ RimWorld: A Cosmic Tapestry of Survival & Stories üåç[/h1]

[h1]üë®‚ÄçüöÄ Colonists & Chaos üë©‚ÄçüöÄ[/h1]
Welcome to the cosmic theater of RimWorld! It's not just a game; it's a stellar journey where your cast of colonists embarks on an intergalactic rollercoaster of survival, love, betrayal, and some seriously wild escapades.

[h1]üåø Colonial Symphony üèóÔ∏è[/h1]
The symphony of construction and strategy is mesmerizing. Erecting buildings, cultivating crops, researching new tech - it's the harmonious dance of civilization amid the untamed wilderness.

[h1]üí• Drama Galore üé≠[/h1]
Watch the drama unfold! Colonists have minds of their own. They'll brawl, love, cook gourmet meals, or have mental breakdowns. It's like a sci-fi soap opera, and YOU are the storyteller!

[h1]üîÄ Choice is Power ‚öôÔ∏è[/h1]
Choices shape destinies. Every decision, big or small, has repercussions. Will you be a benevolent overlord or a tyrannical ruler? The power lies in your choices!

[h1]üåå Narrative Constellations üìú[/h1]
Every playthrough births unique narratives. The yarn spun by this game is crafted from the loom of randomness and player choice. No two tales are alike!

[h1]üéÆ Controls & Caveats üïπÔ∏è[/h1]
Learning curve? Oh yeah, it's there. But trust me, once you groove with it, the universe opens up! Also, modding heaven awaits those craving more complexity.

[h1]üåü Verdict: Galactic Gem üíé[/h1]
RimWorld isn't just a game; it's a cosmos of experiences! Dive into this rich tapestry of survival and stories - a captivating odyssey worth every solar credit.

This game... just buy it and loose yourself.
Base building: Check
Colony manager: Check
Randy Freaking Random: Check
So many different experiences for every play through. Difficult at first to figure out all the mechanics, but once you do, buckle up. Watch some of the videos about people's different experiences. They are so random, funny, sad, adrenaline packed, and crazy. 
Example of one of my many play through: Sent my hunters out to save someone being chased after. They got out to them and fought off the raiders. Took a few injuries nothing major. Back at home a wild animal went rabid. Started making a beeline for my last colonist who was passive. Wouldn't touch a gun or knife. Is that the end of the colonist? Nope, just because they are a pacifist doesn't mean they won't flip that little switch. The one that controls the power to 6 machine gun turrets, and 2 large canons. The rabid squirrel didn't stand a chance. Overkill? Yes, very much. No kill like it. 
Example of another play through: Was attacked by raiders, fought them off but one of them survived passed out due to injuries. Brought them back to the base, and nursed them back to health. Then harvested 1 lung, 1 kidney, and replaced all their limbs with wood stumps. Sent them on their way. Touch evil, yes. However, one of my colonist could use that lung due to being a sickly child earlier in their life. Breath easy my friend and enjoy the new lung. Mr. Stumpy (as I called the raider who left us a bit slowly) never returned. Seems they took the warning to heart.

One of the best colony sim ever made. With more than 15k mods available on the Steam workshop the options on how to play the game are almost endless. Even without mods the game is a awesome to play. 
With different storytellers, for casual builders who want to enjoy building and a quiet game, up to players who love random gen, like the storyteller Randy Random. 
The character customization is really impressive, because you can give your colonist many different things like a backstory, traits, different looks. All of those options have influence on the skills of the colonist. Like, if your colonist was in its childhood a 'Hacker-prodigy' and in his adulthood a 'Logger' his intelligence skill would be pretty advanced and the colonist is good with plants, but because off it, other skills can be 'disabled', like cooking or do 'dumb labor' (hauling stuff, cleaning, etc.). 
If your colonist has the traits 'Hard worker' and 'Ugly' he will have a buff on all the work the colonist has to do and an extra buff if the colonist likes the works he or she does. But the colonist will see other people who are not hard workers as 'lazy'. And with the 'Ugly' trait the colonist will have a hard time finding love. You can start with a set of skills to begin with, but you can also start with no skill at all. It's all up to you. 
Once you made your squad (or trio, duo or you go (Han) solo) and you're in the game itself, you can choose on which tile to start your base and begin your story. 
Because your colonists have different skills, backstories and work preferences, they are entitled to do different 'work-types/job', like: Hauling, Construct, Cooking, grow plants and cut plants, caring for other colonist when they were downed in a fight and treat them with (proper) medicine. Once this is settled all colonists will do the work you that you set them to do. 
Giving jobs to people can go 2 different ways. You can set them on 'on' so they will do all the work you entitled them to do, but you can't configure on which job to do first and which second, etc. There's where the second option comes in. This option gives you the availability to set priorities to jobs. At first at can be a little bit overwhelming, but if you take your time to see what's on your screen you will get it in no time. All off this and it's not even 1% of what the game has to offer. 

Have fun!

It's focus on telling a story with the seemingly unskilled and very insignificant people you choose to follow (to the point where they're even called pawns) instead of a traditional survival experience is an approach I enjoy. With over 3,000 hours logged, I'm still hooked on this game. It grabbed my attention right from the purchase. It's not just a game for me; it's an obsession, both in playing and watching others play. The game itself is captivating, but it's the vibrant and skilled modding community that elevates it. With their mods, every playthrough feels fresh and unique. I can immerse myself in a tribal cult scenario for hours, and then switch to a high-tech mechanator experience. And guess what? I've never actually finished the game. It seems many of my equally addicted friends haven't either. But that's the beauty of it‚Äîit's not about the end goal, it's about the wild and unexpected journey that unfolds during the gameplay.

If you're at all interested in a colony sim, it's pretty much impossible to go wrong with this game. I can't think of another game besides the XCOM series where I got so attached to people-shaped clumps of pixels and finally beating the game can be a real bittersweet sendoff. It's hard not to feel a little down after spending so many hours building a life on the Rimworld and then leaving it all behind to escape.

The music is amazing - awesome space western vibes both during the calm and combat. This is the only game I've ever seen where I love EVERY track, and it defies that "sci-fi means beep-boop music" trope wonderfully.

Even if you find a way to exhaust every part of the vanilla game (you won't), there's a massive modding community. If you can think of something, somebody has probably gone and published it to the workshop already, and installing mods is as simple as hitting "subscribe" in the workshop and enabling ingame.

Given how much I like it, I can't not recommend this game. (Btw, don't look at my playtime here, I played this game a fair bit on someone else's account before I got it on mine).
The replay value, options to alter the game in the scenario editor, the variety of epic mods, the "toys" available in this sandbox - It's really nice.


However (opinion alert), if not for wide variety of really awesome mods that either add a whole lot of content, offer quality of life tweaks, or are great performance boosters, I wouldn't recommend it.
The pricetag is quite crazy as it is, and to play without mods, DLC feel as the absolute must, and to play with them one would need to spend well over 60 USD.

The base game (without mods) to me feels like paying for the game's demo. Maybe call my imagination limited, but to me there's just not enough here to justify 30+ USD pricetag, (btw ~150 of my currency, which is more than 10% minimal wage).
Without the DLCs (at least Ideology and Biotech) mods are an absolute must, at least to me, and by putting pricetag this high it feels like creator is literally asking you to pay this much for game's engine + mod access. And correct me if I'm wrong, but mods, something made by the community, shouldn't be a part of the game's price.

I feel like 30$ would be reasonable for current "base game" +Ideology +Biotech, maybe 35-40$, while it's actually more than [b] twice [/b] that amount, more than a price of a triple A tittle (where AAA tittles a year or two post release tend to get massive discounts, like 50%. Often 60-75% off after 3 years+. And here, for Rimworld? Discounts are practically nonexistant, at least in my country. The highest discount I saw in 4 years period was 10%. Only this Christmas, for the first time I believe, there was first 20%, and it was for "base game only" - which actually had its base price increased over time.)

Feels this way to me, and to at least 4 other people that I know. Not to mention that I saw plenty of posts online with people saying that they feel the same way, consider Rimworld very expensive.

PS: And to those that say "It's worth the money" and "It's not a problem", tell me:
1. Do you use mods, or is "100% vanilla" perfectly fine to you? Because if you use any mods, that means you aren't quite happy with the product as it is, you would like more out of it, and that "something more" that you're getting with a couple mods isn't - or at least shouldn't - be a part of the price.
2. Did you bought it, or did your parents/relatives did? Because if it's the second, you can't say it's not expensive if its not you who paid for it, and If the first, how much are your earnings? I can guarantee, just because it may not a problem for [b]you[/b] specifically, that doesn't change the fact that many other people around the world have worse financial situation. And yes, it doesn't mean that every product should be "made affordable for them", but a single game, game that doesn't have a whole lot in terms of graphics, music, lore or campaign since it's a sandbox, shouldn't cost them a sizable chunk of their monthly income to play it.

"Rimworld: Where My Colonists Make Better Life Choices Than I Do"

I dove into Rimworld expecting to be the wise and benevolent overseer of a thriving space colony. Little did I know, my colonists had other plans ‚Äì like deciding that fighting giant space sloths with wooden clubs was a stellar idea.

The game opens with a crash landing on an alien planet, and my initial thought was, "Wow, this place looks great for a vacation!" Little did I realize that the weather is as unpredictable as my colonists' life decisions. One moment, they're happily planting crops; the next, they're being chased by an enraged herd of space emus. Thanks, Randy Random, you chaotic deity of Rimworld.

Trying to manage my colonists is like herding cats ‚Äì if the cats were armed with flamethrowers and a penchant for starting fires. No, seriously, who thought it was a good idea to give a pyromaniac a lighter on an alien world filled with highly flammable plant life?

Social interactions among colonists are like watching a soap opera set in space. There's more drama in the rec room than in the entire Star Wars saga. Colonist A insulted Colonist B, who then decided to insult Colonist C, creating a ripple effect of hurt feelings that culminated in a full-blown colony-wide brawl. Note to self: invest in more comfortable sofas.

And don't even get me started on the wildlife. I thought hunting was a straightforward task until I witnessed my crack shot colonist miss a giant space rabbit at point-blank range, only to hit a fuel storage tank behind it, resulting in a colossal explosion. I've never seen a rabbit laugh before, but I swear that one did.

Despite the chaos, Rimworld has a strange charm that keeps me coming back for more punishment. It's like a relationship with that one friend who constantly leads you into bizarre situations but somehow makes you laugh through the chaos. Rimworld, you magnificent disaster simulator, you've won my heart ‚Äì and set it on fire a few times for good measure.

Typically I do not review games but do to how much sheer value is here I feel almost obligated to post this:

Throughout my many years of playing games I can easily say there has been one main issue that has plagued my gaming experience more than anything. The ability to feel that a game has "continuous value" to be played. Basically what I mean is games that have either a constant future or had such a good past that there is enough content in the game. I will admit I am a different type of gamer to others and money tends not to be the issue, it's more of the investment. I tend to not touch a game if it lacks good replay value unless the story is absolutely incredible. So to some it up there it's replayability that I've always yearned for in games.

Games like Skyrim while not being directly supported still have a great modding team and there is already such great content in the game so it always feels like Skyrim never ends. Terraria is cool for me due to the many different class challenges I can do within the game, but even that will eventually hit a limit. Another major issue for myself is the Challenge that a game has. I've always loved the Dark Souls games due to feeling like I'm earning something within it and not being that fond of Minecraft simply due to it being "too easy" though I love sandbox games.

So why do I say all this? Well it's because RimWorld has filled that perfect niche for me. I truly feel like I can come up with near limitless playthroughs and challenges due to the many starting senerios, colony location, randomness of Randy, lucky with types of colonists etc. and not only this, with nearly each new expansion they release something that VASTLY increases potential playthroughs: Ideology lets you create your own custom belief system that allows your group to play a certain way such as a slave owning canablist, or a transhumanist that constantly adapts their pawn's bodies to make them perfect. The belief system in Ideology created so much beautiful replayability options but BioTech finalized on it and shot this from an outstanding game to a absolute masterpiece. The Xenogenes allow for you to create pawns with custom genetics either mid-run or create entire new races, further expanding on the different runs possible. Not only this the mechinator that can control mechs and turn the game into a complete simulated masterpiece where the mechs do everything is hecka satisfying. Also the mods for the game make this game a never ending cycle of content. That people can easily get tens of thousands of hours out of. Sure the base game costs some money and sure the expansions cost money, but if you at all like colony sim games this game just has to take the cake as the top best simulation sandbox game I've ever played and likely ever will play.

tl;dr - This game has the best replayability I've ever seen in a game while having outstanding gameplay and great mods. This is truly one of if not the best engineered game I've ever seen in my entire lifetime of being a gamer.

This is probably my favorite game. It's up there with project zomboid and mass effect 1-3.

The replayability of this game is insane, and you WILL sink many hours in this game, given that you're into sandbox, indie, modability, story telling, and the silliness of events in your colony.

Worth the buy for several reasons
1 - replayability, way more replayable than starfield
2 - modability, the modding community in this game is large and active. You can mod the game into something that feels like a different game altogether. Want a medieval playthrough? Go ahead! Want magic? Here you go! Want to enter a dystopian future world where the god emperor is living in undeath, where xenos are all out to get you and super space marines are the last line of defense? Theres probably a mod for that too!
3 - story driven, you make your own story, and no two play throughs are the same. Different biomes, different ideologies, different characters and stats, and all the wonky events ( from maddened squirells nobling you to death, to your colonist setting fire to mortar shells because he didnt eat on a table)
4 - depth. Dont let the look of this game fool you. This game is complex. The ammount of mods makes it even more complex. You need to manage a colony, provide food, shelter, entertainment and protection. Not to mention having children, gene modding, space magic (psycasting), cybernetics, and inter faction relationship.


All in all, the base price of this game is worth it. The to say that this game is enjoyable is an understatement.

Rimworld is a fantastic game and has so much potential but because of an early design decision by the devs I cannot recommend this game. Rimworld is single threaded which means ultimately it has a hard cap on what it can do before it grinds to a halt.

You can easily get 30 hours out of a colony but the game will start slowing down immensly. Now if you keep everything small and hard cap yourself to 1-10 survivors and regularly optimize the game manually or have a mod that does it for you then this game would be fun.

I have a lot of respect for the devs especially Tynan. I understand that it would take a lot of work and would have to change rimworld at it's core which Tynan has said he is just not willing to commit to.

This thread pretty much sums it up: https://ludeon.com/forums/index.php?topic=17357.0

To quote Vas: 

"How exactly do you come to this conclusion?  Lets say you have a 4 core machine at 3.6GHz like mine.

Single Core/Thread: Game starts to lag behind because you have a massive base, it's too much data for one core to handle.  Everything gets queued up to run in proper logical order of events.  Game slows down to handle that slowdown in processing queue.

MultiCore/Thread: Game is able to offload some work to different threads.  Thread 1 handles temperature changes.  Thread 2 handles pawn hauling jobs.  Thread 3 handles Pawn Cleaning jobs including snow and calculates whee they should go next each job.  Thread 4 handles pawn hunger and tiredness levels, beauty calculations and other such.  Thread 5 handles mental levels and thought defs.  Thread 6 handles power grid states.  Thread 7 handles random event calculations.  Thread 8 handles Animals and Plants on the map.  Game runs at normal/fast speeds because there is nothing waiting in line to be executed.

And don't give me that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about buying a single core 10GHz CPU in order to play games.  No.  Unacceptable.  This game is one of those that has too much data for a single core to process."

One of Stellaris' standout features is its unparalleled level of customization. From creating your own species with unique traits to designing intricate spaceships and defining diplomatic policies, the game allows for an unparalleled degree of player agency. This flexibility extends to the narrative as well, as each playthrough unfolds differently based on your choices, encounters with other civilizations, and unforeseen galactic events.

The exploration aspect of Stellaris is a true delight. As you send science ships into the unknown, uncovering anomalies and encountering diverse alien civilizations, a sense of wonder and discovery permeates every moment. The procedurally generated galaxy ensures that no two games are the same, offering a fresh experience with each new campaign.

Diplomacy and warfare are intricate dance forms in Stellaris. The game provides a robust system for interacting with other empires, whether through alliances, trade agreements, or the less amicable path of war. The strategic depth of military conflicts, coupled with the evolving galactic landscape, keeps the gameplay engaging and challenging, even for seasoned strategy enthusiasts.

Stellaris benefits from an active modding community, contributing a plethora of user-generated content that extends the game's lifespan and adds even more layers to an already rich experience. Furthermore, Paradox's commitment to ongoing development and expansion packs demonstrates a dedication to refining and enhancing the game over time.

While the learning curve might be steep for newcomers to the grand strategy genre, Stellaris rewards investment with a galaxy full of possibilities. The game's visuals and sound design complement the epic scale of the narrative, creating a truly immersive experience.

In conclusion, Stellaris stands as a shining star in the grand strategy genre. Its blend of deep strategy, expansive exploration, and player-driven narratives make it a must-play for fans of space-based games. Whether you're negotiating alliances, conducting research, or engaging in interstellar warfare, Stellaris offers an ever-expanding universe of possibilities that continues to beckon me back for one more journey into the great unknown.

Look at you. You're in the review section for Rimworld. Congrats, that means you're considering buying it. That's the first step! Now, go ahead and click that buy button.  Not only are you supporting one of the best small team developers in the business, you're also diving into a world that will captivate you for 1,000 hours, if you let it. 

Rimworld is a story generator. And boy, does it live up to that title. 

If you're wondering whether it lives up to the hype, it totally does.  If you're worrying whether it's too complicated for you, it's not.  It's like any good perma-death style game, you will need to throw yourself at it, fail several times, restart several times, and once it clicks it clicks.

This game is a true marvel, shattering expectations and delivering an immersive experience on an unforgiving alien planet. While the visuals may not be groundbreaking, the building mechanics offer a creative outlet, enabling players to craft and manage colonies in the midst of a hostile environment.

As the late game unfolds, the challenges become increasingly intense, pushing strategic thinking and resource management to their limits. Each decision carries weight, and the outcomes can range from uproarious to heart-wrenching.

What sets this game apart is its commitment to unpredictability. The social lives of your colonists play out like a gripping drama, filled with unexpected twists and turns. Even after nearly 200 hours, the game continues to reveal new layers of depth, making it a perpetual learning experience that is consistently satisfying.

The premise of crash-landing on a harsh planet is executed flawlessly, creating a palpable struggle for survival where every resource is a lifeline. The game excels in evoking genuine feelings of desperation and triumph, a testament to its thoughtful design.

While the absence of the ability to build into the ground or create multi-story structures is a limitation, it doesn't significantly detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

In this game, you'll find a masterpiece of unpredictability, challenge, and depth. The building mechanics and evolving social dynamics of your colonists create a unique and endlessly entertaining experience. With a hostile planet to conquer and a constant need to adapt, this game is a journey that keeps you hooked for hundreds of hours. If you revel in strategy games that test your wit and resilience, this game is an absolute gem.

UPDATE: Sometimes I take a break after a colony goes bad, and I install another colony simulator... I play... I have fun, then I click on my pawns and I realize ..I hate them. Their soulless , meaningless, shells of bad attitude. I want them to die..
 I come to the realization that I had a real connection with my pawns in Rimworld...
 Cooth Hogsweed McToad. He was the leader of my great mountain clan of Red Neck Cannibalistic Skin Harvesters. We survived many a qua-drum, fought horrible meat eating insects, we laughed and danced, ate our enemies, ate our friends...life was miraculous. The Slave labor quarry's were operating at peak performance deep within the mountains. The finest human skin was used to outfit all members of society. Skin top hats! We had advanced as far as any great cannibalistic nation could have hoped for, until the fateful day that Cooth Hogsweed McToad went on a raged filled alcoholic insulting spree. His timing couldn't have been worse, as part of the mountain collapsed crushing his mother in Law and 4 others. They died instantly...better then the fate that awaited my other 7,  an infestaion of bugs bigger then ever before appeared from underneath the party room where fresh human skin rugs had just been laid. McToad was still in a full rage , taking swigs from his bottle.....drunk and unable to draw his weapon..the bugs moved in. 
My pawn who had no legs who was in charge of research( i regrettably forget her name) she went down first. It was hard to watch her struggle to move one tile before having her head bitten off. Her head was gone..but the screams continued? McToad never lived to be sober. He died in a drunken state, insulting his legless friends. I was furious, but saddened for him. He was now a broken man being eaten by bugs...all because of a bottle of vodka that was left as a gift by a bulk goods trader.

The morale of this story is you will truly care about your pawns in this game.

Rimworld is brilliant - it is a love letter to Dwarf Fortress that in many ways outshines its inspiration, not least in terms of playability. Ludeon deems it to be a "Story Generator"; if any other dev made such a claim about their game I would dismiss them as an utter wanker, but here it is definitely appropriate. The mechanics are so well implemented and inspired, meaning no two games ever play the same, and the length and breadth of options, biomes, factions and so on will mean there is always something new and interesting to come across.

Its DLCs are genuine expansions, both of content and scope, that push the game in directions it hadn't travelled before. It is rare to find a dev selling DLCs that aren't just pay-for-patches or content that belongs in the base game - Ludeon does it right and I commend them (him?) for it.

A game that I have no doubt I will still be playing in 20 years. RimWorld is timeless and I say with utmost confidence and conviction it is one of the greatest games ever made.

Hey guys, did you know that in terms of economic profit and skill training efficiency, human leather tailcaps are the best for your colony? Not only are they made of materials that come to you, which are mostly comprised of pirates, Human leather tailcaps take an average of 23 seconds to make, and sell for 89 silver on average at crafting level 6. This means they're fast enough to make to handle constant human raids, and with their impressive sell price and light weight, you can sell in bulk to nearby colonies

I had a cool doctor in my colony, but he got old and lost his hearing. I decided to replace his ears with bionic ones, but I didn‚Äôt notice that he was a Body Purist who hated artificial body parts.

While he was lying on the operating table and recovering from the surgery, a huge raid happened. The raiders built siege weapons and attacked us with rockets and mortars. I managed to fight them off, but one of my colonists died. It was the doctor‚Äôs spouse.

The doctor woke up with pain, grief, and anger. He dug up his spouse‚Äôs corpse and brought it to the main hall, where he laid it on a table. This made everyone else unhappy and stressed.

One of my colonists was a cannibal, and he was hungry and wounded from the raid. He saw the corpse on the table and decided to eat it. This triggered a mental breakdown in the doctor, who attacked the cannibal. They started a brawl that soon involved other colonists.

One of my colonists was a pyromaniac, and he was also stressed and angry. He grabbed a flamethrower and started to set everything on fire. The fire spread quickly and engulfed most of the base.

The doctor had an infection from the surgery, and he was bleeding and feverish. He was also the best doctor in the colony, so no one else could treat him properly. He died on the floor, surrounded by flames and blood.

By the time a mysterious stranger in a cloak came to help us (when everyone was downed and helpless), it was too late. Most of the base was burned down, and most of the colonists were dead or dying. The only survivor was the drug addict, who had taken all the drugs in the colony and wandered off to a meadow. He died there peacefully.

Rimworld is a perfect story-generator.
It's super fun and eats time like no other game I have played. Purchase at your own risk.

EDIT: Steam wants me to update my review after a few hundred extra hours, so I'll have you all know that I now have almost 700 mods installed and am STILL finding more of Tynan's stupid, unfun, unimmersive design decisions to patch.

Don't get it unless you have no problem with modding games to be what you want them to be. 

Vanilla game is almost unplayable, because Tynan thinks "randomness" is the same as "storytelling" and he balances the game around the 0.1% of exploiters rather than 99.9% of normal players.

That being said, if you're willing to discard his obnoxious """creative""" vision and treat Rimworld as merely a framework to build your own game in with mods, you can have a lot of fun with it.

You'd expect me to talk about how you can enslave pawns to do your bidding, harvest all the organs of your prisoners and build a drug empire and with the Biotech DLC to have child labor. Not saying that you cannot do that, but I took a different approach with this game.

Sure, from time to time I might do one or two of the things stated above to benefit my colony, but in general I play this game relatively chill. Don't let others tell you how to play this game ( "commitment mode + losing is fun is the intended way to play this game" ), this game was created to be played however you want it to be. You want to be a pacifist colony that only retaliates when raided? You want to become a pirate faction yourself? Sure, you can do that.

The base game has a lot of replayability and with the help of the DLCs and the Workshop, you can sink thousands of hours in this game without you realizing. You have no idea how many times I said I'll take a break from playing this game after finishing a playthrough, just to create a new colony and start sinking in more hours in it. This game can be addicting, but I know when to st- **DING**

[b]The Base game offers a good tutorial that makes learning the base mechanics of the game easy, although mastering these mechanics takes its time.[/b]
The Game offers a completely customizable difficulty where you can change how dangerous or peaceful the world and its inhabitants are. You can change the possibility of faction raids, animal attacks, natural events (good or bad), the frequency of diseases and even how likely you colonist get food poisoning from badly prepared food. There are also premade difficulty's that are well balanced.

[u]After playing the game for some time in its original form you may want to make things more lively. For that you have two options; one is free and made by the community, the other is in the form of official DLCs.[/u]

The steam Workshop offers vast options of customizing and tailoring your experience to fit your play style. You can add new regions for the map, new factions, new plants, new weapons and armor, new clothes and even let you play as factions from star wars or Warhammer 40k. 
It is not unusual for Rimworld players to have a couple hundred mods in their mod list, although you should be careful as they could break the game.

The DLC made by Ludeon are great to create more Immersion and to tailor the game to your own play style.
[olist]
 [*]The First DLC ,Royalty, is more of a flavor and Role playing DLC as it adds a new faction with their own ranks and a new honor system. Aside from the faction it doesn't add to much and doesn't really impact the game to much. It is a nice addition but not a must have. [b]It is the oldest DLC and adds the least gameplay features[/b]
 [*]The Second DLC, Ideology, adds Religion to the game. It offers great customization options and many features to choose from which directly impact how you play the game. You can create cave dwellers that hate the light, love fungi and love taking slaves. You can also create peaceful hippies that would never hurt others, never pick up a gun and hold charity in high regard. With these you can make the game easier or harder but almost anything you want to do you can do. 
[b]This is the second oldest Dlc and addds a good bunch of gameplay features aimed at immersion.[/b]
 [*][b]The Third and most recent DLC, Biotech, adds by far the most to the game.[/b] It adds children, xenotypes and mechanoids. With the addition of children you can finally let your colonists start a family and raise your kids the way you want them to be. You can make them into well balanced adults that can do most things or you can train them for a specific task and make them your specialists.
Xenotypes are alien races that you can customize yourself to be whatever you want. They could be Dwarves, Elves or Orcs, or just slightly altered humans that are better at cooking than others. You can customize the looks, feelings and even what they are good or bad at.
Mechanoids are robots that are hostile to you in the base game, but with this DLC you can create and control these yourself. You can build robots that help you build stuff, take care of wounded, cook and even fight for you.

TLDR: This game is a true sandbox where you can customize every aspect of the game to fit your play style. I recommend this game and its DLC because it can give you hours of entertainment even before delving into the well balanced DLC and the vast modding scene. You may see this game referred to as a "Warcrime Simulator" and while its true that you can be evil and there are plenty of mods for that, you can also build a peaceful community that builds a farm and that helps people and is running a hospital to help people and makes the world a better place.
[spoiler]Although you will probably remove a few organs and sell them on the black market after the fifthiest raid came in and they killed your favorite animal or colonist. If they kill a colonists kid there are also mods that let you wipe their settlement of the map with righteous anger.[/spoiler]

I've been putting off writing a review for RimWorld because I have put so many hours into it (119 and counting as of now), and yet I feel I've only scratched the surface. At this point, I've had settlements that have lasted and have been successful, and I've had others that were downright awful. There's no telling what will be handed to you, both good and bad, or even when. 

I had one settlement that was thriving until one particular pawn I was building up died. After that, all hell broke loose. The food quality tanked. Because the food got substantially worse, everyone was getting sick. Because nearly half of the population was sick, they could barely maintain the farm. Even the doctor got sick and somehow got through it, only to be slaughtered by a raid that nobody was prepared for. Eventually, there were only two left, living in the ghost of what was formerly their thriving town. Food was scarce, research ceased, and eventually the two remaining souls were lost to the cold of winter. 

10/10, would recommend.

An amazing game. 

You choose your own adventure. 

Whether you decide to start your journey as a small crew of spacers descending unceremoniously from among the stars, or as a large tribe forced to migrate from their homeland, or as a member of the upper-crust deciding to depart their lavish lifestyle to rough-it on a distant planet, or (if you're feeling brave) you can play as someone who went under anesthesia from a minor surgery only to wake up naked on a completely different planet. 

You can lay out plans and build a giant mega-city on a peaceful world where the weather is fair, attacks are rare, and the neighbors are kind, or etch out a meager existence on an inhospitable world where the days cause heatstroke, the nights cause frostbite, and the neighbors could decide at any moment they want to burn down your wooden hovels and steal whatever pittance you've managed to collect before they wipe your colony off the map.

The world is your oyster, but you'll have to use diplomacy and then recruit, enslave, or kill everyone to enjoy it.

This game is amazing and has grown a lot over the years. I might not have a lot of hours into this game (only a measly 234 hours at the time of writing this), but I consider myself decently competent at this game. Rimworld takes some time to learn, and more to master. The game receives major updates from time to time and there's a second DLC, Ideology, releasing soon that looks like it will completely revolutionise the way the game is played. 

Now, the official content is good and all, but where the game really shines is its modding community. There's countless mods to choose from that might change your gameplay in a big (or small) way that adds some more challenge (like Combat Extended), or more things for a certain stage of the game or that adds extra factions (like the Vanilla Expanded series). Or, of course, QOL mods to add things that should be in the game but aren't (yet), or to improve on existing features in the base game. (And catgirl mods. So. Many. Catgirl mods.)

Oh, I almost forgot to mention that you're free to violate the Geneva suggestion at any time, those prisoners don't need all their kidneys and lungs anyway.

As a final score I'd give this game a 9/10 because of the near limitless possibilities for the stories that you can create.

WELCOME TO RIMWORLD
RimWorld: Where managing a colony is like herding cats‚Äîcats with a penchant for setting everything on fire. Forget about utopia; it‚Äôs more like a chaotic circus where your chef is also the resident surgeon, and your janitor just declared war on a neighboring squirrel. It‚Äôs a game where your plans go up in smoke faster than your makeshift wooden structures. But hey, at least Randy Random keeps life interesting, throwing challenges at you like a cosmic stand-up comedian. RimWorld: because who needs sanity anyway?‚Äù

Where do I start...

Rimworld is a [strike] game, [/strike] [strike] experience, [/strike] [strike] colony builder, [/strike]. Rimworld is something different when it comes to gameplay. It can have this relaxed tone and setting behind it with a wonderful score to back its atmosphere. While at the same time providing a sense of tension at every battle. You are in control of colonists who have crash landed onto a, [i] you guessed it, [/i] Rimworld, a planet on the edge of inhabited space. There you are placed, with only a few necessities for survival and are tasked to keep your colonists alive while also finding a way off this rock. 
That's what you hope will happen at least.

After playing for the first time you will most likely lose a lot of people you might grow attached to. Every one of the colonists you are in control of each have their own attributes and backstories which they build on during the game. This can include relationships with other colonists, tribes and enemies. Losing several limbs while fighting. Dying of an infection then being frozen after death and, years later, being brought back from the dead, seeing that the colony of three which they had started with, was now a bustling town of 20.
All of these small stories build off one another, teaching the player how to succeed on the rim. You will learn the best ways to start off, what to focus on to survive and what traits you value for your colonists. Want somebody who loves the taste of human flesh and is fine with blood? You can have that! And sometimes it will be necessary to make a decision on which of your people will need to be sacrificed to keep everyone else alive.

That is the goal in the end. To stay alive, at all costs.

I love Rimworld, not just because it's a canvas where you can let all of the war-crimes you've ever wanted to commit, actually come to fruition, but because it's a journey you are brought on, one in which both the little things as well as the world changing ones all seem to make a difference.
If you liked games such as dwarf fortress, but couldn't get over the text-based nature of it and also love the futuristic genre. Then this game will be right up your alley!

That was my life in 2021

If you're considering buying this game, it's probably due to your genuine interest in a challenging and immersive gaming experience. Allow me to share my insights, borne not just out of my appreciation for the game but also as a brief respite from my intense focus on preparing for an Economics test.

This game elicits profound emotions, inducing tears as you encounter challenges and tribulations. Brace yourself for inevitable setbacks and failures, and profound losses to little bits of pixels you've bonded to. Yet, it's in these moments that the true essence of the game unfolds. Every defeat serves as a valuable lesson, paving the way for eventual triumphs. Far from being a masochistic endeavor, the enjoyment lies in the journey, witnessing the culmination of hours of effort unravel before your eyes, only to rise from the ashes, wiser and more resilient.

The base game itself offers endless replayability, a testament to its engaging design. But the support of the modding community enhances both the utility and content of the game, elevating the gaming experience to new heights. Personally, it's challenging for me to imagine playing without some of them.

In conclusion, this game is more than a mere pastime; it's an experience. A testament to resilience, strategy, and the thrill of overcoming seemingly insurmountable odds. If you seek a gaming experience that transcends the ordinary, with a vibrant modding community to further enhance your journey, then investing in this title is a decision you won't regret.

Rimworld is an awesome colony simulator where you help a group of survivors (or people from another scenario) survive and hopefully prosper on an underdeveloped world on the outer rim of known space (a rimworld). To me this game absolutely stands out due to the storytelling nature of the game and how your colonists feel like individuals who interact with each other and respond differently to the many situations they'll be put into differently depending on the colonist. 

This game has created many fun memories and already became one of my favorite games of all time even though I've only played 160 hours so far. I plan on playing many many more hours due to modding and the ideology dlc that is releasing two days after this review. Although I would certainly play many many more hours even if those two things weren't a factor.

Great game. This is much more than a normal game. It's a story generator and the crazy and funny stories that will organically happen to you are what makes it great. I once embarked on a great trek with many colonists in order to find the ship that could bring me off this planet. Through various misfortunes and battles, I lost people, animals and gear, had to flee and build a provisional base in subsequent steps. About 75% of the way there, my last three colonists died, one was sick and I couldn't operate, the second one went mad with grief and stabbed number three, only to die from blood loss after taking on a cougar. 80 hours of a game and all these characters I came to like and root for wiped out. This is my literal comfort game.  I can play it over and over again for countless hours (as you can clearly see by the absolute ridiculous amount of hours I've put into this game).  A HUGE part of what makes this game so amazing with such a high replay value, is the community!  The modders in this community work hard, non-stop, to offer infinite new ways to play this game.  Whether you want a casual colony builder or something more intense where the game constantly punishes you as you try to progress, all are possible.  You can create your own scenarios and stories with unique and interesting characters and colonists.

Even if you play only the base game, it's still ridiculously fun with interesting and funny moments along with odd circumstances.  There are definitely some morally gray areas or dilemmas you may face in terms of what you're willing to do or not do to make sure your colony survives and thrives.  All bring more fun to the game as a whole and allow you to play it as you wish.  Want to torture your colonist?  Up to you.  Want to keep they healthy and whole (replace those missing body parts and organs) no matter the cost?  Absolutely possible by capturing people and harvesting what you need or advancing your technology enough to create replacements.  I also recommend buying the DLCs if you enjoy the game, as they do expand your options to play as they integrate a lot of great updates to the game and various scenarios as well.  Despite this seeming like such a simple game, it has a lot of variety in worlds, maps, colonists, and preferred game play.  Countless hours of play time and fun no matter your style!

The game itself is really morally corrupting and hard, you make choices what you didn't think you'll never even thought was possible. All for the perfectly imperfect colonist to survive in a hostile world created by AI. Their life is a struggle sometimes and it makes the game so fascinating. One wrong choice might end up making every colonist die. When you talk about this game and take it out of context you'll sound like dictator with bloodlust.

If this game would be fully multiplayer compatibility it would be perfect. The efforts to save your friends from 20 manhunting squirrels so their colonist may rebuild is so much fun.

Edit: Game still good, better in fact. I'm still playing it after another 5 years, 3 DLC, and 4 major updates. I had roughly 300 hours in the game when I first reviewed it. I've on average put in the same 300 hours [i]each year[/i] over the past 5 years. I don't have a problem, I can stop whenever I want.

Original, 5 year-old review (still accurate):

I decided to wait for RimWorld to hit 1.0 before I reviewed it, and I'm glad I did. I got RimWorld years ago, and at the time I would not have recommended it, as it had very little content. However, Tynan and the rest of Ludeon have been working tirelessly on RimWorld for just over five years, and it has become a truly magnificent game. Well, I say game, but, as the title screen says, it's more of a "story generator".
What I mean by that is it has three different "AI Storytellers" with various differing "personalities". Cassandra Classic will slowly ramp up the difficulty as you accumulate wealth in your colony, and raids will get harder and harder, similar to your usual fiction book. Pheobe Chillax is more laid-back, giving you long stretches of time between raids, giving you ample time to prepare for each attack, while also increasing their intensity slowly. Randy Random is as his name suggests - as the game says: "... what happens doesn't matter, it's all drama to him.". There is also a variety of difficulties, basically dictiating how cruel the storyteller is to your colony - from increasing frequency of attacks and other events, to reducing the frequency of new colonists joining you.

As for gameplay, it feels similar to other colony management games like Prison Arcitect (which the art style is heavily inspired by), Dwarf Fortress (which has obvious influence on gameplay), and Dungeon Keeper (to a lesser extent). every person ingame has simulated needs, traits, health, relationships, and moods. Got a person with a artery blockage? They have a higher chance to have heart attacks. have a jealous hard-working glutton? They'll want the best room in the colony, work faster, and get hungry quicker. in terms of game mechanics, there are more than I could ever explain in a simple review. (This one is already getting rediculously long!)

The game is by design very difficult, so if you can't take (lots of) losses while learning the game, you likely won't be playing for long. While the tutorial is well made, it leaves out several details new players would benifit from.

There is built-in modding and workshop support, and a huge modding community providing near infinite replayability to an already incredibly deep game.

Overall the game has come extremely far since I first got it, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone thinking of buying it. The community on the Ludeon forums and RimWorld Discord are both very friendly for anyone new to the game, and can answer pretty much any question you have, and most are willing to start a few new games to test game mechanics they haven't thought to test before.

I'd watch a few episodes of someone's Let's Play on YouTube (I'd recommend [url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCP_Vs5WYfS2tZ1lqbqtTsWQ]Yeti[/url] and [url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCe2l-3DmNBw5i6_AqpWSi6g]Thet[/url]) before buying, to make sure it's a right fit for you, but I'd recommend it to anyone to at least check out!

I don't normally buy Early Access as I worry about the developer abandoning a project once they have the money. So I did a bit of reading before purchase and it is clear that this game is a labour of love. It is also in a very usable state right now compared to many otherwise "complete" games (I didn't experience any game breaking bugs at all). As I have just successfully "completed" the game, I felt it was worth reviewing.

The lore, backstory of your colonists, little blurbs against art, the story that unfolds as you shift from crisis to disaster to success (the games AI storyteller doesn't play nice!), it makes for a very enjoyable experience.

For those that have ever played Dwarf Fortress, this is ideal and you will immediately grasp the game. For those that haven't this is a management sim game with a twist.

I will say, despite my first couple of worlds going sour, losing them was actually a lot of fun due to the circumstances. In the first a single colonist went berserk, downed everyone and then collasped due to exhaustion and that was it! Truly losing this game can be fun.

The mod scene on this game is huge as well, so there looks to be a lot of extra stuff to play at if the 3 AI storytellers, 5 modes and vast land selection isn't enough!

One of the very rare times I would ever suggest purchasing an Early Access game.

I want to start off by saying I am currently doing this for the steam awards - but that is also because I feel I always forget to leave reviews for games.

However, as I have nominated it for the Labor of Love award AND it sits as one of my most played games - lemme explain.

First the award itself. This, game released years ago and to be quite honest - it was fine on release. A top down colony simulator with different ai that will ensure no game ever goes like the last. However, since then they have released 3 huge expansions you can get that changes the game in almost every aspect and adds several new features. Examples are religions, bio mechanical engineering, new factions, weapons, and even different species of humanoids you can have in your colony.

Coincidentally, in writing the review as to why I gave it the award. I feel I have adequately explained at least some of my love for this game. No play through is ever the same and I look forward to the future of this game. Keep it up devs!

If you want a cheap and easy way to drastically improve your colonists moods in their bedroom, just add a marble dresser and bedside table. They'll consider it heavenly and you can keep the rooms on the smaller side. 

Don't forget to play the game with random colonists sometime! It severely helps out with making the game faster to jump into and presents unique challenges! 

Remember, if the durability is below 51% you can safely toss it to expire outside or sell it! Colonists don't like using equipment below that percentage, forbid them from wearing it! 

What you craft with what material DOES matter! Think carefully what fur you use for cold weather, or what materials you use for walls and furniture! They matter a lot and can boost or ruin moods!!

If your colonists hate each other, use their scheduling to specifically keep their recreational time on opposite ends! Work is distracting and nobody wants to have to deal with someone they hate on break!

Truly a game to lose yourself in. 
The art style didn't vibe with me at first, but I'm so glad I pushed past that initial impression because now i appreciate its beauty.
The game has so much to keep you coming back. 
Each play though can be made truly unique thanks to the absurd number of ways you can accomplish your goals and the level of difficulty scaling makes it a game that is impossible to truly master, yet that causes more enjoyment, not frustration.

You may think of this game as a less complex, but more streamlined and accessible version of Dwarf Fortress. However I think casual players are still likely to bounce off of it. This is one of those games that fully hook you in, once you really get them. If you like deep and complex games with many interlinking systems and almost limitless ways to play, you will probably rack up hundreds of hours in this game without even noticing it. And even if you get bored one day, this game has one of the best and largest modding scenes I have ever seen.

Its about time I reviewed Rimworld.  When I first got into this game I had never played a colony management game before.  I set up my little base and my people promptly died because of the heat.  After maybe 5 hours of properly learning how to play I was hooked.  Let me tell you when I got my colonists to automatically hunt, butcher and cook it felt like when I first learned to program.  
Then I got into the stories.  My colonies would be drama filled soap-operas with personal intrigue and hardship every session.  A character would lose family to an overdose, freak out and shoot our wood-fire generator blowing everyone up.  That sort of thing.  I got about 100 hours in just enjoying the game before I got into the mods.  

This game goes from recommended to one of the best games ever with mods.  Genetics, religion, horror, anything you can dream of is in the workshop ready to fit into your narrative.  Ready to add that extra twist of the knife for your beloved characters.  Want a colony of furry fox people addicted to star wars drugs who fight borderlands bandits?  Got it.  Want a colony of cultists to Cthulhu who also have a daycare business on the side?  You can do that too.  The game truly has something for every fan of settlement management.  

The downsides are of course, loss of sleep, social life, and any aversion towards human rights violations.   

Take my f*cking money, Tynan.

Edit: This is probably the greatest game of all time play it.  Tynan pay me for my endorsement.
Still loving it after almost 1500hrs. Thank you Modders!

With the 10 years of labor of love I think it is finally time to leave a review. This game, to me, has been a blast, base game is already enjoyable and fun as is, but modding and the subsequent dlcs have made this game outstanding. While it is not a game for everyone and I know I have played it in excess and I hope to get even more hours of the game. It is a game I can always come back to and pick right back up where I left off without issue. The hurdles and challenges this game can throw at you is outstanding and steep, even aggravating to the point you may wanna let out a groan of frustration or even cup your head in defeat but it makes those victories more outstanding. The storyteller, each in their own right, can just be as cutthroat and ruthless as the others, there is never a kind option and losing a colony WILL happen no matter how hard you try, but from those pits of despair coming rising out a golden throne of victory. 
Now as for the game, the base game is a great starter experience but can get stale, I understand with prices and things now a days that dlcs may be out of the question, but not to fear the modding community in this game is phenomenal! The only DLC I hard recommend is the Biotech, it adds so much to the game it is absolutely worth the price tag. Royalty is a solid 2nd, and if you like flavor or adding backstory to your colony Ideology is a 3rd. Especially if you plan on modding Biotech is a strong contender of needs for a lot of the more complex mods. Speaking of modding the best modders around are, Very much in my opinion, the Vanilla expanded guys, Oskar Potocki as well as Sarg Bjornson! Their mods add a lot to the base game that feels rather natural and have a lot of difficulty climbers as well as slice of life compliments that you will think "Why wasn't that already in the game!" They aren't the only mod makers out there and there a ton more to discover that I have yet to find! Also the graphics of this game are simple and pleasing to the eye so you can play this game for hours on end and suffer no eye strain whatsoever, as well as being a glorious time sink that you will lose track of time managing your colony that when you lean back you will be hungry and the sun will have set! Also as far I have seen and experienced this game is relatively on the low end of bugginess, only having encounter one base game bug that has crashed it out, otherwise any bugs tend to come from the modding end of things, which tends to happen.
Now for the dreaded bad end of it, this game is challenging to point it is unfair, I have spent a lot of time just trying to have a good run start only for it to be quickly be shut down just as fast as I started the game. Also as all games there are metas as to starts and what you should and shouldn't use, if you are like me ignore them they can ruin the experience and make things to easy or too strong at the start and skyrocket the difficulty curve unfairly. Lastly this game is not a longterm game in a run, it is hard to keep the game running smooth on a longterm game as well as the game itself starts to launch poorly the bigger your modlist gets, mine is currently up to a 5 minute launch which I typically have to relaunch it a 2nd time.
Overall I would say this game is an absolute 9/10, if they could fix atleast the launching issues? I would easily raise it to a 10/10 as that is the only thing that grinds my enjoyment of this game. Otherwise if you love strategy, the cruelty of life, having too little free time, or love seeing a colony grow prosper and then proceeding burn down in flames cause your best colonist decided to start lighting fires in your mountain base as everyone roasts like a thanksgiving turkey this game is for you!

Steam Deck Review Update:

This game needs some work for the steam deck. I was anticipating clocking many more hours on the deck while on a work break or traveling but was disappointed at how poorly optimized the controls are. Despite being verify for steam deck, on boot, I was greeted to a dysfunctional official control scheme that didn't have fundamental actions like right click working correctly. I went in to map them myself but only ran into more issues. I could not for the life of me get the right click to work properly. 

I don't think the verified status accurately give users an idea of what to expect when playing a game on the deck. I've tried most of my "great on deck" games and can say I've had mixed results with most of them. FNAF is another game that is verified but doesn't work the way you'd expect it to. 

If you're looking to get a steam deck for Rimworld I'd either reconsider or commit to also purchasing the dock to allow for keyboard and mouse. I haven't played enough on steam deck to review performance but I imagine it struggle when you get to the mid/late game. 

RIMWORLD Review:

Truly as addictive as crack cocaine. Not in a good or bad way but this game WILL steal your life from you and lock away in a closet like my parents did to me when I was younger. I can and will sit for extended hours of time playing. It's like so little happens but also so much when you're just monitoring your colony. All of sudden your 800 chinchillas have Malaria, you're being raided by beaver people that want to kidnap and eat your newborns, you make the mistake of taking on Thrumbos too early, a pack of cargo pods lands in the middle of your base with that desperately needed glitterworld medicine. The amount of unique scenarios and outcomes keeps me engaged and interested in what will happen next as I try to get to space.

  Larian studios continues work on and support Rimworld. Pumping out substantial DLC, just like how I pump the money out of my bank account to buy them, that perfectly compliments the core as well as the other additional downloadable content. There is a unique synergy between the community and devs where the players create mods for QOL stuff while the devs focus mainly on DLC and big picture stuff. Maybe QOL shouldn't be completely on the community but steam workshop mods are essential for most Rimworld players (or Rimmers as I call them) and I recommend using them to enhance your play-through. 

Rimworld is one of those games that I believe everyone should try but there are some flaws. I think if the devs invested in creating an in-depth tutorial at the start of the game more people would stick around. Most people I talk to that have tried Rimworld will tell you how it is tough in the beginning because of how minimal the tutorial is. It needs improvement. And while I do think the community engagement and collaboration is great, taking some time out to add  QOL adjustments to the core game instead of relying on the free labor of enthusiasts would benefit everyone, might be a hot take but whatever. 

I have tons of fun playing Rimworld and sometimes I take extended breaks from the game. Rimworld is life so, naturally, there are seasons. I am aware of ignorance when talking about game development and all that stuff, it is harder and more complicated than I can probably imagine, but this is a non-technical consumer review and just my opinion. I still recommend Rimworld 100% probably the closest to perfect a game can get. Give it a try, commit to learning, and I bet you'll have a great time not leaving your house for 6 months.

There‚Äôs a game that you can‚Äôt win, you can‚Äôt break even, and you can‚Äôt even get out. No, I am not talking about the laws of thermodynamics. I am talking about Rimworld. It‚Äôs a Pandora's box that I can‚Äôt get out of.
Sure, you can win the game, at a high cost of course. The charm of the game is tactically managing resources and human talents. On paper, it would make sense to allocate more resources to unskilled pawns with greedy or jealous traits who you are promoting with higher titles while ordering mentally stable pawns working overtime. Under this logic, a useless pawn would spend most of its time meditating in an 80 square throne room with lavish meal in its inventory while a large population lives in a 2X2 square single bed room and only allowed simple meals and herbal medicine. Needless to say, the peasant pawns would be assigned to melee attack in the front line while the precious titled pawns are standing in the safe zone and trying to make history.
But what if, I wonder, Wiking‚Äôs happiness theory and Bregman‚Äôs human kindness theory could work in this hush ‚Äúreality‚Äù (i.e., starve to survive in Randy)? Would a free, high quality healthcare system survive in this simulation game? How about democracy and a check-and-balances system? I decided to prioritize happiness (mood level) above technology progress and colony wealth as a social experiment. Yes, I know this is not a cutesy game like Stardew Valley or Animal Crossing. (I mean‚Ä¶ have you checked the Ideology DLS?) But I was just curious what if I only assign 6 hours of working hours with 3 hours of recreation hours so that they can spend them in extremely impressive recreation room; allow everyone - including guest refugees - glitter medicine; rather promoting one pawn to the highest title but spreading honors equally among 3 pawns according to how popular they are among the colonists?
Sure, in the end, it‚Äôs a happy and well-defend colony. But guess what, it‚Äôs Randy; you can‚Äôt break even. You can survive many raids, man/woman hunting packs, and mech clusters, but colonists would still suffer from the inevitable curse of aging (‚ÄúBirthday: bad back/ dementia‚Äù) and heartbreaks. Everyone is happy? Great! But you still can‚Äôt prevent love rejections, affairs, and divorces among the colonists. And yes, the Royal DLS added many new technologies to fix these problems, even a serum to revive a dead colonist. But at what cost? Sooner or later, something bigger - from external or internal factors- will rise. The only existing is pack up and leave this colony that you have spent hours to build.
Then why am I still playing it? Because I can‚Äôt get out of this Pandora‚Äôs box.edit
