I bought this game years ago due to the hype at the time thinking it would be just another classic city building game. Boy, was I wrong. Rimworld offers so much more than the traditional city building genre. There is so much detail put into every character, building, enemy, etc. There is always something new and challenging to overcome every time I play. Characters have their own backstories, factions dynamically change depending on various factors, animals and wildlife can dramatically alter how your base functions, and so much more.

If you are looking for a game where you can develop characters, build and operate a base, interact with the world and environment in unique and complex ways, all inside a dynamically and changing atmosphere, Rimworld has got you covered.

After many years of playing this game, I must say that it's the Best Game of All Time, for me.

This is my review. I fully recommend this game to pretty much everyone, but before you go into it, you have to know some deterrents.
Pros:
1. If you have the right mindset, this game can be enjoyable for hundreds of hours
2. Very in-depth social system and an actual combat system
3. Friendly Modding Community
Cons:
1. Some people dislike the RNG of the game, because they could defeat a raid and get a disease on everyone of their colonists.
2. Some people don't want to commit hours and hours to complete one game entirely
3. After watching modded series, some people don't want to go through the "hassle" of buying royalty and installing all 1 million mods the person had
I still highly recommend Rimworld to the people of Steam

Second game I've spent ~1000h in and honestly was it worth it? Sorta.
Rimworld is a good story and colony sim game. It's definitely for the more patient ones out there who like to go through the long grind and development to reach results which eventually mount to nothing. You know there are no achievements or anything you get at the end of it. It's like reading a book and all of the content you wanted wasn't in the last page but the book as a whole. There are moments of struggle and happiness for your little pawns and it's all interesting to watch play out.

Despite all that, there's some problems here. While the game does infact give you unique ways of going through the story, really there is only a few ways it can go. There's not as many actually diverging paths unless you download the two 20$ DLCs, each giving 1 more. Ideology is a bit more flexible though which is an improvement. The DLCs feel like they should be base game. A lot of the active players of this game didn't actually buy rimworld for the vanilla content but for the active modding community who keep the game alive and are ready to bring you more content than what Tynan Sylvester can provide. I could forgive this if the game wasn't as big but in recent times it's seen a surge of hundreds of thousands of buyers. Instead of spending 20 for Tynan, you could just get similar content from hard working and honestly heavyhearted modders for free (or you can just pay them instead to keep them going), modders who should be hired to work at Ludeon to help out bettering the game in terms of content and performance and given a paycheck. Would allow for expansion and a better game but maybe Tynan just doesn't want Ludeon to be like that. Maybe I'm being too greedy here but then is Tynan not for asking 20 for the rim of magic mod? Also the full game costs about 100$ to buy now for newcomers so there's that.

In conclusion: It's ok. Buy it, play it and gas your enemies with none other than the vanilla furniture expanded power module MOD.

I'd say RimWorld is amazing. 

There's a lot of things that you can do to your colony. You create your own story, you can choose a scenario as Crashlanded, Tribal, or Merchant. And then you settle and manage your colony. There's lot of event going on, sometime you have raid which will scale with your wealth, sometime a trading caravan pass by, etc. If you love micromanagement, you can set schedule, task, specific assignment, or rules for clothing on your colony.

The music is great, you can enjoy playing while listening to it. The vibe it gives more like a country cowboy music, although not all the genre are country especially on main menu where it has ambient vibes music.

Just buy it!

Probably gonna get chewed out for saying this but it's rather expensive. There are a lot of things you can do, and a great modding community, but the game has a sort of false depth. It's like they have provided us a lot of tools, and its fun to use them while you are still figuring out as you wonder the extent of possibilities. But soon as you figure out the mechanics, you realize that its actually very simple. And while understanding the mechanics and triggers are essential part of arcade games, it's counterintuitive for simulations. It makes it very difficult to maintain the suspension of disbelief and the game quickly loses its allure(at least for me). I understand that simple mechanics are part of this game's design philosophy and as a result the game holds very well mechanically. However, I feel that if you wanna create a simple game, keep it at a simple price. 

Some notes for players that are coming here after seeing hyped up videos from youtube:
* The notes on paintings are randomly generated, and while they do have your character's name the context rarely make sense unless you really force yourself to make sense of it.
* The pawns have relationships in the sense that they either really like or hate each other and begin fights when they have too much mood debuff. They don't actually 'talk' to each other. Just randomly generated logs ("talked about politics/dogs") if they are in the vicinity.
* The pawns have traits like neurotic or pyro or beautiful. They affect either their skills or social standing. They don't have a personality as such. And traits are just a representation of what work they are good at (shooting, cooking), some of which they are better at learning.  
* You can do a Warcrime playthrough. But the only effect in game you will notice is that your pawns and other colonists will have a mood debuff. It just another Wednesday in the Wild West.
* And the other colonies are pretty much non-existent. They don't really interact with each other or have an influence on the world. They are just.. filler.

If the price was half of what it is, I'd highly recommend it. But this price seems to be for what the game appears to be and not what it actually is. If you have great imagination or need some inspiration for worldbuilding or not worried about the price, go for it. (Really, its good). Otherwise depending on what you are looking for, there might be other games that are better. Hell during sale you can get entire Fallout 4 for cheaper. Subnautica if you want exploration-survival, Frostpunk if you want colony, Surviving Mars if you love Tech Trees. 
I also need to add that, there is this growing popularity of a new metric of measurement where people see the 'hours of entertainment a game provides'. And honestly that's not a good metric. Spending 3 hrs playing Rimworld is not the same as spending 3 hrs watching Dune/Oppenheimer or swimming in a rented pool or watching TV. And on the same note 40 hours playing a beautiful linear story is worth much more than 100 spent in something like counter strike. People please stop encouraging this metric. I know we need to 'support the devs' but this is  not the way. There is a growing trend of newer indie games being priced like AA games.  When the best thing about indie games apart from their innovation was their reasonable cost.

This game is an amazing story-generator.

Play though an epic (or not so epic) story of your dreams (or your nighmares... noone is judging you here ;p )
Be that a story about frontier ranchers in a space-western or that of a a lonely hermit at the polar cap eating the raw flesh of his fellow man for survival.

See your colony prosper from a tribal society that eventually develops interstellar space travel or see your bustling merchant empire crumple to the ground by an ill-timed ravaging horde of rabid ...chickens?!

At its core, Rimworld is about building and survival on a world in the outer rim, but it need not stop there, with an active modding community encouraged by the devs (some devs even being modders) the possibilities are near limit-less. From playing in a pre-industrial world, a fantasy world with elves and magic to interdimentional space travelers facing lovecraftian horrors.

I really recommend this game. It is so enjoyable and relaxing that my smart watch thinks I'm asleep while playing.

1190 hours, and that was all after I bought the official release, My actual time in the game is closer to double what's displayed on my profile, and you want to know what it has taught me?
This developer absolutely HATES the people who mod his game for free. He's never stated this, but his actions with the development of his game seem to differ...
I remember playing this game when it was still in early access, and being infinitely irritated every time a new update came out. Now why would I be mad about updates? Because for people who mod this game, and I'm one of the many who finds this game unplayable without mods, each update breaks every single mod you have installed, because the mods are rendered functionless until the author updates them to the current build. This acted like a sifter, each updates filtering out more and more flavor mods, because the author assumingly got frustrated and abandoned the mod.
When the 1.0 stable build came out, it was a golden age for modding.... Every mod was now perpetually valid as long as it didn't conflict with others you had running. Finally you could reliably run your favorite, personally flavored heavy-mod builds and invest untold hours into them knowing the game will finally have the depth that its potential allows. No more miles-wide ocean that only goes skin-deep (the problem that invariably plagues vanilla rimworld).... This was when I loved the game.
Then Tynan released the Royalty DLC.... This brought an end to the golden age of modding, ruined all my saves where I had invested countless hours into nurturing that stupid little colony through every hardship the game could throw at me. I was pissed enough to drop the game for the mean-time.
Years later I come back thinking it should now be on a stable build with biotech having been released months ago (how many more DLC's can Tynan really fart out? This isn't Paradox Interactive.... right?) Now a week later after getting a good mod list together and giving the game another go.... Ludeon releases ANOTHER piddly little update adding almost nothing to the game, and it breaks all of my saves and my entire mod list. Now it refuses to load my earlier saved mod-list, and keeps all of my 88 or so mods in a constant state of "now downloading"...
I believe I've found the fix through a pinned discussion link, but after dropping $25 on that damned Biotech DLC, I have absolutely no desire to spend another 2-4 hours just trying to resurrect my saves when Ludeon will just break them all again a month or 2 from now when they release the next piddling update.
Ludeon/Tynan, you are ruining your games by actively discouraging the mod base... the only actual life and soul behind the game you created... This game won't be truly great until you get out of the way and stop breaking it every 1-2 months.

11/23 edit: Waited almost a year, and came back to the game. The mods were still in "downloading" limbo. I wiped my mod list. went back and picked out the ones i wanted to try again, and re-subscribed/downloaded them.... after starting up, surprise-surprise! all the newly downloaded mods are still exhibiting the downloading issue.... Been almost a year, another year Ludeon continued to sell game copies and release updates for, but fixing a known problem(one that the playerbase figured a workaround for) is still an apparent non-priority to the dev team.

Simply put, YES. Rimworld is a game that will make you cry out in anger, fall in love with your little colony, planet wide racially motivated genocide, and more!

You can me a farmer, have a simple life with animals and 3 colonists with basic defenses. You can sell weapons for profit, but this will increase your wealth too quickly and your labrador retriever could die. You could be so pissed you spend the next 2 in game years gearing up, and preparing a tactical army to eradicate the inferior Hostile Outlander Faction that removed your dog from this world. You can be responsible for the deaths of hundreds that died because of your mindless crusade to avenge something that can't be brought back....

You can harvest, torture, brainwash your prisoners, or simply sell them to slavery :D

All jokes aside, Rimworld is an extremely immersive game that can be addicting for some. The simple art style can get you hooked without a strain on your eyes, the chill soundtrack and completely random events like man-hunting yorkshire terriers, an aurora lighting the night sky, a stranger flying on your territory from an escape pod, an infamous event known as a "Zzzzt" exploding stuff it shouldn't have... They had to put a clock telling you the real world time in the in game UI. I love rimworld.

All this without even mentioning mod support. There is an insane modding community modding in from some silly items to game changing mechanics. And it's not hard to learn to do it yourself! At least that's what the pros are saying.

RimWorld is an absolute gem in the world of colony simulation games. From crash-landing on an unknown planet to thriving colonies, the journey is nothing short of exhilarating. The depth of gameplay, unique colonist interactions, and the unpredictable AI Storyteller make every playthrough a fresh adventure. With a supportive modding community and a charming minimalist style, RimWorld is a must-play for strategy enthusiasts seeking a rewarding and endlessly replayable experience

RimWorld is one of those games that I keep coming back to again and again year after year. It's so good that even though I pirated it I still bought it just to support the devs and their amazing work. The modding community for this game is dedicated and extremely thoroughly with coming up with almost every idea you could possibly want. 

From a gameplay perspective it is not a game with a set story or something that will really teach you what to do. You just have to sort of figure it out. You will probably lose your first two or three or dozen colonies but each one will teach you something that you can take with you to your next game. No two games will ever be the same and that feels amazing. The devs keep releasing new updates and new DLC that add lots to the game even if you don't own the DLC.

Edit 2023: Even this many years later I still really thoroughly enjoy this game. I've gotten so much deeper into the modding scene since my original review and it just still feels fresh each and every time I play.

Rimworld is a colony building with an AI generated 'story' telling. Said story requires a bit of creative interpretation though - it is mainly the events and random actions happing in your colony that make up the 'story'. That said, this game is great for roleplaying a certain type of colony. Do you want to play a group of shipwrecked spacers, setting up a temporary bases and traveling the planet in search of salvation? Or maybe you'd like to try a cannibalist tribe which sells slaves and harvests the organ of captured enemies to sell them for profit? Perhaps you'd prefer a medieval society in which psi-powers are created for your highest ranking nobles? Everything is possible in this sandbox!

Rimworld has continued to carry the Colony Sim genre to a broader and more diverse audience in comparison to its counterpart that, whilst more complex and wider in scope, is limited by many of its complexities and its simple graphical presentation. With other colony sims beginning to pop up more and more, it will be interesting to see how Rimworld adapts to stay relevant; but with continued DLC support and updates, not to mention dedicated modding scene, its hard to see this game become irrelevant well into its 10th, let alone its 15th or even 20th, anniversary.

Truly a labour of love for a genre sorely in need of more of it.

RimWorld is a unique blend of survival, simulation, and strategy game that offers an immersive gaming experience. You establish a colony on a remote planet, which provides a sense of adventure and exploration. The game is driven by an intelligent AI storyteller, which ensures that no two playthroughs are the same, adding a layer of unpredictability and excitement.

What makes RimWorld truly fun is its deep mechanics. You can build structures, benches, weapons, and more, which gives a sense of accomplishment and progression. The game also has a complex social system, where your colonists interact with each other, forming relationships, rivalries, and even getting into fights. This adds a layer of depth and realism to the game, making your colonists feel more like real people than just game characters.

RimWorld is built on failure, where the unexpected is the norm, and every decision can lead to dramatic consequences. This creates a sense of tension and urgency, making every decision matter and every victory feel earned. The game‚Äôs difficulty can be adjusted to suit your playstyle, ensuring that it remains challenging and engaging no matter your skill level.

Overall, RimWorld offers a unique, engaging, and fun gaming experience that is a must-play for fans of strategy, simulation, or survival games. Its rich mechanics, dynamic storytelling, and deep social system make it a game that you can play for hours on end, always discovering something new and exciting.

Among the almost two-thousand hours I have in this game over the past almost seven years, I can safely say that the game is an awesome colony builder and storytelling game. You'll go through times where you'll get bored of it, surely, then come back for more. Your colony and map is randomly generated and it'll never be the same, since you can practically terraform with the amount of construction and farming you can do as you reach later into the game. If you have a good enough PC, you can practically build a sprawling city that consumes the entirety of the map - if you want to.

A good chunk of the community play it as a strategy game, but it's truly a sandbox where you'll get the most out of it by trying to tell a genuine story (in my opinion) through your colony: whether it's cannibal super-humans, or isolationist cattle ranchers.

I got it way back when, and it was only around $25 USD, but even at it's price today, I'd still get it - it's my most played game on Steam. The DLCs are a bit pricey for their content, but I've got enough out of the game to be okay with supporting the development team.

Rimworld stands out as a top-tier colony simulation, blending storytelling, unpredictability, and depth seamlessly. The game's unique colonists, each with diverse backgrounds and traits, craft dynamic narratives, guided by an AI storyteller that ensures every play-through feels fresh. Meticulous pixel art, intricate systems, and an active modding community enhance the rich game-play experience. With a balanced difficulty curve, comprehensive tutorials, and limitless re-playability, Rimworld sets a commendable standard in the indie game development realm. Explaining Rimworld and its name in public can be amusing, often eliciting humorous reactions and curious glances due to the unexpected title and game content.

- Commit countless warcrimes
- Eat your foes
- Get malaria
- Mow down hordes of tribal savages with fully automatic weapons and mortars
- Lose your entire colony to insects
- Mod your game beyond recognition

All was well during a quiet summer day. Clorox was hauling the hay to the barn while Spoon worked tirelessly scrubbing the floors. Boxtruck came in after a long day of hunting. But then there is Steve. Our doctor. Our ONLY doctor. The smartest one in the village. Not a single person in this entire village has more than a skill of 2 in doctoring. Except Steve. And he goes to sleep in the freezer and dies. Clorox gets depressed and stops feeding the animals. It's a mess. 
I had another play through going on a separate save. Had a good doctor there too. Accidentally had him anesthetize himself before doing a surgery to install a bionic eye. 
10/10 would recommend.

Ever wanted to run a colony of cannibal nudists that form life long psychic connections to each other? I did! It went amazing! Randy on Losing is Fun took 30 full days to send a raid... why? Not a clue! 

That got me thinking, what about trying a mechinator sanguaphage! That would be totally crazy, and if I editted his gene structure so he was godly, that could be a fun mini-playthrough just for some downtime... a meteorite blew his head off the second day...

I normally rocked the usual, tame colony... but there is so much more here, and playing around with biotech is probably the optimal way to reach it! Can't wait to make a colony of ranchers that're stuck in a permanently polluted world, because why not?! Tribal transhumanists? Sea-ice with someone intolerant to the cold? Pacifist Hussars? An army of pyrophobic imps? No, no probably not that one... but a colony of coagulating, super healers who's genes were also "written in comic sans" (they grow tumors on the regular!)? Hell ya!

And between it all... softer bridges of 20-30 hour tame colonies, your standard Rimworld experience, because honestly that's always been my favorite! :>

Steam, you're wonderful... it just took a while to convince me to buy this game, but owning it feels amazing, and the diversity is absolutely endless!

I've... seen things you people wouldn't believe. Colonists on fire during a tantrum caused by a dirty dining room floor. I watched Engie, a glitterworld surgeon, sever a head while attempting to attach an artificial leg. I saw a legendary marksman, a veteran of dozens of firefights, accidentally shoot her beloved pet cobra through the brain while fighting off a pack of man-eating wargs, then go berserk and murder her fellow colonists out of grief. I've seen entire raiding parties obliterated by unspeakable, ancient evils unearthed from long-forgotten tombs. I've seen colonists harvest the organs of their prisoners, and when that doomed prisoner's noseless, earless, armless, legless, lungless, heartless corpse finally grew cold, it was skinned to make a cowboy hat.

All those moments... make this game truly remarkable. 

Time... to do it all again.

What is a game?

Rimworld takes the crown in helping buck the trends set by the gaming community, and even within it's own genre. What Dwarf Fortress started, Rimworld brought to the masses. 

Becoming attached to a save game, losing that one colonist that means a bit...too much to you, finally taming a wild person outside your base. 

Rimworld provides every avenue for you to explore and observe. You are in control, but not for everything, and you learn to let that desire for control go. Sometimes losing will lead you to the next game where you have an even better time. 

If you want to learn to let go, play this game, and enjoy the ride.

A game 5 years in the making, but it was a finished game long before full release. I've played for over 200 hours, and I just keep coming back. The longer you play with a colony, the more attached you get to the little peeps you're watching over. You get invested in each and every one of them, and can even get a little emotional if you lose one. The weird and wonderful ways you can advance your colony, and even the weirder ways they can be lost, are wide-ranging and, sometimes, hilarious. (I lost one colony in the first week when they were attacked by a man-hunting raccoon. Just one. It's that weird!) I would most definitely recommend this game as something to get lost in. But don't play it when you've got work or an appointment to go to, I guarantee you'll be late!

I had one of my pawns got his head shot off in his first combat encounter. 10/10 would watch my pawn's head get blown off again.

While it's graphics and art style may not be mind blowing in this day and age there's nothing quite like Rimworld. It can be a challenging game, even on some of the cosier modes, but the level of variety and freedom you have in the game to mix up various playthroughs make it so much fun. Want to play a bunch of tree hugging people who abhor violence? Go ahead. Want to play some blind mole people who are cannibals? Go ahead. On one playthrough one of my colonists had Asthma, so when I got attacked by raiders I captured a couple and took a good lung from each of them to transplant into my colonist and no more Asthma. I gave the Raiders the bad lungs and then sent them on their way as a message for their group.

All in all it's a well designed game with plenty to keep you occupied for hours and hours every playthrough, for a fraction of the cost of any AAA game these days, and thats not even counting the fact you can toss mods into the mix to change it up to the extreme.

RimWorld is a game where survival is a comedy of errors teetering on the edge of brilliance!

It's a [b]chaos management simulator[/b] where your colony could be a perfect community... [i]but more likely, it turns into a circus of absurd situations and characters whose lives are immersed in surrealism.[/i]

On your path to success, you'll grapple with serious problems like survival struggles, managing characters' emotions, and fires erupting in the bathroom at the most inconvenient times.

From heartwarming moments of solidarity to absurd situations like your psychopathic scientist deciding to adopt a pet giraffe, RimWorld keeps you on the brink of laughter and madness.

This is the first game I have clocked 100+ hours into within a month of owning it. Replayability is insane, modding community (and workshop too) is amazing, and it‚Äôs super lightweight. It‚Äôs one of like 3 games I can reliably play on my laptop when I‚Äôm out of town. It‚Äôs also full of insurmountable and irreversible bs that makes me want to stop playing, but it‚Äôs still so easy to come back to and start over.

The music is incredible, the DLC is amazing, and the amount of personalization (whether in or out of your control) is phenomenal. Each character in your ‚Äústory‚Äù is someone to get attached to, you can become immersed in their day to day lives, feel excited when they find love, dread when they die, etc. 

I will say that the price does run a bit high even on sale, but given its reputation and the mileage I have gotten from it, it‚Äôs not really a complaint of mine. I do wish that the game had native multiplayer support, since it currently relies on mods for that.

the base game is fine, it's good, but it has one of the biggest and best modding scenes i've seen. 

a lot of it, especially the "vanilla expanded" series of mods fit into it so well that i'm not even sure what content is vanilla and what is modded anymore.

do you want more content for lower tech-levels so you could do a medieval or bronze-age playthrough? do you want to ride animals and have mounted combat? get actual vehicles like tanks and planes? genetically engineer a cat with a human face? turn someone [i]into[/i] a cat?? take off with a spaceship and have ship to ship combat??? survive a zombie apocalypse????

there are mods for all of those things.

i don't want to belittle the vanilla experience, but given the sheer amount of modded content available, including a lot that fits into vanilla seamlessly, i cant imagine playing vanilla anymore.

This is a story of a man named Ol' Gunshot.
Ol' Gunshot worked on a rimworld after being conned out of all his money for a surgery he desperately wanted.
Ol' Gunshot's job was simple.
He sat indoors all day in a catatonic state from 9 to 5 every single day.
Orders were given to him from above, telling him which trees to cut, which switches to flick, how long until releasing prisoners, and the order in which they were queued. None of which were met, as Ol' Gunshot was catatonic.
This is what Ol' Gunshot did every day, of every month, of every year.
And although others might have considered him worthless, Ol' Gunshot enjoyed every second of his ever-expanding queue, as he wasted away in bed.
And Ol' Gunshot was happy.

RimWorld, the game that makes you feel like an intergalactic kindergarten teacher. Look forward to managing seemingly harmless survivors who suddenly decide that food is scarce, and it's time to devour their own grandmother. Amidst this chaos, navigating the steep learning curve becomes a true delight, especially if you relish triggering an epic catastrophe with every minor mistake. Where the death of your colonists is as foreseeable as the end of a bad reality show. But hey, at least you'll have a story to tell in the end - if you survive the tragedy and live to share your interstellar misadventures.

This review is submitted for the ‚ÄúSteam Awards 2023‚Äù and it presents my evaluation of the game:

1. Game-play:
1.1. General description: The game begins with the selection of an ideology (which may require a separate DLC), some pawns (for which genetic modifications may necessitate an additional DLC), and a map to inhabit. You'll be also presented with the option to edit the starting scenario and enable or disable some extra challenging features.
1.2. Map generation: This is a very pleasant experience. The game requires constant thinking of new and original strategies to establish the defences and the maps are always varied except for the enemies‚Äô settlements. However, there is no special reward for annihilating the enemies apart from any potential map loot. I would also appreciate if the maps and roads had more significance. For instance, one could create the initial settlement in a remote location but the enemies would still manage to locate it.
1.3. Pawns: The resemblance between pawns and real life humans in decision making are uncanny and well-thought. I have played the game for 400 hours and it still manages to astonish me. Each pawn has its own personality. However, I would greatly appreciate an improvement in path finding. Occasionally, when I instruct a pawn to escape from a furious elephant, the pawn chooses to follow a zigzag path rather than a straight one, thus being killed by the aforementioned predatory animal.
1.4 Ideology: Instead of reviewing the DLC itself, I will express my opinion on how this DLC integrates with the game itself. Ideology provides some additional benefits such as making all your pawns ‚Äúnight-owls‚Äù but many of these traits are overridden by the game‚Äôs core mechanics. For instance, when choosing an ideology that makes your pawns prefer the night and darkness, they still opt to travel at daytime between settlements, which is very frustrating. Moreover, you are trying to create a story about ‚Äúthe only survivors of a great empire‚Äù and suddenly ‚Äúaunt Mary with the same ideology as your pawns‚Äù enters the map and spoils everything you have envisioned about the significance of your ideology.
1.5 Genetics: Similar to the ‚Äúideology DLC‚Äù, I would have appreciated the opportunity to share my opinion on how this DLC interacts with the game; However, due to my limited playtime with it, I am not competent to comment on it.
1.6 Other minor issues or suggestions:
1.6.1 Electricity and power: I would welcome a quick method to dismantle only the power lines and not the entire base. Moreover, the short circuit event should be avoidable by research or improved power lines or at least have a valid explanation to occur.
1.6.2 More defensive options: The existing in-game official methods of protecting the base are inadequate. It is illogical that one can construct a spaceship but cannot equip a turret with a mini-gun.
1.6.3 Research: As an experienced gamer, I am dissatisfied with the impact of the ‚Äútribal faction‚Äù on the research speed.
1.6.4 Limit on the number of pawns: I would aspire to have an empire with a sizable army but I can only sustain a colony with 25 pawns before the game gets angry and throw everything it can to destroy me.
1.6.5 Multi-player: I would greatly desire an official mode to enable a co-op multiplayer. My brother and I occasionally play this game in mirrored (identical map and pawns and everything) to compare our progress. Therefore, if there was an official mode that allowed us to have factions on the same map and to interact or compete with each other, I would gladly purchase the full DLCs and game for him as well.

2. Story: The game features a generative story-telling with various patterns that one can select. However, this generative story-telling is unlike anything one has experienced in other games and it often surprises and entertains.

3. Graphics: I love the simplified and minimalistic look of this game.

4. Sound: I love the existing soundtrack, especially the track titled ‚ÄúFealty‚Äù.

5. Value: The game is worth every penny for its endless entertainment and enjoyment. The developer clearly invested his love and passion into this game and merits what he is requesting for it. However, because the regional situation I am currently in, I cannot afford to purchase DLCs for my brother & I believe this is a regional economical situation that many of my friends are troubled with. I love this game and respect the developer too much hence I would not resort to any shortcuts to obtain a copy however I hope the developer can reduce the price a bit.

Some more defined metrics:

*Game play*: The game has an impressive and vast amount of characters to make, locations, scenarios, difficulties, objectives, etc. You can even create specific scenarios. The DLC adds even more content and expansions for a game that already has hundreds of hours of playability. Years of support and care by the dev!

*Running and Mods*: The game runs well, I haven't encountered any noticeable bugs throughout my play through so far. The mod support is amazing, from in depth things like psychology to war crime meme mods-the community has it all. 

*Tutorials and Guide*: The game is fairly easy for an entirely new players to pick up in a couple of hours with tool tips, a wiki, and a forum. There's also a baseline tutorial.

Overall, it's one of my favorite games and I highly recommend it.

I have logged many, many hours. I have lost many pawns. Gained others. I have spread my people across stars, across unknown futures, and even spread their ashes among my farmland. I've had many worshipers of my religions, and many haters. I have lost life and limb for the defense of my lands. Seen children grow, get old, and die before my very eyes. I have watched man become one with machine. I have seen many settlements rise and fall. I have chuckled as empires crumbled beneath my armored feet. Metal and flesh have clashed in my recent past, a display of humanity versus the march of technology. 

This is a fraction of RimWorld. My small slice of the proverbial pie that is this game and its boundless enjoyment. When I got this game, I expected nothing more than to play a few hours and then refund. But... here I am, 2K hours later. This game has been my favorite, nay, my chosen game. I have had many hours of enjoyment with this game, and I plan on having many, many more.

This game has given me many stories to tell, and it will continue doing so for the pleasantly foreseeable future.

A complex game with an interesting learning curve. you can attempt to create a Utopia or authoritarian, anarchist, or cannibalistic hell within your colony; the journey there can be a leisurely stroll or a no-holds-barred, blood-sweat-and-tears struggle against the forces of either destiny or chaos. With 3 DLC that add options to design your colony members' very morals, or to unlock psychic powers, or mutants of many kinds - to include space vampires - Rimworld is quite the fleshed-out game suitable for the deranged sort of people that would remove the ladder from the pool in Sims games.

Much like that scene from Spongebob where Squidward is building a snow fort, Rimworld is one of those games where there's perpetually "just one more thing to do before bed" and then it's 7:00 AM and your alarm is going off.  You start a game with some number of colonists, and the goal is just to survive.  There are a number of "win" conditions, but my suggestion is to just ignore them, the real game is satisfying your hierarchy of needs.  Do your colonists have food and shelter from the elements?  Do they have barricades and guns for the approaching raiders and dangerous animals?  Are you going to play match-maker and set their work schedules to promote friendships and romance?  If you choose to role-play, you can even go so far as to project self-esteem and respectability on to your colonists, which brings us to Rimworld's selling point:  Rimworld is more of a story generator than a "game."  There are conditions you can meet to get the screen to fade to black and roll credits, but you don't play Rimworld to get to the end, you play the game to watch and influence your colonists' stories as they unfold.  I once had a colony that was starving; I hadn't grown enough crops and had already hunted all the animals on the map - all of the animals except for a small group of rhinos off in the corner.  So I took four colonists armed with bows and arrows and left the one pacifist colonist back at the base.  The hunting expedition went wrong almost immediately; my colonists opened fire on one of the rhinos and instead of fleeing, it got enraged and charged my colonists.  This also set off the two nearby rhinos, so I had three rhinos bearing down on four of my colonists who were pretty much just throwing sharp sticks at the beasts.  The rhinos dropped my first colonist pretty much immediately.  I had two colonists pelt the beasts while my fourth and last able-bodied colonist fell back to put some distance between them, but it was no use.  The two colonists went down almost as quickly as the first guy and the fourth colonist could not output enough damage or run fast enough to escape the animals.  In just a matter of in-game minutes, I had four colonists laying on the ground, gored by a trio of frothing mad rhinos who were now rampaging around and banging on the doors of my base while my fifth and final asthmatic, sickly, pacifist pawn cowered inside.

"Welp, that does it." I said to myself, as I hit the button to speed up time in the game, so the rhinos would hurry up, break through the doors, and kill my final colonist (I wasn't going to send her outside to her death; I'm not a monster), but then, the banging stopped.  I looked at the unconscious rhino laying at the front door, bleeding out all over the welcome mat, then at the two other rhinos, who were now raging on the opposite side of the base, limping from injuries and blood loss.  I looked at my asthmatic colonist and then at her friends downed on the other side of the map, rapidly fading from this world.  It's funny how attached you can become to these little limbless potatoes, I thought to myself, as I held my breath, praying the other two rhinos wouldn't follow as I sent my last pawn to try and save her friends.

Everyone made it out alive.  Some may have been missing bits and pieces, but everyone was alive, and from that point on, I had a colony of rhino hunters.  I found better weaponry and used smarter tactics, but every rhino that wandered onto that map knew swift and unwavering justice.

And that's just one aspect of story that can naturally emerge from gameplay if you're willing to use a bit of imagination.  All-in-all, Rimworld is a simply fantastic and incredibly compelling game.

[b]Score:[/b] 9/10 | [b]With DLC:[/b]  9/10
[b]Pros:[/b] Sim like with decent management options to get one started. The best way to label the game is a story simulator, as you react to situations thrown at your colony over and over. Gameplay works akin to an RTS, but it is more sims than anything else, so don't go expecting like warcraft. The simple visuals prevent the potential gore filled events and scenarios from being too real, so you can get invested without feeling like it gets too much. 
[b]Cons:[/b] There will be times where nothing happens, which is part of life, but can be boring. It can be tempting to reload a save when your favorite colonist is wounded or dies, but don't do it, your overall colony's narrative will be better. You can often find yourself down hours out of no where despite nothing happening as well as you become invested in your digital people.
[b]Recommend to:[/b] Fans of sim games, slow paced management games, and those who enjoy watching systems work and fight each other in interesting ways.
Overall: You can make sofas out of human leather. lol.

Old Review: 

If you like simulators and story generators, then you'll love this one. It's one of the best.

Gameplay:
Traditional management styled gameplay. Tell units through priority systems what the should do. The more people you get on your colony, the more complex it gets. It's simple gameplay, but the stories that can get generated from it is what makes it. Doing well building your farm? Bam, suddenly a raid and your best farmer gets shot and loses and arm, and you get your scientist working to get mechanical limbs researched so you can get him working again. You basically create a new breathing world each time. Looks up comics and stories on rimworld to see how awesome these can get.

Graphics:
I like the drawn style, but I can see why others may not. It works for the game.

Overall, it's great for those who just want to chill and watch something grow. Don't expect gameplay to be the immersive aspect, but how it all comes together that does it.

Seriously, get this game. Apart from the many heart-wrenching stories that could be told, there are also the funniest things you'd get the pleasure of witnessing. A tortoise taking down an entire colony? Check. Someone fleeing manhunting yorkshire terriers? Check. A person flipping out because they ate on the floor? All too common. Raiders wandering straight into an insect hive? We've got that too. Aside from that, RimWorld's prolific modding community allows almost anything to be possible. Want to be neolithic-only? Want to make stuff out of thin air? Want to zap your foes with magic? Want to satisfy humanity's... ahem... baser urges? There are mods for that! 

Aside from those, RimWorld has a ton of possibilities for your inner sadist; you can eat human meat, create hats out of human skin, inflict all manner of war-crimes upon your foes, harvest the organs of everyone and their mothers... it's so prevalent that some fans have created a checklist to break as many rules of the Geneva Convention as possible! Of course, there's still in-game punishment - people won't like it if they eat human meat without being cannibals, for example.

The DLCs add so much flavour to the game as well, tying in nicely with the many mods.

No matter your playstyle, whether you want to sing Kumbaya and release every raider you capture, or whether you'd rather make authoritarian leaders look like Boy Scouts, whether you like a challenge or to chill, the desert or the snow, a colony that's closely-knit or one where every pawn's family tree is a ladder, there's something for you.

EDIT: Biotech and Ideology add new ways to play - with these addons you can make that cannibal catgirl colony you wanted, or make literal PETA in rimworld, or make stoner moles, or...
TL;DR - Buy it. Seriously.

Overall score 10/10

Game play: Pace depends on the settings you choose. Game is easy to pick up with lots of nuance that makes each colony unique from every other colony. Good for hours of entertainment. The story of the game is what you make of it. 10/10

Controls and UI: Very easy to understand and pick up though with all the information on screen it can be a bit overwhelming at first. But the games built in help function (which you can turn on and off depending on what you want at any point in the game) really helps you when your first starting your first colony. The UI is very well organized and the controls are very simple and easy to use. 10/10

My hours alone should express how good this game is. There are definitely a lot of nuances to getting a hang of the mechanics of Rimworld, the UI for sure. It isn't Dwarf Fortress levels of Excel Spreadsheets, but larger colonies can get pretty close. The story generation, the pawns, the drama, it's all great.

Vanilla, this game is a gem, with mods, a national treasure. If any mods are ones I'd recommend, it's all the Vanilla Expanded ones. The devs and mod authors have worked together on multiple occasions so I basically consider it cannon.

Regardless, if it isn't for you, it's a niche title for sure. But if this game gets its claws into you, pray Randy will be gentle.

There are some games that are incredible from release. Others get better or even good with DLC. Others are saved and elevated to perfection by mods. RImworld is a mixture of all three: already good in its base, with really good expansions(one wrongly named, but whatever), and that gets even better with mods.

And still, it doesn't matter how you change the game, it still is a incredible story creator. I still remember my first colony, that was going well, but lost many members, got slow and boring. Or when one of the man in black came, being a thunder mage or something, and destroyed a elemental raid. And i will never forget the histories i saw in youtube, with Joris, Icewolf, Void and many other characters.

I still don¬¥t have all the thousant of time some people put in this game(it is difficult to play a game for thousants of hours when you put enough mods to overheat you bad gamer laptop), but i don't need one hour to feel conected to the colony, and to love the experience

Thank you to everyone involved. Just keep doing great content.

Decided I'd make my friends live through hell in this simulated apocalypse.
My only black friend follows horror movie trends and dies first to a stray grenade about 3 weeks in in the fifth raid.
My rocker friend takes this hit pretty badly and gets shook up something fierce.
In the very next raid we capture a guy very similar to my dead friend and he joins us after a week of feeding him nice meals.
Rocker Friend enjoys the company and tries to replace his lost love, but ultimately still notices something missing.
His mental state deteriorates faster than we can keep up, no amount of sprucing up his room, nor does Replacement getting chummy is fixing it; but they both help a bit.
The next raid sees another friend lobotomise Replacement with a chain shotgun; he fires into the fray right as Replacement darts in to get a quick shivving on a raider named Lamp.
He dies instantly, and the death cripples Rocker Friend.
The stress is too much now and Rocker Friend has a minor mental break.
Rocker Friend traipses over to the graveyard and digs up Black Friend to console himself - and promptly eats him.
The fact Rocker Friend has seen not just a corpse, but the corpse of a good friend (twice), and feels terrible about becoming a newly recognised cannibal instantly destroys the remnants of his mind.
Rocker Friend enters into a major mental break and roams the halls, unnervingly quiet, until he dies of starvation.

10/10 would cause my friends to become cannibals and die agonising deaths again

An amazing game that I've consistently gone back to over and over again for the last several years that I've owned it. Between the expansive base game, DLCs, mods, Rimworld provides a truly free to do whatever you wish experience like no other. Its story is what you make of it. You could play as a simple farming colony that exports its crops, a vampire cult of cannibals, or a drug lab of mole people that have augmented their bodies with bionics and gene tailoring. I'm glad it's been receiving more love recently and if you ever catch it on sale then don't pass it up!

If you want a game that gives you the freedom to design a colony and run it however you want, this is it without a doubt. 

The base game gives you so many options in terms of how you handle your little ant farm whether you want deadly cannibals, peaceful farmers or something in between. The DLC expands on this by introducing royalty and ideologies that give you more control over how your colonists react to any given situation and how they treat their fellow man/animal/plant/alien/robot etc. 

If this sounds like it's too good to be true, it's not because I've not mentioned the modding support yet. If you somehow find yourself bored then there's full mod support to guide you back into the light with gameplay overhauls, new buildings and materials,  AI storytellers, factions etc and it's all as easy as clicking "subscribe" in the workshop.

At roughly ¬£60 total for both DLC and base game, it's well worth the investment even more so when it's on sale, you'll lose days without realising.

Honestly one of the best and most riveting gaming experiences i've had. I love story based games but something about making your own story is so exciting. This game has excellent atmosphere, with battles and moments that see you grasping onto survival and scraping by day by day. At any moment things can go wrong, and all your work is thrown out in a dramatic and emotional ending, but one that is so rewarding and keeps you wanting more.
I recommend this game to anyone who loves stories of drama and brutality, and to those who like problem solving, building, and conquering. But i feel as if almost anyone can appreciate the stories to be a part of in RimWorld.

This game has grown into one of the best examples of depth over scope in games. It has literally hundreds of interconnected systems that build on each other to generate exponential depth in game play while keeping the game itself scaled down to an entirely reasonable and understandable slice of the larger world you're playing in. With a huge modding community there is effectively endless content to play with on top of an already expansive and robust base game and DLC. This game puts many, many, colony builders to shame.

It's one of those games that shine because of workshop support. Seriously go have a look at the workshop and you'll understand why this game is special. There are so many "hidden colony sim games" inside of this one.

Some possible combos you can achieve with mods are:
- Nuclear weapon enabled cannibal pacifists
- Warhammer 40k guardsmen fighting off Illithid hordes
- Organ harvesting Tolkien dwarves

A lot of vanilla gripes are solved by using mods. My wholehearted thanks go to the modding community, for making this game extra-special.

I heavily recommend picking up this game even when it's not on sale, maybe supporting Tynan, or your neighbourhood modder will yield some more cool new things into the game that can be hooked into and tweaked.

This is a great game!  Are you interested in fascinating, complex, and challenging game-play more than you are photo-realistic graphics that turn your $2000 machine into a potato?  Then give this a whirl.  You will get far more entertainment value for your dollar.

Infinite replay-ability.  Easy to nearly impossible game modes.  Varied and interesting challenges.  Harvest a lung, explode a rat, milk a cow and be crowned a duchess while shooting robot spiders with an RPG... all in the same day.

One of my favourite games out there. If you are looking for a story generator, then i recommend Rimworld. The introduction is pretty simple, a group of three colonists crashing on a rimworld and wanting to get back to the stars. There are multiple scenarios like a 5 member tribe but primitive technology, solo glitterworld colonist or the hardest and the one that really does well on youtube - naked brutality - solo colonist with nothing, pretty much fight for survival. Story tellers also spice up the game: Cassandra Classic - pretty much a mode of chill, then raid, then chill and so on... Phoebe Chillax - this one for the fellas that are learning the game or looking for a easy mode and the one and only Randy Random. The games DLCs are worth too, adding a new experience to the game. 

Personally i give this game a 10/10, i still come back to it and enjoy experimenting with the ideology system.

Title: "A Masterpiece of Storytelling and Strategy"

RimWorld stands out as a brilliant fusion of strategy and storytelling. Its deep, AI-driven narrative and complex systems create a dynamic and replayable experience. The game's intricate details, from colonist relationships to unexpected challenges, contribute to an immersive world. Balancing resources and making tough decisions adds strategic depth, while the modding community enhances customization. RimWorld's engaging gameplay, memorable characters, and limitless possibilities make it a standout title that excels in both storytelling and strategy.

One smexy ass game. 10/10

Rimworld is just one of those games you keep coming back to. Many times have I stopped playing for a few weeks and came back and thought "why did I stop playing this again?" The modding capability mixed with the DLCs makes the game endlessly replayable.

My alpaca, Jeremy, has dementia and is wandering around in a constant state of confusion. My researcher, Weaves, developed cataracts and has become restricted to the laboratory. My cook, Mila, lost both of her hands to a robot with blades instead of hands, so we subsequently removed the robot's blades and now Mila has blades for her hands. My crafting specialists all died in a horrific workshop fire. My herd of animals all died to a group of raiders with flamethrowers. The only romantic couple surviving is a misogynist and a misandrist that have been here since the beginning, and have taken a liking to each other. We've begun harvesting the organs of prisoners for profit and medical purposes. My doctor, Callahan, is also a cannibal, and recently ate a victim of a botched surgery. Jeremy, the alpaca with dementia, was recently killed by raiders, so we did the obvious thing. We slaughtered their entire village, took the civilians as prisoners, harvested their organs, and sent them into the world with one working lung, one working kidney, no eyes, no ears, no nose, one peg leg, and one steel arm each. I'm not sure if we're the good guys.

3rd DLC and 600 more hours again (i'm starting to see a pattern here), i still recommend that game !

2 DLC and 600 more hours of playtime later, time to update that evaluation (original one left down there if you wanna read it too). Gonna focus on the 2 new dlcs. So much new stuff added that improves QoL as well as adding content. And oh boy, what content it is ! Royalty added a new faction with its share of quests, a new ending, psy powers, and so on. Ideology on the other hand brought the belief system, allowing a deeper and more immersive customisation to your colony and playstyle. Wanna play as nudist raiders ? dwarves under the mountain ? blind and scarred ? Tree lovers ? Cowboys in the far west ? You can do it all and much more ! Those 2 dlcs were not expected but they sure are worth it ! And while i'm writing this, most of my mods are already updated to 1.3 so i'm not even losing much from my usual modlist. (some mods even got merged into the main game as QoL updates)
In any case, i sure do recommend that game ! And now, excuse me while i go back in there turning my archotect fanatics tunnelers into true mechanized warriors searching for the old one's sanctuary !

Played it a bit, liked it.

More seriously, this game is good. 

Vanilla, you'll meet a good challenge between the RNG from the storytellers, your dreams and your own mistakes. You'll play, and lose. Try again, and lose again, maybe even faster who knows ? But you'll come back and give it another go. Before you notice it, it's been 6 hours spent in a row on 3 or 4 colonies. You'll lower the difficulty, or try another storyteller, maybe even check some youtube videos to learn and understand the basics (i would recommend Eviltrick's channel and his stream, really good fella that will answer your questions if you have any, as well as the chat). Then you'll try again, and maybe do a bit better. Maybe a lot better ! You'll feel good about it ! Then you'll get crushed by mechs or a pirate raid that drop right in the middle of your colony.
Before you know it, you've been playing this game for months. few hours over there, the whole day over here.
Maybe you'll even manage to get the hang of all the trading part of the game, deal well with your Ancient Danger ?

And when you finally feel like the game is good but you could use a bit more challenge....
let me welcome you...
to the mods.
Gameplay overhaul ? New Factions ? QoL mods ? 
You can have it all !
Big fan of Lovecraft ? Get the Call of Cthulhu mod pack ! with factions, items, craft, creatures, Lovecraft himself as a storyteller and more !
Believe me, if you liked the vanilla game, you'll like the modded version. Get yourself a mod that allows you to create and manage your own mod list and you'll be able to switch between them with a few clicks and enjoy multiple ways of seeing your colony burn in agony ! what ? survive and reach the end game ? yeah, that too. maybe.. probably..

If you're looking for a video game that will captivate your mind, heart, and soul, look no further than RimWorld. This masterpiece of a colony management simulator offers a truly generative gameplay experience, where every playthrough is different. As you guide a crash-landed group of survivors on a hostile alien planet, you'll face countless challenges, from building a base and securing food to dealing with raids, natural disasters, and the emotional turmoil of your colonists.

RimWorld's brilliance lies in its ability to weave captivating stories around your every decision. Each colonist has their own unique personality, skills, and backstories, creating a complex social dynamic that you'll need to manage carefully. Will you nurture their relationships and keep them motivated, or will you focus on efficiency and let their spirits plummet? The choice is yours, and the consequences will shape the narrative of your colony.

Not only does RimWorld provide an endless supply of emergent storytelling, but it also boasts a thriving modding community. With thousands of mods available, you can tailor the game to your own preferences, adding new items, mechanics, and even different genres to your playthrough. Whether you want to transform your colony into a futuristic utopia or a post-apocalyptic wasteland, the possibilities are endless.

With its deep mechanics, endless replayability, and supportive modding community, RimWorld is a must-play for any fan of strategy games, colony sims, or just great storytelling. Prepare to lose hours upon hours as you immerse yourself in the captivating world of RimWorld, where every decision has a consequence and every story is unique.
